metaDescription: Range Rover Driving App is a new iPhone/iPad app that lets you experience a virtual drive through eight stages in the big Range Rover. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Land Rover North America wants you to know, really know, what it’s like to get behind the wheel of the new Range Rover. You don’t have to drop $83,000 to get the feeling; you can dial up an all-new app, The Trail Less Traveled, for free on your iTunes account for the iPhone or iPad. This is the first Land Rover app, but we’re betting it won’t be the last.

The Trail Less Traveled is part advertisement, part game. It takes you on an eight-stage interactive journey that will almost make you feel you are inside the big SUV. The action is shot from four synchronized camera angles, each of which you can select to change your point of view. It lets you virtually try out the iconic SUV both on and off road, inside and out. Want to see the view from a wide-angle camera? Prefer a tight closeup? How about the view from behind the wheel? Choose which view you want on the main screen, and continue to follow the others in smaller images on the side.

You can also choose music—electric, acoustic, or symphonic—while you drive through water, climb to the top of mountains, clamber through dunes, and overlook scenic vistas, all on the way to a luxury resort in the final stage. Following cues embedded throughout the game, you can swipe the screen for information and video clips showing various features of the Range Rover. At the end of the last stage, when you do get to the resort, you can go check in or keep driving.
It’s “an authentic Range Rover driving experience,” says the company. It’s also one hell of an advertisement for the SUV and the lifestyle that goes with owning one.
One quibble: That vehicle sure does look clean at the end. Where’s the dirt? Because I’d need that to feel I was getting all the fun out of the Range Rover.

subTitle: Could VW interest you in a 210-hp turbo?
promoTeaserSmall: Could VW interest you in a 210-hp turbo?
promoTeaser: Just in time for spring,VW rolls out a little more power, better fuel economy, and a sporty R-Line.
metaTitle: 2013 Volkswagen Beetle Powers Up - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: 2013 Volkswagen Beetle Powers Up with a 10-hp increase to the four-cylinder turbo, plus a sporty R-Line version of the Turbo. Read about them on JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: Thinking of putting a fun little car or even, considering the time of year, a fun little convertible into your life? Volkswagen has just rolled out the Beetle Turbo R-Line, a sportier version of its Beetle Turbo. Its engine is an improvement on the current Beetle Turbo, up 10 horsepower to 210 hp, yet it's up to nine percent more fuel-efficient around town.

The improved version of the four-cylinder TSI engine is for the regular Beetle Turbo as well. The 2013 Beetle Turbo comes in both coupe and convertible versions. It starts at $25,165; for that price, you get amenities such as a spoiler, V-Tex leatherette seating, a leather-wrapped steering wheel, and an eight-speaker audio system as well as interior and exterior chrome.

If you move up to the new R-Line (pictured above), the starting price is $30,930, and you’ll get nineteen-inch wheels (up from seventeen-inch on the standard Turbo), bi-xenon LED headlights, and a sportier set of bumpers on both ends. Inside, you’ll find real leather seating, a navigation system, stainless steel kickplates, and a chrome vanadium dashboard panel. What you won't get is a convertible version; the R-Line is available in coupe form only.
On any Beetle Turbo, a six-speed manual transmission is standard; the six-speed dual-clutch automatic transmission is an $1,100 option.
The more powerful Turbo and Turbo R-Line will reach dealers this month, VW says.

contributors.bio: Holly has reported on cars, lifestyle, travel, and everything else for publications including the New York Daily News, Redbook, Elite Traveler, and Fox TV. She lives in New York City with her family, including Jack, a toy poodle (and test driving partner!).

header.title: car seat that talks to your phone

homepage.title: car seat that talks to your phone

pageElements.text: The warm months are here, and with them the first news reports of children left in hot cars, often with disastrous consequences. Have you ever wondered why somebody doesn’t come up with a child seat that tells you if you’re about to accidentally walk away from a sleeping infant in a car? The thought has occurred to us.

So when we learned about The First Years’ True Fit IAlert car seat, we were intrigued. This is a convertible car seat that syncs with a smartphone. Using a monitoring sensor integrated into the car seat, this seat can alert you when a child is left in the car when it’s not moving—or if a toddler manages to get out of a seat when the car is moving.

At $399.99, the IAlert seat is priced way higher than traditional convertible seats, but it does offer the first commercial application of this kind of safety technology in a child seat. The seat is expected to be available at the end of June but can be pre-ordered at Amazon.com now.

There are three situations in which your smartphone will receive visual and audible alerts from the IAlert seat:

    • The child is left in the seat and the car is not moving.
    • The child manages to get out of the seat while the vehicle is moving.
    • The Bluetooth connection is interrupted between the smartphone and the seat.

IAlert also helps in two other ways:

    • Showing the angle orientation of the seat so you can achieve the correct angle when you use the seat in the rear-facing installation for children under age two.
    • Constantly monitoring the temperature in the back seat in real time and displaying it on the IAlert app.

When you install the app on your phone, you can choose to set up an even greater security measure that makes the phone send an e-mail or text to your friends, caregivers, or family members if you do not acknowledge certain alerts as you receive them. We’re guessing that’s a setting for worried parents to use when a babysitter is the one transporting the child.

The Danger Is Real

How necessary is this new technology? According to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA), heat stroke, or hyperthermia, is the leading cause of non-crash vehicular deaths in children under the age of fourteen.

On a moderate day, the interior temperature of a car can climb twenty degrees in ten minutes. On an 80-degree day, the cabin of a car can reach 100 degrees in the time it takes to pick up a package of diaper wipes at your local convenience store. The fact is that a child’s body can heat up five times faster than an adult’s. In other words, a child can die from heat stroke on a 72-degree day.

This kind of technology has been looked at before. Just last year, NHTSA researched eighteen safety devices meant to alert parents or caregivers that a child has accidentally been left behind in a hot car.  The tested products were found to be inconsistent and unreliable.

The researchers found that many of the products required too much setup work. Also, the restraint-based inventory didn’t address the 20 to 40 percent of kids who are killed in hot cars when they enter a vehicle without adult permission. That question still hasn’t been solved.

NASA Had This Idea Years Ago

NASA came up with an early concept, the Child Presence Sensor (CPS), in 2002. The device, inspired by aircraft flight test technology, senses when a child is seated in a car infant or booster seat after the driver has left the vehicle.

Designed to hang on the driver's key ring, the CPS has an alarm that sounds ten warning beeps if the driver moves too far away from the vehicle. If the driver doesn't return within one minute, the alarm beeps continuously until he or she returns to the child safety seat and resets it.

The CPS never got off the ground. The device still exists as a prototype because it has not been licensed to a commercial manufacturer. When we got in touch with Chris Rink, public affairs specialist at NASA, he suggested that we take a look at a similar invention—the IAlert seat.

Good Tips to Remember

But whether you want to pay $60 or $400 for a car seat, it’s important to know the basics. The following are tips from NHTSA’s national campaign, "Where's baby? Look before you lock."

• Never leave a child unattended in a vehicle.
    • Do not let your children play in an unattended vehicle.
    • Never leave infants or children in a parked vehicle, even if the windows are partially open.
    • Keep a large teddy bear or other stuffed animal in the car seat when it's empty. Move the teddy bear to the front seat when you place the child in the seat as a visual reminder.
    • Make a habit of looking in the vehicle—front and back—before locking the door and walking away.
    • If you are dropping your child off at childcare, have your spouse or partner call you to make sure the drop went according to plan.

title: GM Signs Climate Change Declaration
subTitle: Does this change how you see GM?
promoTeaserSmall: General Motors looks to set a good sustainability example among auto companies.
promoTeaser: General Motors looks to set a good sustainability example among auto companies.
metaTitle: GM Signs Climate Change Declaration - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: GM Signs Climate Change Declaration, the first automaker to do this. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text:
How much should auto companies show they care about global warming? That's a question that may come up more, now that General Motors has become the first automaker to sign the Business for Innovative Climate and Energy Policy (BICEP)’s Climate Declaration.

GM inked the agreement last week and becomes one of forty other major U.S. companies to endorse the declaration.

Is this mere lip service? Maybe. But it does take a stand, calling on businesses and policy makers to acknowledge climate change and address it by encouraging clean energy and efficiency and limits on carbon emissions. Many Americans now believe that climate change is happening and would like corporations and politicians to do more to address the issue. A statement like this could be a start.
The Climate Declaration isn’t specific about what should be done, but that hasn’t stopped dozens of companies—ranging from Nestle to Intel—from signing on.

GM Is an Early Adopter on This Stuff

This isn’t the first we’ve heard from GM about climate change and sustainability. In March, GM CEO Dan Akerson called on President Obama to form a blue-ribbon commission to develop a long-term policy framework for energy security. Mike Robinson, GM’s vice-president of sustainability and global regulatory affairs, has said that he wants GM to be an agent of change in the automotive industry, boasting that the automaker is “at the forefront of changing the way we move.” And GM listed what it has already done and plans to do about the issue in its first Sustainability Report in 2012.

images.caption: 2014 Cadillac ELR (shown here in cold-weather testing)

pageElements.text: Then, of course, there are GM’s green vehicles. The extended-range plug-in Chevrolet Volt (shown above using a solar charging station) will be joined by the fully electric Chevrolet Spark EV this summer and a diesel-powered Cruze this fall. The Cadillac ELR, which shares the Volt’s extended-range technology, will hit showrooms next year.

pageElements.text: I love road trips. My husband, Tim, and I prefer to drive whenever we’re going on a trip if we have the time. He especially likes to drive, so I frequently find myself in the role of passenger for hours on end. In the case of this road trip, from Michigan to New York City for the New York Auto Show, we brought along videographer Scott Allen.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/qVmw-1BbJeY?list=UUKWoLlV8-sE8zQnoWHI9qoA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

The only problem: there were three of us and all our stuff. Tim had to drive the entire distance, because he couldn’t fit in either the front passenger's seat or the back seat. I literally sat upright in the passenger's seat; I couldn’t put the seat back, because Scott was sitting right behind me. On the bright side, there was no problem with seatroom in the back, no problem with headroom, and the panoramic window helped prevent claustrophobia.

My Evoque History

This wasn't our first trip in the Evoque. Last New Year’s Eve, Tim and I decided on a whim to drive from Michigan to visit a dear friend in New Hampshire whom we were missing. It was really cold but not snowing badly. However, we knew we were heading into a blizzard.

At Automobile Magazine, we had had a history of breakdown problems with Land Rover products in the past. Consumer Reports rates the Evoque at fifty-eight out of 100 points overall, dead last in its category of compact sporty SUVs. We wondered, would it be okay to take this car across the country in a blizzard?

We decided that we were going to go for it anyway, and we sure did hit a blizzard. Driving through it, the Evoque was a tank. It was a mountain goat. It was as solid as a rock. You get the idea: it never slipped, and it was steady. Loved the 240-horsepower turbocharged engine, too. On the way home, it was seriously windy and cold, but the wind didn't buffet the car at all. In fact, the wind was unnoticeable while we were moving.
We're really glad that the Evoque was the vehicle we took to New Hampshire, and equally glad to have chosen it to take us to New York City this time.

But Can It Carry Enough Hats?

The short answer: yes. On this trip to the auto show, I planned to visit a couple of hatmakers (see videos of my shopping adventures with New York hatmakers Barbara Feinman and Jasmin Zorlu), so I was doubly worried about space. In the end, as you'll see in the video, I shifted a few bags and jammed a couple more hat boxes in there. It worked out great.

title: 2013 Mercedes-Benz GLK250 BlueTec
subTitle: Behind the wheel of the clean diesel
promoTeaserSmall: Behind the wheel of the clean diesel
promoTeaser: BlueTec has a great reputation as environmentally friendly technology. But how is the car to drive?
metaTitle: 2013 Mercedes-Benz GLK250 BlueTec - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: 2013 Mercedes-Benz GLK250 BlueTec: is it as fun to drive as it is environmentally creative? I drove it to find out. Read my impressions on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: We’ve been singing the praises of clean diesel cars for months. They have great fuel economy and durable engines, but they’re not loud or smelly the way old diesel burners were. Sounds great, but does the reality live up to the hype? I drove Mercedes-Benz’s new GLK250 BlueTec to find out.

The GLK is Mercedes-Benz’s entry-level small SUV. The base model GLK350 starts at $37,995, including destination, and earns 25 mpg on the highway—not bad for a car its size, but not stellar, either. It’s a touch small to be a family car—75 percent of GLK buyers are childless—but it’s plenty big enough to haul a weekend getaway’s worth of luggage to a cabin in the woods or to take four adults to dinner in the city.

BlueTec Mercedes Impresses in Highway Mileage

Better yet, the GLK’s new variant, the aforementioned GLK250 BlueTec, adds a diesel engine to the mix, giving the GLK both some added efficiency and extra torque. The 2.1-liter diesel engine makes 200 horsepower and 369 pound-feet of torque. It also earns a rather impressive 33 mpg on the highway, a number I easily matched on my drive despite putting the car in sport mode and employing my usual spirited driving style.

True to its promise, the diesel engine hummed along without emitting any offensive noises or smells. In fact, if it hadn’t been for the added torque aiding my accelerations, I might never have guessed it was an oil burner.

Black Ash and Steel Grey

The interior of my test car was comfortable and stylish, with dark seating and wood trim in a pleasing black ash. My test car’s equally pleasing Steel Grey exterior paint is a $720 option—less than the $750 buyers would have to pay for heated front seats or the $2,790 it takes to get the COMAND infotainment system with Mercedes-Benz’s mbrace suite.

The GLK250 will be Mercedes-Benz’s fifth diesel in their U.S. model lineup, and despite the technology’s lukewarm reception on this side of the pond, the carmaker is confident that the new addition to the Bluetec family will perform well. Bart Herring, Mercedes Benz’s general manager of product management, expects that diesel engines will make up ten to fifteen percent of GLK sales. Only about two percent of all U.S. vehicle sales are diesels.

Going Diesel Getting More Affordable

Part of the reason Mercedes-Benz expects the car to do so well is that they have done away with the significant premium that many diesels are burdened with. Starting at $39,495, the GLK250 BlueTec with 4Matic all-wheel drive is more expensive than the base model GLK, but less expensive than a GLK350 with 4Matic, which starts at $39,995. Sandwiched in the middle of the lineup, the GLK250 could just hit a sweet spot for diesel-curious shoppers.

title: Mercedes Employees Work for Charity
subTitle: An example of an automaker giving back
promoTeaserSmall: Dozens of nonprofits benefit when Mercedes-Benz Financial Services lends out workers for a week.
promoTeaser: Dozens of nonprofits benefit when Mercedes-Benz Financial Services lends out workers for a week.
metaTitle: Mercedes Employees Work for Charity - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Mercedes Employees Work for Charity during a Week of Giving, May 6-10, notably in Detroit and Fort Worth. Details on our website: JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Mercedes-Benz Financial Services employees are doing community projects in Detroit all this week in an initiative called “Week of Caring.” The employees are wearing T-shirts labeled ROI, for Return on Involvement, and they’re spreading out to charities, including Habitat for Humanity homes, the American Red Cross, the Community Food Bank, Greening of Detroit tree-planting efforts, and even a local elementary school.

This is an annual event for the financial arm of Mercedes-Benz, and it’s not limited to Detroit: more than 1,000 employees in five countries across the continent are working for a total of thirty-five nonprofits. The other major U.S. effort is in Fort Worth, Texas.

Employees at Mercedes-Benz Financial Services get to work with other employees in their departments once a year, as well as another day of their choice, for a charity they choose, that is offered as a paid personal holiday. These photos are from the Mercedes-Benz Financial Services Facebook page. Visit the page for more images of their work.

Mercedes is not alone in organizing a charity-oriented week for employees. To name just two, Ford ran its seventh annual community service week last September, and General Motors’ inaugural teamGM Cares week of charity work also took place last September. It’s great to see a big company reaching out into the community in this way.

title: Horseless Carriages in Central Park?
subTitle: Would you go on a romantic EV ride?
promoTeaserSmall: Would you go on a romantic EV ride?
promoTeaser: Electric cars that look like 1909 Pierce-Arrows could replace horses, if animal rights groups win the day.
metaTitle: Horseless Carriages in Central Park?
metaKeywords: Horse and Carriage Association of New York City
metaDescription: Horseless Carriages in Central Park? Animal rights groups are helping fund a prototype of an electric car to replace the horse-drawn carriage. It's controversial, like most issues in New York City. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I don’t understand people who dislike driving. I really don't. The freedom of getting behind the wheel of a car and just taking off can't be compared with anything else. You really feel that you’re in charge: in charge of the car, in charge of the road, and in charge of your life. Why on earth would you want someone else to drive you around when you could do it yourself? It’s so liberating! Obviously, I love driving. I suppose that isn't a particularly original statement for a Detroit native, but it's true. I was a little late getting my driver's license because of that pesky parallel parking, but once I got it, nothing could stop me. It doesn't matter if I have to chauffeur my grandmother to the bank less than a block from our house or drive across town. If I have my green Chrysler LHS--affectionately christened "Betsy" by my mother--and some gas in the tank, and if I am somehow able to avoid getting pulled over for driving just a little too fast, I'm good to go.

Since I graduated from the University of Michigan, in April 2012, Betsy has taken me everywhere. She has been my steadfast companion on trips to buy more supplies for various sewing projects, leisurely drives along Jefferson/Lakeshore Drive in Grosse Pointe Shores, Michigan, and frequent jaunts to the bookstore to buy yet another copy of Hamlet, a 500-plus-page book on Elizabeth I, or a good book on British history that isn’t as dry as a piece of chalk…And, yes, there is a little bit of theme there. Not only am I a bibliophile, but I’m also a self-proclaimed Anglophile who loves Shakespeare and Elizabethan verse and one day plans to see the Houses of Parliament, visit the Tower of London, and, perhaps most important, eat real fish and chips. If only I could drive Betsy "across the pond…"

pageElements.text: Taking a nice, leisurely drive through Central Park in a horse-drawn carriage is a longstanding tradition, but if a certain New York-based animal welfare nonprofit gets its way, that tradition will be changing.

In late April, New Yorkers for Clean, Livable, and Safe Streets (NYCLASS) signed a contract with Jason Wenig, founder and president of The Creative Workshop, a coachbuilding and restoration firm in Florida, to build a full-scale prototype of an all-electric, seven-passenger horseless carriage. He's calling it the Eco-Carriage.

“Even though passengers will feel like they are being transmitted to the Gatsby era, the electric car will have cutting-edge battery and EV technology and many ergonomic and safety features not found on the horse-drawn carriages or the original cars for that matter,” Wenig said. “Not to mention, it can hold more passengers than the carriages and is outfitted and amenable to all types of weather.”

This Is a Big Controversy If You Live in New York City

Although Wenig’s car, inspired by a 1909 Pierce-Arrow and a 1909 Packard, isn't exactly Jay Gatsby's 1920s-era Rolls-Royce, NYCLASS has been petitioning the New York City Council to approve a pilot program that will run the prototype through Central Park along the carriage route. NYCLASS has been agitating for changes to city regulations that would increase safety and animal protection for the 220 horses that pull carriages—mostly without success so far. NYCLASS is a five-year-old organization that has the support of the ASPCA, which has long opposed putting horses to work inside the city. The group also claims support for its goal, getting rid of horse-drawn carriages, from a coalition of animal rescue groups, PETA, and more than half of the city council members, including Melissa Mark-Viverito (D-Manhattan), who has sponsored legislation offering an alternative to horse-drawn carriages.

According to NYCLASS and the ASPCA, carriage horses are to be pitied. They work for at least nine hours every day while inhaling exhaust fumes and navigating streets choked with cars and buses. Because horses are generally unaccustomed to urban life, they can become scared quite easily by traffic noise and congestion and have been known to cause accidents, endangering coachmen, pedestrians, other drivers, and themselves. Replacing the carriages with turn-of-the-century-inspired EVs, they say, could reduce the number of horse-related accidents in the city and improve the quality of life for both horses and humans, all while retaining the romance of a carriage ride.

However, Mayor Bloomberg himself is against the idea, and in that he's joined by the Horse and Carriage Association of New York City (naturally), whose employees are represented by Teamsters Local 553, as well as the politically ambitious speaker of the city council, Christine Quinn.

But How Do The Horses Feel about It?

If the proposal succeeds, the horses would be out of a job, but they wouldn't have to fear the glue factory: NYCLASS and the ASPCA declare they'll find "retirement homes" for every horse.

“[Our] objective is the well-being of the horses,” said Bret Hopman, senior media and communications manager for the ASPCA. “While we welcome regulations that would improve their well-being while they're on the streets, we ultimately view the provisions outlined in [Councilwoman Mark-Viverito’s] legislation that calls for a phase-out of horse carriages in New York City, replacing them with electric-powered classic cars, as the best approach, because they address the economic, environmental, and quality of life interests of the horses as well as the people.”

In addition to the political complexities of legislating the horses out of Central Park, a major obstacle to the horseless-carriage plan would be cost: the pilot program would cost $450,000 for just one prototype car. NYCLASS intends to pay this cost, but so far, there has been no word on a financial plan beyond that.

pageElements.text: I’ve been racking up to 100,000 miles a year since my late teenage years, when I was a taxicab owner/operator. There is nothing I love to do more than to teach kids the driving secrets I’ve learned over the miles. Damn. I wish had me around when I was their age. I would have told me how stupid it was to drive everywhere at 100 miles an hour. I would have learned emergency maneuvers long before I actually had to make one.
Of course, there is nothing like, oh, a few million or so miles behind the wheel, with a chunk of that at high speed on a racetrack, to give you a tad of well-earned confidence behind the wheel.
At least I learned how to drive a stick before I saw my first automatic.

So here I am, ready to serve. This isn’t a comprehensive driver’s ed class. I’m aiming with the No. 1 Ladies' Driving Academy to share the things I’ve learned wayyy outside the classroom. I want kids to know as many different ways as possible of getting out of trouble on the road. Like, say, avoiding it altogether.
I will keep making these videos as long as there are kids (and don’t take that Ladies thing seriously; boys Я allowed) with new questions about how to do whatever it is they are afraid of doing.
Ask and you will receive.

Love,
Jean

pageElements.text: Andy Warhol’s splashy red, green, blue, and yellow 1979 BMW M1 art car was on display at the inaugural Paris Photo Los Angeles fair this April. Warhol’s pop aesthetic has endured on the number 76 racing car that ran at the 24 Hours of Le Mans in 1979. A film depicting Warhol’s process was on view at the photo fair held at Paramount Pictures Studio, which focused on the art of the still and moving image. BMW has been a partner in the fair for ten years in Paris, where it is held at the Grand Palais. This inaugural Los Angeles event featured sixty international art galleries and public conversations with artists, curators, and Hollywood luminaries.

image.altText: warhol s bmw m1 art car visits la

pageElements.text: Warhol, whose films and Polaroid pictures are a substantial part of his body of work, painted the car by himself, allowing the immediacy of his strokes to guide his expressive work. The car was intentionally made to look blurred, capturing what he felt was the action of speed. “I love that car. It has turned out better than the artwork,” Warhol said of the M1.

BMW has commissioned seventeen art cars for its collection since Alexander Calder made the first one in 1975. The French racing driver Hervé Poulain originally approached Calder to customize his car, which led to the creation of the collection.

images.caption: The first BMW art car: Alexander Calder, BMW 3.0 CSL, 1975
Jenny Holzer, BMW V-12 Le Mans roadster, 1999

pageElements.text: Each art car has its own story, authentic to the major artists invited to create them, including Jenny Holzer, Robert Rauschenberg, Frank Stella, and, most recently, Jeff Koons in 2010. The Koons car, like the Warhol car, raced at Le Mans. The BMW art cars are widely regarded as important works of art and include a range of vehicles that capture the essence of an era in automotive design. The art cars have traveled the world and been presented in major exhibitions in the Louvre Museum in Paris and the Guggenheim Museum in New York. The permanent collection is housed in the BMW Museum in Munich, Germany.

The video series lets Walsh compliment Cadillac for giving her a moment of quiet amidst the chaos,” as well as to praise the auto company for “consistently guarding the marriage of art and commerce.” The Manhattan streets look good on the gleaming black crossover, although the parking question went unanswered. Cadillac’s SRX not only starred in the videos, but the automaker also supplied valet service at the gala for certain VIPs.

Walsh, whose styling prowess has been seen on such luminaries as Gwyneth Platrow and Kristen Wiig, is working in this series with actress Greta Gerwig (of Arthur, the Woody Allen film To Rome with Love, and the upcoming Frances Ha, which she co-wrote). It was an opportunity for Cadillac to draw parallels between its own emphasis on looks and style and the fashion and movie industries.

This year’s theme for the ball, perhaps a bit of a stretch for Cadillac, was “Punk: Chaos to Couture.” An exhibition related to that theme is on display at the Met from May 9 through August 14. The Cadillac-themed videos are on Vogue.tv’s YouTube channel.

metaTitle: Fast Women: Audi's Simone Gronewald - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Fast Women: Audi's Simone Gronewald is the designer behind the graphics and instrument clusters in Audi's concept cars. Dealing with human-instrument interface is her strength. Read my interview with her on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: There’s a lot more that goes into designing a car besides deciding what the body panels should look like. From drag coefficients to the shape of the seats, everything is considered.

Simone Gronewald is a woman with one of those jobs you might not know existed if you weren’t thinking about it, but that doesn’t mean it’s not interesting. Gronewald works in graphical user interface design for Audi Design in Ingolstadt, Germany.  She’s behind the graphics and instrument clusters in Audi’s concept cars, so she spends her days dreaming up the car of the future.

Since landing at Audi, she has worked on the Crosslane Coupé Concept, the Urban Concept, and the 2011 A2 Concept. I caught up with Gronewald on the very day that her most recent project, the Audi TT Ultra Quattro Concept, was announced as one of the show cars for Wörthersee, the annual Volkswagen and Audi car show in Reifnitz, Austria.

Can you explain what "design for graphical user interface" means?

[At] Audi, I’m doing the MMI system: the navigation telephone screen, radio screen, and also the instrument clusters. I’m strongly connected with the [interface] interaction. I work together with our human machine interface department. They are responsible for making all the concepts.

Were you always interested in designing for cars?

I was always interested in designing for cars. I once asked my mother when I started to be interested in design at all. There is a nice story that I was sitting [in] our car when I was eight years old and I told my mother, “I will be a car designer.”
Since I was very, very little, my father and my grandfather always drove Mercedes-Benzes. I was allowed to sit in the car and pretend to drive the car.

Tell me what led to your job at Mercedes-Benz.

My thesis actually didn’t have anything in common with the automobile industry. I decided to make a digital sketchbook. This was a very conceptual work. For me, a digital sketchbook should have all the advantages of the analogical world and the digital world. You should have a physical product that looks like a sketchbook, but you also have everything digital. You can copy and paste; you can see a timeline of the sketch. I was thinking about technology. I was thinking about e-paper. I didn’t have a prototype, but I decided to make a video, and that video was enough to get me an interview [with Mercedes-Benz].

How is designing for concepts different from designing for production cars?

First of all, for concept cars, you have a lot less time: you have just a few months. You are very happy if you have a year. For production, you have five years.

In these few months, you have to design your concept and [the engineers] have to build the design. In the Crosslane [right], we tried out transparent OLED displays that you cannot use in cars now because they’re not automotive yet. We used it for the climate control, and as they are transparent displays, we could position them one behind the other and switch between them. At the end, everybody is proud when they can see the car at the fair.

What is your goal when you get to work every day?

My biggest goal is [to have] the graphics integrated into the car. When I start the project, I try to see the model from the very beginning, see what the interior designer wants, and see what the exterior designer wants. I want to make sure that the graphics are very well integrated.

image.altText: Audi TT Ultra Quattro Concept INT 622

pageElements.text:
What are you working on right now?

At the moment I’m working on concepts and production. For production, I really can’t say because it’s all secret, and for concepts, it was the TT Ultra Quattro Concept—we will show the whole car at Wörthersee. [The instrument panel is shown at right; see the photo gallery for the car.]

Do you think being a woman has given you an advantage in your line of work?

I hope not. And I don’t think so. I think that if you apply for a job, you have to convince with your design. Sometimes it’s actually hard when you go into technical detail: you have to convince people that you can understand technology even though you’re a woman.

What’s your dream project?

I have one that’s not really related to the automotive industry: I’d love to publish a photo story.

metaDescription: Auto Racing 101 is a brief guide to what each kind of racing is, what the cars are, what the point is, and why somebody should care to watch or follow it. Indy Car, Formula 1, NASCAR, etc. Read it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
When Automobile launched in 1986, my byline appeared on a sidebar to the cover story written by our founding editor David E. Davis, Jr. Yet it wasn’t inevitable that I’d write for the magazine, even though my childhood was heavily automobile-flavored: my father raced jalopies and late-model stock cars on the oval tracks around Omaha, Nebraska, where we lived, and my favorite uncle liked drag racing and hot rods.

After earning a B.A. in English from the University of Nebraska, I moved to Los Angeles to become a screenwriter. Instead, though, I ended up holding cue cards on TV shows, including the soap opera Days of Our Lives. My first magazine story, the inside scoop on how we prepared those cue cards, appeared with my own photos in Soap Opera Digest.

In my freelance career, I’ve written for Bon Appétit, the Wall Street Journal, and many others. I started corresponding for the Automobiles desk at the New York Times in 2010, which is proving to be a great relationship. As a change of pace, my historical column for DBusiness (“Detroit’s Premier Business Journal”) has run since 2006. But while a food-and-wine tour can get boring after a couple of days, nothing beats a call from Automobile. I’ve been behind the wheel of everything from a Ferrari 458 Italia (“Blood Red to Goodwood,” March 2011) to the Fiat 500 Abarth. On assignment for “Three Zero Heroes,” I co-drove the winning BMW X3 in the 2004 Alcan Winter Rally. Teaming again with the same navigator, we won the 2006 Carolina Trophy, bulldogging a 1951 Chrysler Saratoga to the finish for “Substance over Style.”

Other assignments have placed me not only in the driver’s seat of a Porsche 911 Targa for the 2002 Targa Newfoundland, a plummy nod that seemed to indicate my editors’ favor, but also in the co-driver’s seat of a Class 1 buggy for the 2003 Baja 1000, suggesting they wanted me dead.

As you might guess, there’s no regret about failing as a screenwriter. And now I’m beginning something new: teaching automotive journalism at Art Center College of Design, in Pasadena. My workshop, Creating Content for Automotive Media, launched in 2012 and will be offered twice a year. I look forward to helping students along on their way to incomparable automotive adventures and working with the best editors in the business.

pageElements.text: Auto racing is a fabulous spectacle, whether seen in person or on TV. The tracks are huge theaters. When followed regularly, the sport offers the rewards—and sometimes pain—of human drama. Drivers and mechanics struggle against adversity, use their athletic ability under extreme circumstances in concert with machinery, and face injury and death.
No matter what the racing series, rules ensure that competition is tight: three-tenths of a second per lap is a huge advantage.

The show goes on ten months of the year. Changing backdrops add interest. Rivalries are played out to stunning effect. Villains emerge. Like most soap operas, there’s even a hospital: every track has an infield care center.
Here’s a look at the different major leagues of racing and why your interest may be rewarded:

Formula 1

Growing out of competition among aristocrats in quest of the Grand Prix, or top prize, of European nations before World War II, Formula 1 fields highly advanced automobiles.

The open-wheel cars (meaning the wheels sit outside the body) look like stick insects on wheels, and their tiny but potent V-8 engines, situated behind the drivers, shriek like unleashed geophysical forces. The drivers—no women, currently—tend to be slightly larger than jockeys; their daily gym workouts are grueling.

Truly global, F1 holds its glittering events everywhere from Shanghai to central Texas. The races are conducted on purpose-built tracks with numerous turns, both sweeping fast ones and tight and fast ones. Monaco’s famous race, the Monaco Grand Prix, scheduled for May 26, follows streets in this principality on the Riviera. The season goes from March to November. This year's U.S. Grand Prix is the penultimate event, held on November 17 at the Circuit of the Americas in Austin, Texas.

Technologies refined in F1—antilock brakes, electronic management of engines and other components, and even tire design—filter down to your driveway. The byzantine rules require cars to weigh at minimum 1,420 pounds—less than half the weight of a Ford Focus—and coin strange terms for parts like the modesty panels over the nose, which are an aerodynamic factor.

So who cares? We know a woman in Los Angeles, the proud owner of a BMW, who used to rise at three a.m. on Sunday morning to watch the Hungarian Grand Prix. Now she sleeps the night through but enjoys the recorded races at a friend’s house.

NASCAR

The National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing (NASCAR) emphasizes entertainment over technology. Its Sprint Cup championship series is America’s most popular racing league.

NASCAR first raced regular Chevrolets and other familiar makes that were modified with speed parts developed by moonshiners. They ran on short tracks in the Southeast and the shoreline at Daytona Beach. The preeminent tradition of oval superspeedways arose at Darlington, South Carolina, and the massive 2.5-mile track built at Daytona in 1959.
Now, although the cars’ bodies must be identically shaped, they still look like Fords, Chevrolets, and Toyotas, thanks to good graphic design. All entries use the same roaring V-8 engine.

NASCAR’s tremendous TV ratings are due in large part to huge crashes, which rarely cause injury because of the cars’ internal reinforcement. Top drivers have long careers. Ally yourself with one, perhaps Danica Patrick, and you’ll watch every week.

IndyCar

The Izod IndyCar Series has roots at obscure one-mile horse tracks in Illinois and Indiana, as well as the Indianapolis Motor Speedway, where the 500-mile race was first run in 1911.

Today’s IndyCar league is similar to Formula 1. The cars are open wheeled like those in F1, but IndyCar's racing cars have turbocharged V-6 engines and a semi-batwing shape. Street circuits, oval tracks large and small, and dedicated road-racing circuits are used. All races are in North America except one in Brazil, where several IndyCar drivers come from.
Currently, Simona de Silvestro is the league’s top woman, and some are betting on her to become the second female IndyCar race winner after Danica Patrick.

Endurance and Sports Car Racing

In France, the 24 Hours of Le Mans has been one of the world’s more important races since 1923, when it was initiated. A unique, wedgy sports-prototype car has developed for the top formula, rather like an F1 car with fenders. Audi’s dominant cars use hybrid turbodiesel-and-electric propulsion systems. Four-driver teams split shifts behind the wheel.
Other competitive classes at Le Mans include very close relatives of roadgoing Ferraris, Porsches, and Corvettes.

In America, the American Le Mans Series (ALMS) practices a similar discipline, with races held on city streets (Baltimore, Maryland, and Long Beach, California) as well as dedicated circuits like Road Atlanta, which every October hosts the season-ending Petit Le Mans, covering 1,000 miles or ten hours, whichever comes first. ALMS races offer a glittery, high-toned atmosphere similar to that of Formula 1.

Drag Racing

The National Hot Rod Association (NHRA) grew from match races held at local airports and paved quarter-mile strips, and it’s still a hoot. Four big-time classes use widely different formulas: Top Fuel, Funny Car, Pro Stock, and Pro Stock Motorcycle. Outrageous invention characterizes drag racing, and the cars and bikes are like living, fire-breathing cartoons.

Women are increasingly involved in the NHRA. Because drag racing is good TV fare, picking your own icon of speed can lead to an engaging experience—maybe even to your own participation during the local track’s amateur night.
Incidentally, because of their treadless tires, known as slicks, the NHRA and NASCAR are the only major leagues that stop the action when raindrops fall.

“Seldom has so much automotive charisma been carried by a mere handful of letters and numbers.”—Karl Ludvigsen, The Mercedes-Benz Racing Cars


This article was originally published in the December 1986 issue of Automobile Magazine.

Why are we bringing it back right now (other than because it's a great story)? Because Mercedes-Benz USA CEO Steve Cannon and I will be back in a Gullwing next week for the historic Mille Miglia in Italy. Pictures and stories to come!

Essex, Massachusetts, fall 1986—Alex Finigan doesn’t own a Mercedes-Benz 300SL. Few people do: only 1,400 of the spectacular Gullwings were built from 1954 to 1957. But Finigan has been restoring them for a decade, most recently for Paul Russell at the Gullwing Service Company, thirty-five miles north of Boston in Essex.

There are two parts to Alex Finigan: he is the worst sort of car freak, one who has a photographic memory and who has twenty car magazines delivered to his house every month. And Finigan is a full-blown nut case. Sha Na Na on speed. “We never see Alex down,” say his coworkers. “In the shop, he’s a howl. If he hears a song he likes on the radio, he puts it up real loud and sings at the top of his lungs. Alex really enjoys life.”
“I’m a fourteen-year-old,” says Finigan, eyes crossed and tongue out, “with forty years’ experience.”

You need to know a little of Paul Russell’s philosophy on the art of Gullwing restoration to understand why customer Nick Jones loaned Alex Finigan his rare $150,000, aluminum-bodied 1955 Gullwing (number twenty-eight of twenty-nine aluminum Gullwings made) to drive to Monterey. The Gullwing Service Company is not a museum. When the guys come to work and look around the shop (today the work bays hold a 1957 Gullwing, a 1957 Roadster, a 1953 170S, a 1961 Roadster, an aluminum Gullwing belonging to Ralph Lauren, a white 1956 Gullwing, and a chassis believed to be the first Gullwing), they see cars. And their job is to put those cars back on the road in perfect running order—in most cases, better than new.

On the subject of concours-quality cosmetics, Paul Russell says: “It seems nasty to have a guy with white gloves on stick his finger up your tailpipe.” Not that the Gullwing Service Company won’t or can’t do a concours-winning restoration. But to the guys in Essex, the matter of restoring the greatest of Mercedes-Benz production cars goes much deeper than the number of lacquer coats on the car’s sensuous skin.

In its day, the 300SL was revolutionary. “With its unsurpassed speed, its acceleration still strong up in the three-figure region, and its exotic good looks and technical features, the 300SL hit the motoring world with the impact of a sledgehammer,” wrote Karl Ludvigsen. Mercedes-Benz had never intended to build a production Gullwing. But Max Hoffman, the man responsible for bringing the greatest European marques to America in the 1950s, was enthralled by the 300SL that won the 1952 Carrera Panamericana. He convinced Mercedes-Benz to put the car on the street by promising cash for the delivery of 1,000 production 300SLs.

The car made its debut before the public at the 1954 New York International Motor Sports Show, showcasing the industry’s first production fuel injection system. The 240-horsepower in-line six-cylinder engine used an overhead cam, and the injection pump housed a built-in altimeter and thermostat to compensate for air density changes. An aluminum intake manifold sprouted ram pipes to each of the cylinders, the brake drums were steel-lined aluminum, vacuum-boosted, and finned for cooling, and the chassis was a tube frame. Mercedes-Benz also advertised optional rear axle ratios that would deliver up to 162 miles an hour at the top end. And it was beautiful.

“For some people, these cars work as art objects,” explains Finigan. “For us, they’re almost like industrial machine objects. We build our cars to be driven. We pull apart every last nut and bolt; the cars are almost remanufactured. Most of our customers want cars that work, that they can drive 120 miles an hour all day long. If our cars can’t do that, they’re failures. We don’t build cars, put them on stretchers, and haul them to shows.”

The Gullwing Service Company is the kind of place where real people rebuild honest cars for genuine car enthusiasts. Paul Russell’s customers believe in his work, pay him by the hour, even. There’s a two-year waiting list. And the Gullwing Service Company has the kind of customers who would say, “Sure, drive the car to Monterey for the races.” It had, in fact, two such customers: Nick Jones and Manfredo Lippman.

So, in honor of the Mercedes-Benz One Hundreth Anniversary celebration at Pebble Beach and Laguna Seca, Alex Finigan, accompanied by his good pal me, coworkers Jack Daly, Peter Bulkeley, and Bruce Marston, and our fearless f-stop Martyn Goddard, lined up the aluminum Gullwing and a red 1958 Roadster for a week’s worth of 500-mile days.

By the morning of our departure, our two-car caravan had grown to include: a white 1957 Roadster that we would drive as far as Chicago; attorney John Perenyi and his black pearl 1955 Gullwing; and the company van, which was hauling a covered trailer full of spare parts sandwiched around a 1960 Roadster that would be delivered to its owner in California. And Finigan had published our route in the 300SL newsletter as a challenge to any other sporting types to put their cars on the road to Monterey.

We had one rule that we promised to abide by: we wouldn’t drive the aluminum Gullwing over ninety miles an hour if its side glass was removed, to avoid the possibility of blowing out the Plexiglas rear window. There wasn’t too much else to worry about. Let’s face it—when you can start with bushel baskets full of parts and finish with a pristine $150,000 Gullwing, you’re not going to be racked with worry about the car breaking down.

pageElements.text: As with all road trips, this one started out tentatively, the drivers a little on edge as they tuned themselves into the rhythms of their cars and the road. We eased onto the Massachusetts Turnpike, raced to 100 mph, slowed to sixty, ran nose to tail, then side by side, until the only real matched set among us—Perenyi and his very own Gullwing—put his foot fown and left.

We found him an hour later in a service area with the missing link of a perfect cross-country motorcade—master bodyman Al Poskus and his sidekick/protégé Johnny Yanakakis. Big, grizzly Al and short, well-muscled Johnny. Thirty-six and twenty-one. Lithuanian and Greek. The bodymen, in their lustrous, cream-colored 1969 280SE coupe, were waiting to show us the way. This, of course, could never have been accomplished with a stock 280SE, so Big Al mated a high-performance 250SE head to the 280 block, added a 280SL cam, injectors, and injection pump, and traded a four-speed manual for the automatic to squeeze more revs from the motor.

“Everybody said it wouldn’t run,” Big Al told us, smiling. “I’m really happy with the way it runs. What are we sitting here for?” And, grinning a demonic grin, he nailed the gas. We finally had our rhythm—to drive fast enough to keep Al in sight.

We could never hope to catch the crazy sucker—the aluminum Gullwing had a 4.11 rear end, good for only about 120—although we had great fun trying. All four forward gears were jampacked with revs waiting to be tapped. The car was more animal than bird; little of the fury under its hood was muffled from the cockpit, and we fairly had to shout to be heard. At sixty miles an hour, the straight-six was turning 3,000 rpm; at eighty, 4,000; at 100, a lusty, bellowing 5,000 rpm. We were hooked on the noise at five grand, lungs thrumming in our chests from the engine’s power coursing through the car, but prudence reined us in at around 4,000.

Mercedes-Benz had the feel and placement of the pedals and the stout little stick shifter right thirty years ago. And the gauges were clustered tightly within the circle of the large steering wheel. That thin, hard, oversize wheel (a mere 2.0 turns lock to lock) had complete command over our course; it was a little vague through the center, but there was no slop in the system. The brute force required to handle the Gullwing’s wheel would scare off the faint of heart. Conversely, there is a raw, physical thrill that comes with expending a large amount of energy to drive a Gullwing with élan.

There aren’t many thirty-year-old cars you could push like this. The boys had done their job well. They, of course, knew all along what the car would do. I was the one who was completely delirious thinking of the thrill of the week ahead.

“Jack and Bruce and Bunchy [Peter Bulkeley] were the only guys in the shop who wanted to go on this trip,” admitted Finigan. “You work on them every day for ten years, you get blasé. It sometimes takes someone else’s enthusiasm to spark you.”

Of which there was plenty. Throughout the miles of road construction on Interstate 80 through New York and Pennsylvania, our rolling auto show made huge points with the construction crews. They always let us through on the tail end of the green flag, thumbs up. At our first fillup, 412 miles from Essex, the station manager exploded from his office. “Wow! I ain’t seen so much money in my life at once. Where’d ya get all them good-lookin’ automobiles? I’m gonna take yer picture, girl. Ya prob’ly won’t be back here, will ya?”
And a state trooper (Ohio, of course) followed us into a truck stop near Cleveland. He was a big one.

“Howdy, fellas,” he said, pulling on his Big Hat against the broiling sun. The asphalt was literally oozing tar around his feet. “I’ve got a buddy with a ’36 Ford pickup, and he’s going to get them gullwing doors.” After thirty minutes swapping hot rod stories, he promised to keep an eye on the cars while we stopped for lunch. In Ohio, I’m telling you. These cars were definitely magic.

The boys didn’t really get heated up until we got to Chicago and found a red Roadster with Ontario plates waiting in our hotel parking lot. By morning, two more Gullwings had materialized. So had our “support” vehicle, which was lagging so far behind that it might as well have been parked back in Essex.

A crowd gathered in the local Denny’s parking lot to gawk at the flock of metal birds, while we powwowed over pancakes. The late arrivals had decided not to stop that night with us, but to press on for Bonneville. Finigan and Jack Daly locked eyes.

“Bonneville!” they shouted in unison. “Oh, shit! SPEED WEEK!” It was the first time that the van and trailer, Jack Daly at the wheel, would beat us anywhere. The massive 280SE pulled the rumbling group back onto I-80. With Big Al leading the way, three-pointed star flattened against the 280’s hood, four Gullwings and two red Roadsters flailed the deserted highway, holding first at ninety-five, then 100 miles an hour.

America’s early morning vacation traffic might not know the exact identity of the megabuck machinery barreling past, but it knew that this was something special. Try passing a Good Sam Winnebago at ninety in a Countach and see what digit gets flung up in salute. But it was all thumbs for the 300SLs. While Dad snoozed, Mom honked, and the kids waved furiously.

We found a farmer looking at the cars when we came back from lunch, in Altoona, Iowa. “You boys watch out for cops over to Omaha,” he drawled. “They picked me up two months ago. They had an airplane!” he said in disgust. “My Whistler didn’t do me a bit of good. I shoulda had it through the roof.
“What year is that Mar-cedes?” he asked, squinting at the Gullwing. “I didn’t know they used them doors like Da Larryan.”

pageElements.text: Evening prayers before supper were the same every night:
“Didja see that Bronco on tank treads? Jee-zus!”
“Yeah! And didja see the ’65 Bug with chrome zoomies? Jee-zus!”
“How ‘bout the ’36 Ford three-window coupe? Jee-zus!”
The Lancia Zagato. Jee-zus.
The ’54 Chevy Bel Air two-door hardtop. Jee-zus.
The ’56 Nomad wagon. Jee-zus.
The ’58 Chevy 4x4 dump truck on eight tractor tires. Jee-zus.
“Yeah! Yeah!” hollered Finigan. “Holy shit!”

And the closer we got to Bonneville, the thicker grew the traffic of magnificent machinery. We found Jack Daly and Bruce Marston standing next to the truck by the entrance to the salt. They were in Bonneville T-shirts and Bonneville baseball caps, and they had installed a Bonneville sticker and a Bonneville license plate bracket on the van. Jack, looking for all the world like a member of ZZ Top, had chunks of salt dribbling from his long red beard. “I kissed the salt,” he said sheepishly.

Because none of us had been there before, we were stunned to discover that the paved road stopped five miles short of the action. “We can’t drive the cars on the salt!” we yelled at each other, as we teetered on the edge of the pavement, dying to get to that point in the distance where a blinding light was moving rapidly across the horizon. Eventually, we bought T-shirts and left, devastated.
“We should have hitched…” I began.
“Don’t even say it!” Finigan warned.

It was hot now, well over 100 degrees. We had the Gullwing’s side windows removed, but the sweat was soaking the towels covering the seats. “I feel like someone sprayed me with Pam,” whined Finigan, as I scribbled in my trusty notebook. “Are you writing that you’re sweating like a hog?” he asked.
“…sweating like a hog…,” I scribbled.

It could have been worse. Gullwings were notorious for being as hot as ovens, and the Gullwing Service Company had sprayed closed-cell foam behind the dashboard and in the channels behind the doors to better insulate the cockpit. They also louvered the rocker bottoms to suck hot air out the bottom of the rocker panels. So we got roasted instead of toasted.

We traded often between the Gullwing and the Roadster, just to experience a little breeze. For the passenger, though, the Roadster was even worse. Its exhaust ran down the right side of the car, and the floor would become hot enough to cook Thanksgiving dinner on. I would swing around in the seat and ride with head on dash and legs up over the trunk, which drove the truckers crazy, according to Big Al’s squawking CB.

At first, we thought the heat had caused the Gullwing’s only mechanical breakdown: a failure in the auxiliary fuel pump, which we ran to counteract vapor lock during hard driving. The problem proved to be electrical. The truck, of course, was about five hours behind us.
“Twenty grand worth of tools in the truck,” groaned Finigan, “and we don’t even have a dime to use for a screwdriver.”

Martyn Goddard peered around his Nikon, stopped shooting for a moment, and fished around in his camera bag, coming up whith his bazillion-blade, full-boat, dee-luxe version of the trusty Swiss Army knife. The boys jumped into action, jury-rigging a hot lead from the pump to a taillight.
“Martyn, do you suppose you’d have a soldering iron in that bag?” asked Jack Daly.
The Roadster experienced a number of niggling problems—a wacky speedo cable, a horn that began honking by itself in Nevada—but nothing that shut the car down.

Living with Gullwing and Roadster for a week sparked great debate over which one we’d buy when we won the lottery. The Roadster was certainly an easier car to live with. Its handling was less diabolical than the Gullwing’s, thanks to the redesigned low-pivot swing axle assembly and the addition of a horizontally located third coil spring. (This “compensating” coil allowed softer main springs for reduced camber change with no loss of load capacity.) And the Roadster’s 3.25:1 rear axle ratio made it a much easier car in which to carry on a conversation. Although muted, the engine still sang. Coming slowly down through the Sierra Nevada from South Lake Tahoe to Sacramento, Jack Daly played between second and third gears to hear the engine’s delicious shriek on the rock faces that lined Highway 50. “You could almost feel it smiling,” he said later on.
To Bunchy, though, the Gullwing lit the flame. “It makes me feel like I did when I first had my driver’s license and didn’t want to ever get out of the car.”

Crossing the California state line had been bittersweet. The adventure would be history in 300 miles. And, sadly, so would the camaraderie. “I feel like this will be the highlight of my life,” said Bunchy, forlornly. “And it’s almost over.”

We were greeted in Monterey by the not-even-slightly-anxious Messrs. Jones and Lippmann, and the rest of the Gullwing Service Company, who had come to watch the boss race Nick Jones’s Gullwing. (Was there no end to the generosity of Mr. Jones?) There was a moment of uncomfortable tension, as the guys from the shop who had flown to Laguna looked at our tan, laughing group, arms thrown casually around each other, eyes bright. The unasked question was clear on each face: Why didn’t I go?

I walked away from my pals at Laguna Seca. Paul Russell would drive our faithful Gullwing to eighth overall in the 300SL race. Bunchy, John Perenyi, Jack Daly, Big Al, and John Yanakakis would drive back. Finigan would fly.

And I would fly to England two days later, sit in a pub wrapped in sweaters drinking an ale with Le Mans winner Derek Bell, suntan shredding off my face, and hear the echo of Finigan leading the guys through the paddock at Laguna. They were praying again:
“Didja see that ’53 Siata 208? Jee-zus!”
“Yeah! And didja see the Type 35 Bugatti? Jee-zus!”
“How ‘bout the Birdcage Maserati? Jee-zus!”
The ’64 Alfa GTZ. Jee-zus.
The ’65 Cobra 427. Jee-zus.
The ’59 Stanguellini Formula Junior. Jee-zus.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

Vital Stats

Base price: $19,780 for 2013 Juke S FWD, the base model; $26,780 for base Juke SL AWD CVT (prices include destination)
This car: $28,405 (includes destination). This car’s price reflects three options: carpeted floor mats and cargo mat ($180), center armrest ($245), Midnight Edition package with seventeen-inch black alloy wheels, black mirror covers, black rear roof spoiler ($1,200)
EPA fuel economy: 25 mpg city/30 mpg highway (with 188-hp 1.6-liter turbocharged four-cylinder engine, linked to a continuously variable transmission)
Standard safety features: Six airbags, ABS, vehicle stability control, traction control
Chief competitors: Honda CR-V ($23,625 for LX; $31,125 for EX-L AWD with Navi), Kia Sportage ($19,850 for base model; $29,250 for Sportage X), Toyota RAV4 ($24,145 for LE; $27,855 for Limited); all prices include destination

Key Points

- The Juke is one of the smallest crossovers on the market and not the most utilitarian in the class
- The 2013 Juke is largely carryover, with the exception of the Midnight Edition package that is available on S, SV, and SL models (and is shown in the video)
- Bargain hunter alert: Prices have just been cut, as of May 3, upward of several hundred dollars, depending on trim level
- Review after review calls its radical styling “ugly.” I disagree
- The Juke is aimed at those who might also shop for a Mazda 3, Scion tC or Mini Cooper; Nissan says its design was inspired by motorcycles and rally cars
- It is affordable, especially up against the Honda CR-V and the Toyota RAV4
- But it requires premium gasoline!
- Rear seats will be out of the question for most adults, plus cargo space is minimal
If you need more space, the Mazda CX-5 might be a better choice, since it’s a lot more roomy and offers the same athletic handling
- Optional manual transmission cannot be bundled with optional all-wheel drive, which may annoy purists
- Rear-view monitor is newly added to the navigation package on SV models
- A revised Rockford Fosgate ecoPUNCH audio system is added to the SV navigation package and is standard on SL models
- Three new colors: Atomic Gold, Brilliant Silver, and Pearl White

contributors.bio:
Sheer serendipity.  That’s how I became a contributor to Jean Knows Cars.  Well into a lovely dinner party, I received a most unlikely suggestion:  “You should write about cars from your perspective – a 4’11” single mother with a ten-year-old minivan who drives around three overactive children and a Bernese Mountain Dog.  Theatre, swimming, hockey, lacrosse, figure skating, field hockey… You love to tell stories. Tell them about cars.”  I suggested that my background possibly lacked necessary expertise – B.A. from Duke in art history and medieval/Renaissance studies; Fellow of the American Academy in Rome; Ph.D. from the University of Michigan in medieval architecture --  nothing about cars there!  My friend persisted, “You may be an art historian, but you are also a hockey mother who can whistle like a trucker, a runner, and a lover of good food, wine and the written word.”

I pondered.  The auto industry and I did have a long, if tangential, history.  I did a stint as an executive secretary to the president of a car dealership and spent fifteen years negotiating a dual identity as an academic and as auto company spouse.  I have always suffered from car envy, particularly acutely when I lived in Europe.  (As envy and lust are amongst the seven deadly sins, I’m in trouble.) Automobiles, functional objects that often shape image, are fundamental elements of today’s society.  This would be another mode of cultural analysis and critique.  Couched in that light, it made perfect sense!

(And, I really can whistle like a trucker, but louder. I may be an art historian, but don’t sit next to me at a hockey rink.)
