pageElements.text: My story began in the winter (Part One), when I first started considering whether I could justify replacing my Honda Odyssey with a Fiat 500. It continued in Part Two, when I overcame envy of others driving Fiats and made my own shopping list. And the saga continues:

Part Three: Into the Showroom

It was hard enough to find the entrance to the Toyota showroom, given that the dealership was under construction. “Poorly marked” does not begin to describe the signage to the door. I was in that efficient maternal mode, prone to frustration, as I was trying to squeeze in three test drives while the children were at play rehearsal. Moreover, I was a touch resentful that I was spending the first sunny Saturday in weeks car shopping. Mother Nature seemed to be telling me: “You know you want the Fiat. Don’t waste your time with other vehicles.” My conscience, however, was driving me to due diligence. Thus conflicted, any impediment to my efficiency was not welcome, particularly with a car that was lower on my list.

Slightly frustrated, I wandered in through a side door, down a dark hallway with offices off the corridor occupied by middle-aged men, and into what was supposed to be a showroom, yet with nary a car in sight: lots of desks and paper and clutter, but no cars. Cubicles, some occupied by salesmen and customers and some empty, rimmed the center of the room. I stood there a few minutes, looking to see if there was someone with whom I could speak. No one seemed interested in acknowledging my presence. Finally, I noticed a gentleman behind a desk in what appeared to be the Scion display area.
“Excuse me,” I said as I made my way up the three steps toward him. “I am interested in looking at the Scion iQ and perhaps test driving one.”
He glanced up. “We close at three.”
Not “Hello, may I help you?” or “I’m sorry, we’re about to close.” Simply, “We close at 3:00.” It was 2:55 p.m. I was taken aback.
“Oh, well, do you have a brochure on the Scion iQ?” I asked.
“We don’t have any. You can get it on the web.”

A number of inelegant retorts sprang to mind instantly, but given that none was ladylike, I resisted and turned to leave. I walked slowly, taking the labyrinthine path out, just to see what would happen. Not a single salesman spoke to me. The Scion iQ was dropped from the list immediately.
“We close at 3:00.” I was incredulous—at both the time of closure and the complete lack of interest in a potential customer.

When Am I Supposed to Go Look at Cars?

A not-so-fun fact about the state of Michigan: a law that dates from 1953 prohibits the sale of automobiles on Sunday in areas with populations of 130,000 or more. Those populations can buy liquor starting at 7:00 a.m. on Sundays, but not cars. While the impetus for the law was founded in a particular Protestant work ethic and notion of the day of rest, the continuation of the tradition seems to stem from the dealerships’ resistance to change.

Michigan is not the only state with such a law. That said, in the twelve other states that ban vehicle sales on Sundays, the approach to sale hours is far more sensible. Some dealerships outside Michigan stay open until 9:00 p.m. on Saturday; some are only open until 6:00. In Ann Arbor and other Michigan cities, most dealerships close at 3:00 or 4:00 on Saturdays. There are other dealerships that even close at 5:00. As for hours on the weekdays, Monday and Thursday are often the only nights with hours that last until 9:00 p.m.

While I applaud the resistance to Sunday hours reluctantly, I might suggest that the pattern of dealership hours harks back to a different, idealistic era of the workforce and American life, when the men were at the office, the wives were at home cooking, dinner was on the table by 5:30, and the family could visit the dealership on the way to Dairy Queen. How quaint and 1950s-esque. Perhaps dealerships might take notice of the new reality. I’m lucky if I’m home by 6:30. Dinner on the table before 8:00 is a rarity, which does not exactly leave time on Mondays and Thursdays to pop out for a test drive. And Saturdays? Throw in one hockey game or another typical Saturday children’s event, and it doesn’t exactly leave a large window between 10:00 a.m. and 3:00 p.m. I’m not quite sure when parents are supposed to car shop in this town.

Perhaps My Gender Has Something to Do with This?

However, I wondered if gender were coming into play at the Toyota/Scion dealership. As I embarked on my test drives, I was curious about how the process would go as a woman shopping alone. All the other times I’ve looked at cars in my life, I’ve been with my now ex-husband, who was quite happy to take the lead in the “man’s world” of car shopping. Would the experience be different this time, and would my reception be gendered?

To be sure, certain moments, such as the Scion iQ experience, could have come straight out of a documentary. I am fully confident that had I been a man in a suit, as opposed to a small woman in black jeans and a fleece jacket, the experience would have been different. I felt the same at the Ford dealership earlier that afternoon. I wandered around for ten minutes without anyone speaking to me. I noticed, however, that when a couple or an older gentleman walked in, they were greeted immediately. I finally went to what seemed to be the front desk and asked, only slightly sardonically, if I had to sign in, as one does at the doctor’s office. There was a sudden scramble to find a sales associate. Could it be that, from a distance, I look about twenty years younger than I am? If that is the case, should it matter?

The time spent at the Toyota/Scion and Ford dealerships gave me the opportunity to analyze the spatial arrangement of the two dealerships in which I was virtually ignored. Neither dealership’s layout is conducive to customer interaction. The low ceilings and crammed central spaces ringed by messy offices result in a claustrophobic atmosphere that makes leisurely browsing unwelcome. In the case of the Ford dealership, it was easy to get lost among the cars, signs, and people jammed into the central area. Given my size, it is quite possible that it was easy to miss me.

As an architectural historian, I should note that spatial arrangement has a profound effect on customer perception and quality of service. At the Mazda and Honda/Volkswagen/Audi dealerships, the vehicles occupy the showroom floor, and the offices are set to the back of the building. One has space, literally and figuratively, to examine the models on display, and the salesmen have the space to observe and approach an unattended customer. The Chevrolet and Fiat dealerships—both owned by the Suburban Group—took consideration of space one step further. Spatial fluidity drives the showroom arrangement. The vehicle display blends with open and inviting desk spaces. “Inviting” seems to be the mode, as both dealerships had salespeople who greeted each customer who walked in the door. And that is how I met the striking, if not quirky, saleswoman at Suburban Fiat.

An Italian Aesthetic, Minus the San Pellegrino

No dealership exploits spatial expressions of brand image better than Suburban Fiat, where Italian architectural design meets Italian auto manufacturing. To be fair to the other dealerships in town, this space was purpose built and brand-new, having been open for only a short time. Moreover, the entire space is given over to one car and one car alone: the Fiat 500. Yet the spatial branding is so well done. Drawing from glass-box mid-twentieth-century modern design, the building has a façade of plate glass windows with ceilings twenty-five feet high. One enters a showroom in which a row of five or six Fiat 500s are neatly aligned. Sleek display cases house Fiat brand merchandise (everything from key chains to coffee mugs to polo shirts) on the back wall to the left, while the right-hand back wall contains an interactive display where one can select and watch videos of the 500 in action. The cabinets in the office area continue the modern aesthetic: mod and Fiat red with minimal hardware. The theme of sleek Italian design even carries to the restrooms, sparsely articulated with slick fixtures. Imagine an Italian auto dealership fit for Dwell magazine, and you have Suburban Fiat.

Space alone, however, does not create an Italian ethos. Activation and associations of a space depend on the personalities and the rituals within. In every way, Suburban Fiat embodies the Italian ethos. Just to the right of the door to the dealership is a low, modern built-in desk with chairs of taut black leather and chrome. A woman greeted me as I walked in. It dawned on me later that she was the only female salesperson I encountered at six dealerships. Tall and model thin, she sported  short, cropped hair and an elegant, flowing outfit accentuated with arresting jewelry. “Hi. Welcome to Fiat. Are you interested in the 500? Have a seat. Would you like an espresso or a water?” This is my kind of car shopping.

The Kirkland brand water that she handed me, straight from Costco, as opposed to the bottle of San Pellegrino I was expecting, was the one slightly jarring reminder that I wasn’t in Italy. I took a seat, and she asked what brought me in. I went through the narrative—recently divorced, daughter about to turn sixteen, tired of the gas mileage on my Odyssey, and wanting a small, fun vehicle. Just as I was finishing, a couple returned from a test drive. He was tall and dark, attired in jeans and a black Patagonia down vest; she was slight, athletic, and wearing jeans and a rust-orange Patagonia jacket—a fairly stereotypical Ann Arbor couple. “We really liked it.”

“Did you check out the turning radius?” the saleswoman asked. “No? Take it back out and do a couple of spins in a parking lot.” They dutifully headed back out. The saleswoman and I continued. What other cars were under consideration? I recited “the list.” She smiled and pulled out a handy-dandy chart that Fiat has prepared for people like me: line-by-line comparisons between the Fiat and every car I mentioned.
“Plus, the Fiat is more fun than any of them,” she added.

Comparison Testing

It turned out that she was right. I dutifully test drove five cars: a 500, a Ford Fiesta, a Mazda 5, a Chevrolet Spark, and a Volkswagen Beetle. It was, at times, a bit of a trick convincing salesmen that I really wanted to test drive a car with a stick shift. A woman interested in a manual transmission would appear to be a rarity. More than once, I had to counter the “We don’t have many on the lot; it will take time to find one” response with quiet insistence. Imagine my amusement when the Mazda salesman declared, “Wow, you really know what you’re doing!”

In the case of the Ford Fiesta, once I started driving, I immediately understood the salesman’s reticence to pull a stick shift around. Its five-speed transmission shifted like a child’s awkward toy when you pushed the lever up into the slot: clunk, clunk, clunk. The stick shift was too large for my hand and set too high in the car, the audio/radio display on the dashboard was incomprehensible, and the car shimmied at 70 mph on the highway. The Fiesta was off the list.

As for the Mazda 5, it had the tightest and most fluid transmission of all the cars I drove. The gearshift was the right size for my hand, but the vehicle is prosaic and devoid of personality. It struck me as the type of car a middle manager in the Dilbert comic strip would drive. Scratch.

The Chevrolet Spark lacked, well, spark, despite the arresting design personality. Its price point, however, was considerably lower than the 500's. Were one able to fit more than two small Target bags in the trunk (in spite of the fact that the Spark boasts more cargo space on paper), it may well have been a contender, but it failed the hockey bag test. The Spark: off the list.

Indeed, the only rival for the Fiat was the Volkswagen Beetle. The new Bug has been “masculinized,” and many of the features that played on the Barbie-car association, such as the flower vase, have been removed. The new interior has crisp lines that reflect Bauhaus design and the sensibility of form, function, and German aesthetic. The lines are so architectural that I compared the space to driving a modern penthouse. Needless to say, the salesman was slightly puzzled by my analogy. The manual transmission shifted efficiently, and the drive had a lovely fluidity about it. What’s not to love, aside from the price, which would have topped the $20,000 limit? The seats. The seats were designed for a large man in a small car. The base was so long that my knees just made it over the edge; the side bolsters projected so that every time I shifted, the back of my arm hit them. I had a tender spot on that arm for two days after the test drive, bringing new meaning to the term slug bug. I asked if the car came with a pillow to place behind the backs of short women. At that, even the salesman concluded that the Fiat would be a better fit for me. We agreed, and so the Beetle, too, had to go off the list.

image.altText: fiat lust part three test drives

pageElements.text:
Back to Suburban Fiat

So it was that I found myself back at the Fiat dealership for a second visit, this time with my three children in tow. I needed to make sure they could all fit, and we had numbers to discuss. We rushed in on a Saturday afternoon, squeezing in a visit between play practice and a hockey game and mindful of Ann Arbor’s crazy car hours. My saleswoman was just finishing up with another typical Ann Arbor couple, two handsome males sporting black jeans and matching black North Face fleece jackets. Outdoor chic seems to be the attire for Fiat drivers. She greeted me like an old friend.
“You brought your children! Look at how blond and beautiful they are. Your son looks just like you! Hi, I’m....” And the introductions began. Just like in Italy.
I, however, was concerned about efficiency. Was there time for a test drive?
She smiled. “Certainly! We close at 5:00.”

title: Fiat Goes Electric with the 500e
subTitle: Sorry, it's for California only

promoTeaser: The all-electric Fiat comes for a visit, and we are charmed.
metaTitle: Fiat Goes Electric with the 500e - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Fiat Goes Electric with the 500e, a California-only electric version of the popular, stylish Fiat 500. It came to Michigan for a visit, and we were charmed. Read the story on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: Some of us at Jean Knows Cars have it bad for the Fiat 500. It’s cute, it’s affordable, it’s foreign; what’s not to like?

Not much, and starting this summer, when the larger and more practical 500L and the fully electric 500e go on sale, even less. Those models are still a few months away from their on-sale dates, but being the sister website to Automobile Magazine (and sharing a parking lot) has its benefits. This week, one of those benefits is that there’s a 500e hooked up to the charging station.

When Fiat’s team dropped off the 500e last week, they told us about the car’s impressive 108 MPGe on the highway and its 87 miles of combined city/highway driving range, but what they really wanted to talk about was what made the 500e different from its EV brethren.

Not Your Standard Electric Car

For starters, you can search all you want, but you won’t find an “eco” button on the dash. There also aren’t animated leaves or growing forests to tell you whether you’re driving efficiently. Fiat designed this car to feel and drive as much like a gasoline-powered car as possible—except that it has the instant torque that makes electric motors so much fun. That philosophy may not resonate with some ultra-environmentally-conscious electric-car buyers, but I can’t help liking a car that bucks its paradigm so willfully.

Some Heavy Numbers

Of course, some concessions must be made to electrical power. The 500e is 617 pounds heavier than the base Fiat 500, and some rear legroom has been sacrificed to accommodate the battery. The 500e's electronically limited top speed of 85 mph won’t exactly set any records, either.

The car will come with a standard navigation system, which will help drivers find their way to the nearest charging station, and a free mobile app that will allow drivers to monitor their car’s state of charge, search for the nearest charge point, and plan trips. Fiat is also giving drivers twelve days' worth of free car rentals for each of their first three years of ownership, in case they need a car that will make a longer trip or need to move a couch across town.

The 500e will start at $32,500 (including destination) when it goes on sale in California this summer. Buyers in other markets will have to look on with jealousy until Fiat decides to expand availability for its electric car.

image.caption: The 300SL that Steve Cannon and I will be driving this week.

pageElements.text:
Jean's Most Excellent Adventure! Part 1

I have had some mighty fine times in my privileged life as an automotive journalist-adventurer. The most exotic, the most memorable, have involved long distances in priceless vintage cars, often in faraway places: Driving the weeklong Pan Pacific Rally across New Zealand's North Island in a 1916 Benz open touring car from the factory museum. Driving 2,000 miles with Sir Stirling Moss in a 1965 MGB from London to Cortina D'Ampezzo in Italy via the Nurburgring, the Hockenheimring, and every famous mountain pass in between.

I returned to Italy today to "race" in the famed Mille Miglia as a guest of Mercedes Benz, co-driving with the boss of U.S. operations, Steve Cannon. That sentence doesn't quite convey the enormity of my good fortune. It really should have exclamation points. We'll be driving a 1955 300SL Gullwing!!! It's the same year as the car in which Sir Stirling and navigating journalist Denis Jenkinson made history, setting a blistering pace that has never been repeated. They covered the 998-mile course in ten hours, seven minutes, and forty-eight seconds, averaging 98.5 mph. The weather was perfect, the car was perfect, and the two spent only two and a half minutes during the entire race refueling.
I am not new to the original Gullwing, having driven (you may have just read about it here) across country from Massachusetts to Monterey back in the 1980s.

The party is about to get started, but it's been revving for weeks. Roger Penske sent a quick e-mail saying that he, too, would be in a 1955 300SL and close to us in the pack of 375 cars. (We are car #303.) His co-driver will be Mario Illien, of Ilmor race engineering fame. Don Rose, of the prestigious RM Auctions, will be here, as will be the always sartorially splendid Donald Osborne, a collector and concours judge who also sang opera. At the Met.

As you might imagine, the locals like cheering for Italian cars and drivers, but there is a lot to be said for being part of the team sponsoring fifteen cars as well as the entire event. Mercedes has an army on the ground, spiffy as hell in team jeans and polos decorated with the distinctive blue/red/yellow plaid of the old 300SL upholstery. My teammates include the editor of Auto Zeitung, the lifestyle editor of Vanity Fair Italy, and old compatriot Car and Driver editor Eddie Alterman. We are all decked out in matching team polos, hats, sweaters, and jackets.

It's interesting to note that the Mercedes team is packed with racing drivers, from champion sports-car drivers Marcel Tiemann (five-time winner of the 24 hours of Nurburgring) and Bernd Maylander (DTM and FIA GT World Championships), to old Formula 1 drivers Jochen Mass, David Coulthard, and Karl Wendlinger.

The Jag team takes it much less seriously, packing their roster with a different kind of celebrity: fashionista Yasmin Le Bon, global supermodel David Gandy, German actress Hannah Herzsprung, Salvatore Ferragamo, Jr., and Daniel Day-Lewis, who will co-drive with the head of 20th Century Fox.
You can peruse the entire, massive provisional list of participants here.

I am here, the sun is shining, and I'm about to head to the Fiera di Brescia, where the cars are gathering for technical checks. On the official event schedule is "Holy Mass at Duomo Vecchio in Piazza Paolo VI" at 5 p.m., and "blessing of a selected number of cars representing the Mille Miglia" tomorrow at 11:30 a.m. Can't help thinking that this looks like another good reason to be attached to an Italian team.
Stay tuned to Automobilemag.com and JeanKnowsCars.com for my sporadic reports in photos of the fabulous week ahead!

Buon Giorno!!
Jean

pageElements.text: Speed bumps are like broccoli: they’re a good thing, a healthy thing, and yet they suck. You know why there are speed bumps in parking lots and in residential areas. They exist to make cars slow down when going through a neighborhood like the one shown here. But what’s the best way to manage them? Should both wheels go over together, or should you maneuver your car to go over the bump at an angle?
You know you can’t just cruise over them at 30 mph, not if you want to protect your car and keep from breaking your teeth. Here’s our handy guide to the best way to handle those humps.
Slowing down allows your vehicle to have full suspension travel, and that will avoid damage and that terrible jarring feeling.

1. Slow down. The whole point of a speed bump is to get you to moderate your speed, usually through a neighborhood or in a parking lot. Treat speed bumps the same way you treat railroad tracks and big potholes. They all require full suspension travel to go through with the minimum amount of jostle and damage to your car. Slowing down allows your vehicle to have full suspension travel, and that will avoid damage and that terrible jarring feeling.

2. Approach the speed bump at an angle. Maneuver one wheel to the side first, and come at the bump at an angle. Then, as you come over the bump, turn slightly in the other direction to go over the bump diagonally. This will minimize the damage and disruption to the underside of your vehicle.

3. Slam on the brakes. No, seriously. If you find yourself coming up on a speed bump unexpectedly, don’t keep going at full speed. That will make the underside of your car go “blammo” onto the speed bump. Not pleasant. So when you brake, really brake hard—enough so that you have almost stopped before you reach the speed bump. Then…

4. Foot off the brake and let your vehicle gently traverse the speed bump. Right before you get to the speed bump, take your foot off the brake, let your shocks recover, and smoothly go over the bump. Your vehicle will again have full suspension travel, which is just what you need for a smooth crossing.

pageElements.text: We greeted the news of an all-new 2014 Mercedes-Benz Sprinter with more than casual interest. We don’t like to use the word “empowerment” too much around here, but when a vehicle is this capable and still has a veneer of German-automaker chic on it, we’ve got to admit it’s likeable.

Perhaps you aren’t in the habit of carrying eleven people, or big stacks of full sheets of plywood, or all the equipment and supplies of a small business. You’ve still got to admire the can-do spirit couched in Mercedes luxury that is a Sprinter van. I mean, really, doesn’t it make you want to start some kind of dog grooming service or florist shop, just so you have an excuse to own one of these?

And, as it happens, a million people around the world have found a reason to buy a Sprinter. True, most of them aren’t in the United States, but just wait. As Claus Tritt, general manager of commercial vehicles, freely admitted, speaking of the Sprinter’s run in North America, “We were the oddball for more than ten years; now we’re the benchmark.” Now that rival vans are coming onto the market such as Nissan’s NV and the upcoming full-size Ford Transit and Ram ProMaster, the European-style tall-roof van will become a little more common on U.S. streets.

Changes for 2014

With the new model’s debut—it goes on sale in early September—Mercedes-Benz has added a four-cylinder BlueTec diesel engine, mated to a seven-speed automatic transmission, that should be popular around town as a money saver. With it, fuel economy is expected to be up eighteen percent. You can still get a V-6 BlueTec diesel, but now it’s optional. On the inside, there's an audio system with a 5.8-inch screen, an optional navigation system that lives in the glove compartment, and a new seat design.

It’s not only the three-pointed star that will remind you that you are driving a Mercedes; you can get the famed Mercedes-Benz safety systems on the 2014 Sprinter: collision prevention, lane keeping, blind spot, and high-beam assistance systems, and the segment-exclusive load adaptive control, which detects if your load is shifting. And, starting at just over $40,000 for the passenger van (2013 model prices; the 2014 prices won't be announced until closer to launch), it’s a pretty affordable vehicle for what you get.

Now if you want to go north of $40,000 and way north of utility, there are eighty-five companies licensed as Preferred Upfitters for the Mercedes-Benz Sprinter. As an example of the kinds of customization you can get, Mercedes showed us a passenger van transformed by Midwest Automotive Designs Corp., which made a fully Kardashian-worthy limousine out of the Sprinter that would cost around $150,000 (Sprinter included). If you choose to have a Sprinter upfitted, Mercedes-Benz will handle all the arrangements through a specialized Sprinter dealer. “The dealer will make it happen for you,” Mercedes promises. Three-quarters of Sprinter purchasers take advantage of that opportunity, whether to get specialized work equipment, wheelchair lifts,  or to turn the Sprinter into an ambulance or a luxury camper.

Not ready to buy a Sprinter of your own? Play with this design program for fun. Or enjoy looking at the Sprinter's ancestor (right) the truly adorable 1955 Mercedes-Benz L319, which makes a delightful contrast to the sleek 2014 model. It made an invigorating 40 horsepower but got the job done. There are wood slats across the cargo area in the back, perfect for sliding in your wood crates of Gewurtztraminer wine. That's some work heritage to be proud of.

pageElements.text:
If you haven't already, you can get up to speed by reading Part One. Okay, ready?

Thursday Afternoon

This is the day when we just sit and wait. The start is tonight at 8:30. Right now, it's pouring rain, and I'm sitting next to Gina Lollobrigida. But I digress. Here's what has happened so far.

The Welcome Dinner

Last night, Mercedes-Benz threw a giant welcome dinner for its team: fifteen cars, including ours, supported by about forty people. Mercedes has rented out the Museo Mille Miglia, and the museum store has actual Ferrari engine heads for sale. It has an original Mille Miglia scarf from around 1950 that you can get for about 1,500 euros. There’s another one from the 1960 Mille Miglia that's silk, priced over 2,000 euros. Original posters for sale! Reproductions, too. I just love it.

For dinner, all the drivers sat at a long table, and all the support staff filled the museum around the drivers’ table. David Coulthard is proving to be very funny, very nice, and very friendly. Jochen Mass is a total joker. He's a riot. Karl Wendlinger is very serious. We haven’t seen him smile once in two days.

By the time they were getting ready to serve the meat course, we were full and finished in every way. Team USA, with our faces inches from the plate, decided it was better to leave. We repaired to our rooms, and I hit the hay and woke up at 7:30 a.m. without having moved once. The other American members of the team reported doing the same.

We Consider Ourselves Warned

This morning, we gathered at the Fiera di Brescia, a giant open exposition center where all the cars were and where the tech inspection took place. Steve Cannon and I took out our #303 Mercedes 300SL and drove around in the parking lot. We needed to get used to the very bad feeling of drum brakes, which I remember from 1970. I'd forgotten just how bad the brakes were.
We kept telling ourselves over and over again: As you’re driving with these brakes, you’ll get used to them. They'll feel really good. You have to remember to pump.

Next we had a personal seminar from one of the mechanics. He told us, “Every Gullwing is different. There's a row of switches and buttons that are not labeled at all. They’re fuel, and interior lights, and fuel pump, and heater. There’s also a hidden one that will release air from underneath the dash and blow cold air. This is very important because this Gullwing has an exhaust system running underneath the floorboard, so on a really hot day your tennis shoes will get very tacky, because the floorboard gets so hot.”
Not on a day like today, when it's cold and rainy. We feel like winners as we watch other people in open cars driving in the pouring rain, looking just miserable.

Jochen Mass Lends His Perspective

We did notice, however, that the windshield wipers were at about eye level on their upward motion. They didn't seem to get much higher than halfway up the windshield. So I corralled Jochen Mass and asked him, “How many of these have you been on?” He flashed his fingers through the air. Five, ten, so many times I couldn’t count, and he laughed. I asked him, “What’s the most important thing to worry about: the windshield wipers or the brakes?” He said, “Both. The windshield wipers are here [putting his hand horizontally across the bridge of his nose], so you have to brake differently.”

I'm pretty sure that what he meant is, neither one of them is exactly perfect. I can’t tell you how many times one of the mechanics has already come up and said things like, “The brakes will be very bad. The tires will be like driving in snow. Please be very careful.”
I’ve already decided that if I crash this million-dollar car, I'm planning to die in the wreck. I won't want to come home and face the music.

Auspicious Beginning for the Navigator

An hour later, we were suddenly called to our cars by the team and told to go to the Piazza della Loggia in Brescia. We jumped into our cars and lined up to go. Steve was driving. I opened my route book, and it's at that point I realized we had no directions. None.

We followed the cars in front of us. Within minutes we lost the car in front of us. That's when I pulled out the beautiful Mercedes-Benz map and realized it was no use to us, because they put the symbol for where we needed to be across the map in such a way that it completely obscured the names of the streets. We were somewhere in the city of Brescia, but where? Great start for this navigator who was so highly touted by everyone from Stirling Moss to herself.
Steve noticed a sign for Centro, so we decided, that's it. Go for the center and look for the castle. I said to Steve, “We track like guided missiles. Actually more like scuds.”

We wandered around. Another Gullwing was following us, which we thought was hilarious. We found a cop who couldn't speak English but gave us the idea that we had to turn right three lights up and look for a street. Then we saw another cop. She took one look at our car, then pointed everyone else to the left and us to the right. Suddenly, we found ourselves in a line of cars going where we needed to go.

We Felt as Important as Any Movie Star or Formula 1 Driver

The streets were mobbed, despite pouring rain and gusting wind so strong that there was a stack of inside-out, broken umbrellas at every corner trash can. Some guy off to my right was yelling, “Attenzione! Attenzione!” I turned around, and it was an old guy, who said, “Buona Giornata!” He was just trying to get our attention so he could wish us a good day.

Once you're going slowly, the car gets a little hot and steamy with the rain coming down and the exhaust heating up. We opened the gull wings and were driving slowly with the doors open. Some kid put his head into the car. We couldn’t quite understand what he was saying, and then we realized he was asking: "David Coulthard? Karl Wendlinger?” And he took our picture.

Then We Met True Italian Royalty

They put a sort of zip tie around the steering wheel shaft of the car. We entered the incredibly ornate opera house in Brescia, the Teatro Grande, which has a ceiling that resembles the Sistine Chapel. The SLR Club, the whole team, and all the drivers were there. But everyone bowed down to Gina Lollobrigida, who is eighty-five and has not a line on her face.
We had our team photo taken inside the opera house. I just saw Aida in Detroit last Sunday, so I was especially excited to see an original poster for Madama Butterfly, which opened here in 1904.

Ready to Start

Any minute now, we’re going to get in our cars and head back to the museum. The start is at 8:30 tonight.

We’re not nervous at all. Steve is the nicest guy in the world: really calm, really excited, comfortable driving in the rain. Also, the only person I’ve met who drinks as much coffee as I do. He keeps talking about bucket lists; I think he’s already overflowed his.
The story continues tomorrow!

I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: It is a truth universally acknowledged that a family with two or more children must be in want of a minivan. It's what Jane Austen would have said if she had been writing about the modern mom instead of unwed young ladies in the early nineteenth century. We’ve got plenty of love for the minivan here at Jean Knows Cars. In fact, two of our number drive minivans and swear by them. But if a van just isn’t your jam, don’t despair. There are plenty of options out there for the stubbornly stylish.

To prove that point, JKC senior editor Molly Jean and I went on an Automobile Magazine jaunt to Holland, Michigan, where we test-drove three-row crossovers and took in the sights at the local tulip festival. We whittled the original crop of crossovers down to four favorites: the Chevrolet Traverse, the Ford Explorer, the Hyundai Santa Fe, and the Mazda CX-9. See what we liked best about each of them below.

Chevrolet Traverse

Base price: $39,440
As tested: $42,880

The Chevrolet Traverse was the first car I drove on our trip west from Ann Arbor, and it set a fairly high bar for the crossovers that followed. The Traverse isn’t particularly eye-catching, but neither is its appearance offensive. It just looks like an average, well-designed large crossover.

In fact, its nondescript makeup may be the Traverse’s greatest strength. It does just about everything fairly well. The engine has plenty of power, the steering is reasonably accurate, the infotainment system is intuitive, and the seats are comfortable. There’s not much to complain about, really. Traverse owners might not fall asleep thinking about how much they love their car, but they won’t stay up nights trying to figure out how to afford a new one, either.

Real-life thirteen-year-old Sam Brown, our expert on back seats, didn’t go so far as to actually call the third row comfortable, but he did stop short of saying it was uncomfortable, an honor he granted to only one other crossover.

Ford Explorer

Base price: $40,995
As tested: $45,415

The Ford Explorer is by far the top seller on this list. It outsold the Chevrolet Traverse by nearly 80,000 units in 2012. Sure, part of this is probably due to name recognition and brand loyalty, but the Explorer is also genuinely good at being a people and stuff mover. With one of the roomiest trunks in the group, the Explorer easily outdoes some of the other crossovers as a vacation car. (The Santa Fe’s trunk didn’t even have room for a cooler when all three rows were in use.)

All that trunk space comes at the price of some third-row legroom, which, combined with the small third-row windows, made Sam comment that the third row felt “slightly claustrophobic.” But it’s all about perspective, and after sitting in all four third rows, he ranked the Explorer’s as one of the most comfortable alongside the Traverse’s third row. The back seat also redeemed itself with its copious storage and beverage space, as well as an accessory plug that made up for the lack of a rear entertainment center. (It’s a $1,995 option in the Explorer Limited trim level.)

Hyundai Santa Fe

Base price: $35,705
As tested: $38,840

The Santa Fe was the least expensive of the vehicles we tested, but its classy, attractive interior and the massive panoramic sunroof made it feel like one of the most expensive. That’s no mean feat on Hyundai’s part, considering the Santa Fe’s as-tested price was almost seven grand cheaper than the most expensive crossover in the bunch.

The Santa Fe also felt less hulking on the road than some of its competition, which will make it less of a chore to drive around when the kids aren’t in the back seat. But the Santa Fe’s trunk didn’t even have room for a cooler when all three rows were in use. Sam wasn’t a huge fan of the third row—his knees were in his chest and he denounced it as uncomfortable—but he appreciated the third-row climate controls. The second-row captain’s chairs, on the other hand, passed comfort tests with flying colors. For families that absolutely need seating for seven, the Santa Fe can be had with a second-row bench seat.

Mazda CX-9

Base price: $37,170
As tested: $39,605

With Mazda’s reputation for building great cars, it should come as no surprise that they’ve managed to build a seven-passenger, three-row boat of a car that feels nimble and capable on the road. The CX-9’s interior styling was unique among the cars we drove in its refusal to employ fake wood trim and poorly textured plastics. I was impressed but not overwhelmed by the CX-9’s exterior styling until I saw it lined up with our other favorites. Even in that relatively attractive group, it stood out as the clear style champ and the one I would most like to be seen driving.

As might be expected, carlike handling and a carlike exterior come with a slightly cramped interior. Sam declared that the CX-9’s third row was the worst of the bunch, with barely room for his feet behind the second row. But kids don’t pay the bills, and the CX-9’s agile ride and attractive face might be enough to overrule the protestations of back-seat passengers.

There’s plenty to recommend each of these cars, and plenty that can help you forget that they’re big enough to carry more people than live in the average American household. Perhaps the best news of all is that even though they’re all in the same price range and have the same basic specs, they don’t all feel the same. Yes, there’s a seven-passenger crossover for every palate. And if none of these quite does it for you, you could always check out one of those minivans people keep talking about.

pageElements.text: Rearview cameras are a boon to drivers, pedestrians, and parked cars everywhere. Chances are, if you’re buying a new car, it will come with a rearview camera or offer one as an option. But what if you’re still driving a car you bought before rearview cameras were even thought of? Don’t worry; you’re not destined to run into a pole every time you back out of a spot in a parking garage. For less than the cost of a new rear bumper, you can bring your car into the twenty-first century with your very own aftermarket rearview camera. One caveat: since some aftermarket backup cameras require drilling small holes in the car’s body to mount the camera, you might want to have a dealer or technician take care of the dirty work. Look carefully at the setup explanation before you buy.
Here are three options for drivers looking to add an extra pair of eyes to their ride.

Brandmotion 8501

Manufacturer Brandmotion released its latest aftermarket rear-vision system this week. It’s a camera that attaches under the trunk lip and is wired to an existing in-dash display, giving you the same experience as if you’d opted for a rearview camera in the first place. Brandmotion says its camera, a one-quarter-inch Panasonic color model, is designed to provide a high-quality picture for a price competitive with less accurate systems. The Brandmotion 8501 costs $175.95.

Pyle PLCM8200

You can have the magic of a backup camera even if your car didn’t come with an in-dash display. Many aftermarket rearview cameras also come with a monitor that can be mounted somewhere on the dash to show the driver what’s going on behind her. One such model is the Pyle PLCM8200, which hooks a rear-mounted camera to an 8.1-inch color monitor. The monitor comes with universal clips that can mount it to existing mirrors for easy viewing. Pyle's camera and monitor system will cost shoppers $211.99.

Peak Wireless Backup Camera

Another solution for cars without existing display monitors is to replace the normal, boring rearview mirror with one that doubles as a rear-vision camera display. This type of system acts as a normal rearview mirror unless the backup camera is engaged, at which point a section of the mirror will be given over to a picture provided by the camera mounted to the license plate. The Peak backup camera system will cost between $85 and $130.

pageElements.text: Maybe the first thing you think of when you think about the Kia Soul is hamsters. That would make sense, because that famous series of  hamster commercials helped make the Soul a hit as an "urban passenger vehicle." The all-new 2014 Soul made its debut at the New York Auto Show, and design chief Tom Kearns walked me around it and showed what's new about it.
<iframe width="420" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/uZqPH3HCwYo" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

As he says in the video, design cues from the 2012 Track'ster concept (shown at right) were important in the new design, such as the floating body-color liftgate insert on the back end, which Kearns calls a "backpack" look. The 2014 Soul is just about as boxy as ever on the outside, wrapped around an all-new chassis that Kia says is 29 percent stiffer for better ride and handling.

It's on the inside that the changes are most evident, with soft-touch materials and an overall feeling of quality improvement. You can even get leather seating and an eight-inch touchscreen. If you move up to the top-level Soul Exclaim, options will include a piano black center console, a leather-wrapped steering wheel, and a cooled glove box (!). Hamsters in evening clothes?
The 2014 Soul is expected out in early fall.

contributors.bio:
When Automobile launched in 1986, my byline appeared on a sidebar to the cover story written by our founding editor David E. Davis, Jr. Yet it wasn’t inevitable that I’d write for the magazine, even though my childhood was heavily automobile-flavored: my father raced jalopies and late-model stock cars on the oval tracks around Omaha, Nebraska, where we lived, and my favorite uncle liked drag racing and hot rods.

After earning a B.A. in English from the University of Nebraska, I moved to Los Angeles to become a screenwriter. Instead, though, I ended up holding cue cards on TV shows, including the soap opera Days of Our Lives. My first magazine story, the inside scoop on how we prepared those cue cards, appeared with my own photos in Soap Opera Digest.

In my freelance career, I’ve written for Bon Appétit, the Wall Street Journal, and many others. I started corresponding for the Automobiles desk at the New York Times in 2010, which is proving to be a great relationship. As a change of pace, my historical column for DBusiness (“Detroit’s Premier Business Journal”) has run since 2006. But while a food-and-wine tour can get boring after a couple of days, nothing beats a call from Automobile. I’ve been behind the wheel of everything from a Ferrari 458 Italia (“Blood Red to Goodwood,” March 2011) to the Fiat 500 Abarth. On assignment for “Three Zero Heroes,” I co-drove the winning BMW X3 in the 2004 Alcan Winter Rally. Teaming again with the same navigator, we won the 2006 Carolina Trophy, bulldogging a 1951 Chrysler Saratoga to the finish for “Substance over Style.”

Other assignments have placed me not only in the driver’s seat of a Porsche 911 Targa for the 2002 Targa Newfoundland, a plummy nod that seemed to indicate my editors’ favor, but also in the co-driver’s seat of a Class 1 buggy for the 2003 Baja 1000, suggesting they wanted me dead.

As you might guess, there’s no regret about failing as a screenwriter. And now I’m beginning something new: teaching automotive journalism at Art Center College of Design, in Pasadena. My workshop, Creating Content for Automotive Media, launched in 2012 and will be offered twice a year. I look forward to helping students along on their way to incomparable automotive adventures and working with the best editors in the business.

pageElements.text: For Corry Weller, driving a truck in the Lucas Oil Off Road Racing Series means soaring over jumps, slamming to the ground, and sliding sideways through 180-degree turns. Because off-road trucks don’t have windshields, she gets splattered with mud. The truck is a twitchy beast and will roll over easily if she doesn’t use the greatest care and precision.

In her second season as the only woman behind the wheel of a Pro 4 Unlimited entry, which is the top class in the Lucas Oil series, Weller has distinguished herself. The forty-one-year-old Chandler, Arizona, resident was 2012 Rookie of the Year, with a best finish of second place. Her goal is to win a race this season, and next year, she wants to contend for the series championship.

I met Weller last Friday at Lake Elsinore Motorsports Park in southern California before the fifth and sixth rounds of the series. From a starting field of eleven trucks, she finished fourth in both Saturday’s and Sunday’s races, averaging 79 mph per lap on the rutted, twisting 1.1-mile course.

After her first practice session, she was relaxing in her Optima Batteries/Tilted Kilt team hospitality area. She explained how she started in motocross twelve years ago. “I was in a bad marriage and needed to get away and do something to de-stress, just for one-half of a day,” she said. Supercross races on TV fascinated her, and she found herself visiting a powersports dealer. She purchased a four-wheeler, or quad, for the track.

Role Model for the Kids

For technical support, she had her father. “My dad was a car guy,” she said. “I grew up in the garage with him.” She had also taken automotive courses in high school and college and knew how to handle tools. Having now discovered her passion, she was on her way to five years of motocross success. Her six-year-old daughter and four-year-old son saw their mommy getting all fired up and winning races.
“I never really knew what I wanted to do,” she said. “I just went where life took me until I started racing. As soon as I started racing, I was like, ‘That’s what I have to do.’ ”

After motocrossing on the quad, the intermediate step was short-course racing on a Yamaha Rhino, a larger all-terrain vehicle with a 700-cc two-cylinder engine and four-wheel drive. Meanwhile, she married her second husband, Jason Weller. To have a job with a flexible schedule, she went to work at a Tilted Kilt pub. Her manager backed her with measured support, and then the chain’s leaders decided to sponsor her move up to the Pro 4 Unlimited division. Optima Batteries joined the effort this year.

image.altText: corry weller off road truck racer

pageElements.text:
Intensity behind the Wheel

Weller’s impressive performances come from her ability to tune out the pandemonium and finesse this heavy, roaring, V-8-powered, four-wheel-drive truck. A highly technical and disciplined driving style is required.

“I don’t really think about what I’m going to do on the face of jumps any more because I’m so used to what my truck does,” she said. “That’s all just reflex and now I can focus 100 percent on the race, what’s going on, because my subconscious is doing all the little stuff.”

Each of the weekend’s Lake Elsinore races covered sixteen laps, which meant an intense physical ordeal lasting just over twenty minutes. Weller prepares with a daily CrossFit workout supplemented by additional weightlifting. “I also eat pretty clean and drink tons of water,” she said. “Fitness plays a huge part in your reaction times on the track and helps with these brutal races and throwing the truck around.”

Strange Bedfellow

While every racer finds his or her own rewards, for Weller the ultimate satisfaction comes from taking on a new challenge, like moving up to Pro 4 and steadily improving. While she admitted that she once slept with a first-place trophy, she said winning is more for the people who tirelessly support her. “Otherwise, me, myself, I’m just happy racing, honestly.”

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: What the heck happened to Team 303 in Italy? you ask. The last you might remember was that my teammate, Mercedes-Benz USA CEO Steve Cannon, and I were waiting at the Teatro Grande in the center of Brescia, staring at Gina Lollobrigida, trying desperately to find a working cell tower and waiting for the evening start of the Mille Miglia. (Read Part One and Part Two of this tale, if you haven't already; then come back.)

Obviously, something went very wrong. If you follow JeanKnowsCars on Twitter, you already know from a handful of sporadic posts that we were able to send in rare moments of cellular service that our lovely old 1955 Mercedes-Benz 300SL Gullwing had terminal engine failure a mere 50.4 miles from the start. Here’s the long version of our sad story.

Thursday evening: It's time to leave the Opera House and join the stream of Ferraris old and new blasting through the dense crowd of spectators. No worries about finding our way. The route out of downtown is mobbed on both sides of the street, despite the rain, the wind, and the fact that it’s the middle of the day and the middle of the week. Young men are sauntering brazenly into the path of the cars with hats cocked sideways, while grandmas are sweeping their hands encouraging more speed. Little kids are waving flags. Traffic lights do not exist. We are heroes. At every intersection, police are waving us through. Every agente di polizia with a scooter is on it and assigned (or self-assigned, for all we know) to the race. Stirling Moss is right: Brescia is in a frenzy.

And we are only going to the museum. Another couple of hours, another groaning buffet. "Are we supposed to be carbo loading for this?" Cannon asks. He is serious. This is a guy who won the Phys Ed award at West Point, which is saying something. I am the exact opposite. "Yes," I say, equally serious.

Our wall of gray-jacketed Mercedes-Benz mechanics is waiting by our car with crates of snacks, water, and a bag of supplies that includes flashlights on headbands, hand wipes, eyeglass wipes, and on and on.

They should strike, if not fear, than intense jealousy into the hearts of the competition. Mercedes is not only the main event sponsor, but the fifteen-car factory team includes board members Thomas Weber and Joachim Schmidt and head of PR Jörg Howe, among other luminaries including former Formula 1 drivers Jochen Mass, Karl Wendlinger, and David Coulthard, who watches the courtyard full of cars firing up from an open window in a tower above the crowd. “I’m going to do a Le Mans start,” he shouts down to me. Which means he is going to run down the stairs, leap into the car, and take off. Such a joker, this one.

We feel like we're in a protective cocoon of fabulousness and invincibility. That, of course, would be wrong. We are dashed to earth immediately on leaving the museum for the starting ramp. We're directed out the back driveway, and we pop out into traffic with no idea where we are and without sight of a single other of the 400-plus competitors. I have no idea which way we're even pointed.
"Not again," I say.
"I think I remember that building," says Cannon. We both start laughing. "We have an hour to go two miles," I remind him.

Just as we notice the crowd walking on the sidewalk suddenly thicken, we come around a turn and join the throng of vintage cars and trucks, driven by entrants from twenty-eight countries, clogging the street in front of us. We have joined the 2013 Mille Miglia. Within no time, we are waved off amid the cheers of the crowd, the roar of our engine, and the sounds of our names over the loudspeaker.
I tell Steve I'm absolutely overwhelmed and close to tears. "Not just you," he says to me.

It is really overwhelming. And it’s hard not to go as fast as possible, even though this is merely a re-creation of a very real and brutal race, which ran from 1927 to 1957. The end came when popular Formula 1 driver Alfonso de Portago crashed near the finish in Brescia, killing himself, his co-driver, and nine spectators.
The crowd wants fast, even from Team 303, which means that 302 cars in front of us already gave them fast, and they are still there, as excited for us as they were for car number 1.

From Start to Finish

I’m an overachiever navigator. That means I go through the book with a highlighter, and I mark every potential place we could miss a turn. There were so many roundabouts one on top of another and opportunities to get lost that I had highlighted half the book. I was feeling really good that I had marked the whole first leg, from Brescia to Ferrara, a total of 158.5 miles. I would worry about leg two, Ferrara to Rome, once we got in.

This was going to be the easy night, and as it turned out, we really didn’t need to worry so much about the turns, because even into the night, the route was lined with spectators pointing the way. There was a policeman at every turn pointing to the turn. There was a Mille Miglia arrow signboard pointing the correct way.

About fifty miles into the event, night had fallen and we had entered the ancient walled city of Verona. The last time I was in Verona, I saw Franco Zeffirelli's Carmen in the Roman amphitheater. At intermission, I drank champagne with Zeffirelli, he of the dyed yellow hair and orange skin, neither color found in nature. It was an emotional experience, and as we passed the amphitheater and I was telling Steve the story, I got choked up again.

In the end, tears would have been the correct emotional response to our time in Verona. We got into a traffic jam almost immediately, right by the amphitheater. All the race cars were around us. Cars were overheating right and left. Some were making U-turns and going down side streets. Others had their drivers pushing them.

We crept along and crept along. At one point, we were side by side with Roger Penske and Mario Illien, and we shouted to one another like it was old home week and joked about Mario’s array of high-tech timers stuck across the dash on the passenger’s side that he was using to negotiate the strictly timed portions of the rally.
They were clearly in it to win it. We were more in it to not spin it.

One of the organizers came through the gigantic traffic jam of stopped racing cars, handing out new directions for leaving Verona because the route was partly flooded. This did not bode well for the rest of the event, since weather forecasts called for continuous heavy rain and high winds. In the end, we didn’t have to worry about that, because just as we came within view of the timing control point where our time card was to be stamped, steam began to pour from the engine. As one, we looked at the water temperature gauge. "It’s on 0, it’s not working," said Steve. He tapped on it. I tapped on it and looked closer and I said, "Oh it’s working, it’s pegged."

Our engine had overheated and was pouring steam out, and Steve immediately got on the phone to the mechanics. They told him, "Turn it off, wait until the temperature gets down to 80 degrees, fill it with water, and you’ll be fine."
We sat within view of the timing stand as the other cars inched past us, one after another.
After thirty minutes, the temperature was still at 100 degrees. As the last of the stragglers were passing the control point, our temperature was still at 90, and we decided to go for it.
Once we cleared off the steam and heat, we filled the whole thing with water, fired up the engine, and watched white smoke billow from the tailpipe.

Steve revved it a few times, and more and more white smoke came out. Everyone standing around looked at it and said aloud what we knew in our hearts was true: there was water in the engine, which was not a good sign.

We went through the control, got our time card stamped, and went down the road just outside the city wall. Then we pulled over under a streetlight and parked, hoping it wasn’t true, but knowing that our race was over.

The mechanics were an hour away, but we were kept company by people who had come to watch the rally and now had one car that they could just sit and stare at. So they did. We were never alone, always with bystanders. As some drifted away, others came.

One person stood and watched the entire time, making occasional comments in French. In the U.S., we don't have that kind of time. We'd be all, "Dude, looks bad, need help? No? Okay, gotta run."  Not our Frenchman. He stood by while we waited for our guys to either rescue us and get us running or tell us the race was over.

The End

No one wants to be out, least of all the mechanics, who have worked hard on the cars, brought them to Italy, and had individual sessions with each driver to explain the idiosyncrasies unique to each of our sixty-year-old sports cars. I have never met a racing mechanic who didn't think that, if given a chance, he could outrace his driver.

It must have been brutal for our rescue team—Klaus, Sven, and Nate Lander from the Mercedes-Benz Classic Center in the U.S.—to see us out of the race and not wonder what they would or could have done differently to prevent our car from overheating. What if we'd pushed it along the traffic-clogged streets of Verona instead of firing it up?

But no. Klaus apologized. "It is our fault. We gave you a car that had a problem." He was sincere in suggesting that the problem was very likely lurking below the surface and had just worked its way to the fore. This is the beauty of being on Team Mercedes-Benz. Great guys, great cars, great organization.

The decision was made to flatbed the Gullwing about an hour south to Ferrara, where a fresh crew of mechanics could possibly change the head gasket, if parts were available. During the wait, they added water and ran the car up and down the street, causing both black smoke on acceleration and white smoke on deceleration, indicating there was water in the engine.
It felt like waiting for the College of Cardinals to vote for the new pope. They pulled spark plugs, which were surprisingly dry, and they pulled the dipstick to look for water.

The flatbed arrived, along with a phone call letting us know we had no spare parts. By then, we'd arranged the mechanics' luggage and parts in their GL support vehicle to hold our stuff, too. A head gasket wouldn't have fit in that stuffed GL.

title: Kid-Friendly Vacation Trip Planning
subTitle: Five ways to get them involved
promoTeaserSmall: Yes, you can take a road trip that's fun for the kids without plugging them in to video screens.
promoTeaser: Yes, you can take a road trip that's fun for the kids without plugging them in to video screens.
metaTitle: Kid-Friendly Vacation Trip Planning - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaKeywords: how to take children on a vacation
metaDescription: Kid-Friendly Vacation Trip Planning will help your family have a more united and memorable time in the car. Here are five ways to get your children involved in preparing to go out on the road. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Going on a road trip with children rarely turns out the way you fantasize. So it's pretty similar to the rest of your life with children. Go ahead and plan, organize, and expect all you want; things will have to adjust. It's all a matter of having the right attitude toward the inevitable twists and turns. For that reason, a driving trip can be the best way to take kids on an adventure, because you are literally at the wheel and can stop the car or change the itinerary in ways you can't on an airplane, a train, or a cruise ship.

As a veteran of many adventure drives with kids of all ages (see my Road Trips with Teens story), I have come up with this handy list of five ways you can involve your children in planning for a road trip.

1. Let Them Fantasize

Do you remember having huge travel dreams as a kid, which your parents responded to by cutting them down to size? I remember my sister and I wanting to take a bicycle trip across the United States as preteens, with no more plans than the dream of pedaling endless sunny, traffic-free, flat asphalt lanes all day and sleeping in wildflower meadows at night. My parents wouldn't let us get to Square One. I think they actually laughed. You may say, "Of course they did! That was a ridiculously clueless idea."

If my kids expressed that bicycle fantasy to me, I would help them plot out a family car trip that included a night or two of rustic camping and a one-day family biking event in some town a state or two away. That might be enough to satisfy their bike-trip dreams forever. But it could also start them on the path toward a lifetime membership in a bicycle touring society. How about finding out what your kids' dream of a road trip looks like? Then take that and make the adjustments you have to, while helping them fulfill just enough of it to keep the flame alive. Sometimes just taking children seriously is enough to make you a great parent.

2. Give Them Map Power

Yes, you've got a fancy navigation system these days, plus Siri, plus Google Maps. Get an atlas or a paper map anyway that kids can write on with a highlighter, crumple up, and learn to fold. Any elementary school teacher will tell you that a tactile experience helps kids learn. Take off for a short day trip carrying a state, county, or city map. Picture how great it will look with your kid's carefully drawn route from home to the amusement park or the lake, and your kid using it to see how close to "Are we there yet?" you are. You can back it up with Google Maps, or put your kid on the computer and let him or her Google Map it for you. Then, let your kids take turns as navigator, sitting in the front passenger's seat if they're over twelve and tall enough, and using their maps to direct you. Okay, it's good to teach them how to use the car's navigation system, too. The point is to put your kids at the center of the navigation experience.

3. Turn Them into Trip Trackers

Some families like to keep a travel diary. If you want to try that, put your kids in charge of writing things down like departure times, starting and ending mileage, and impressions of different places you stop. Give them a box to collect receipts, postcards, and brochures. Help them notice things like gasoline prices, figure out how many exits are left until you get to the next hotel, and suggest possible stopping points along the way. Keep kids actively involved in the process of getting where you are going. Don't turn them into passive occupants of the back seat with no personal stake in how the day goes.

4. Make Them Governor of a State (or Mayor of a City)

Don't be obnoxious about it and assign kids to write reports, but do put them in charge of finding out about the places you're going. If you are crossing multiple states, put each child in charge of a state and make him or her the point person for information. What famous people come from there? (Not just presidents, but rock stars and TV actors they actually care about.) What geographical features shouldn't you miss when you're driving through? The whole time you are in that state, that kid is the go-to family member. Encourage them to notice if there's a town with an amusing or interesting name, or a sign for the Millard Fillmore Museum or the World's Largest Artichoke. Then pull off the highway and go look at the town for fifteen minutes. Help your kids figure out what a "not to be missed" experience consists of. The Disney Worlds and Grand Canyons are essential, of course, but don't be in such a hurry that you miss out on the small happenings that will turn into family jokes and shared history. There are things to learn everywhere, even if it's just the visual stimulus that comes from people watching.

5. Give Kids Control of What the Family Hears and Watches...Up to a Point

If you've read this far, you must agree with me that a road trip with kids is not a necessary evil to get through, but an adventure to be embraced. If so, you'll want to avoid the temptation to plug your kids in to an endless cycle of videos, video games, and iPod music with headphones. I'm not saying you won't ever want to resort to that; technology allows each of us to have "alone time" while sitting right next to each other. That's exactly why you want to limit it. Why put everybody in the car as a family and then ignore each other? Instead, bite the bullet and let your kids have control of what the group listens to for some of the time, and listen to it together. Some of my favorite drives are when my teenage son Henry acts as DJ and plays me everything from vintage Bob Dylan to weird Japanese electronic music. I get some sense of what's going on inside his head.

Take everybody to the library for audiobooks (or get a free OverDrive account and borrow audiobooks from the library to download onto your iPhone, iPad, or iPod). Listen to short stories or podcasts that somehow relate to the place you're visiting. Get one of the kids to make a playlist of music that suits the trip. Even toddlers can learn to prefer stories read aloud in the car. That's so much better than a constant stream of cartoon videos that block out the scenery they should be looking at on a trip. Having said that, you don't have to be shackled to tween pop music stations the whole time, and you do get to put on NPR or whatever you'd rather be listening to. Sharing your favorite things, and then being patient while others share theirs, is a lesson the whole family can keep on learning.

metaTitle: Nicko McBrain and Me - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Nicko McBrain and Me: An interview with the drummer of Iron Maiden, who has a lifelong love of Jaguars (and a brand-new customized XJR-S). See our conversation on video on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: I first met Iron Maiden's drummer, Nicko McBrain, in 2003, when I wrote about him for the December 2003 issue of Automobile Magazine. We did a special section on Rockers Who Love to Roll, and I called Jaguar, since they're always tied up with celebrities. They told me about this crazy guy who loved Jags and bought all his own cars. They also told me that he had recently been arrested after he bumped a security guard with a Jaguar XJR while running late to an outdoor concert.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/gwmql32K8aw" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Iron Maiden was going to be playing at Madison Square Garden, so I concocted the idea that I would chauffeur McBrain around before the concert for his own safety (or the safety of the public), also in an XJR. I had no idea what kind of guy I was about to meet. Here's this outrageous headbanging group that has a crazy monster named Eddie as its mascot. I saw myself as more of a refined Pink Floyd-style headbanger.
I went to his hotel and arranged to meet him for breakfast. He set the time at 1:00 p.m. We were off to a roaring start.

When he appeared, he definitely looked like a rocker, or like Mickey Rourke in The Wrestler, with long, streaming platinum blond hair. He was wearing a Hawaiian shirt, and I realized it was an Iron Maiden Hawaiian shirt with Eddie embedded into it, and he had a tough-guy Northern British working-class accent. But he was also extremely well groomed, wearing elegant linen slacks, and he was a real salt-of-the-earth guy, game for anything. We hit it off immediately.

We took the XJR to the car wash, where I got a photo of him scrubbing the car. We drove around Harlem and in midtown Manhattan, where our crazy British photographer asked us to drive around the corner again and again in rush-hour traffic. When we got back to his hotel, there was a long line of people waiting for autographs. I ended up driving him all the way into Madison Square Garden, up the circular ramp to the stage, way above the main floor.

Since then, I had not seen Nicko McBrain until the Los Angeles Auto Show. I had no idea he was going to be there. I went to a Jaguar party, and I noticed someone I thought was a girl in a white suit from the back. Then he turned around, and before I even recognized him, he shouted, "Jeannie [pronounced more like "Jaynay"]! I was hoping you'd be here!"
Some people, no matter how famous or not famous they are, once you meet them, you're friends forever.

I really like the fact that he has bought all his own cars, and mostly secondhand. He's like a kid in a candy store, with a lifelong love of Jags that's real. He's humble and genuinely tickled that anyone at Jaguar would have any interest in his opinion at all. It was great to have the chance to talk to him again for this interview, in which he talks about his new customized Jaguar XKR-S, which, among other modifications, has Iron Maiden mascot Eddie's face in place of the Jag growler.

subTitle: Does this make EVs look better to you?

metaTitle: Tesla Motors Repays Uncle Sam Early - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Tesla Motors repays Uncle Sam early, paying back its Department o fEnergy loan nine years ahead of schedule. Read our commentary on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: Elon Musk, co-founder and CEO of electric-car startup Tesla Motors, is a man who loves big announcements. He teases big Tesla news from his Twitter account regularly and occasionally has to bump major announcements for other, more major announcements. But we’ll give him a break this time, because yesterday’s Tesla news was genuinely big. The carmaker announced late on Wednesday that it has wired nearly half a billion dollars to the United States government, repaying the remainder of its $465 million Department of Energy loan nine years early.

The $451.8 million payment was funded by the company’s decision to sell additional shares of its stock after glowing reviews of the Model S (right) sent stock prices through the roof. Musk, the billionaire founder of space technology company SpaceX and co-founder of PayPal, purchased $100 million of the stock himself. This isn’t the first time he has shown his willingness to support Tesla personally. In April, Musk announced that he would back the Model S’s residual value guarantee with his personal checkbook, a move we can’t quite imagine from any other CEO.

In the announcement, Tesla claimed that it was the first American carmaker to repay its government loans in full. This prompted an indignant blog post from Chrysler, reminding us all that Chrysler’s loans were repaid in full in 2011, also ahead of schedule.
