metaDescription: I Tested Delphi's Car Tracker, car tracking, geofence, Mercedes-Benz Mbrace, Vehicle Diagnostics by Delphi, Verizon vehicle diagnostics, car diagnostics app, vehicle diagnostics

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: When they write the book on the twenty-first century, they’ll look back on the 2010s as the decade when connectivity was king. Cell phones grew ubiquitous, Facebook turned every sneeze into a news event, and constant access to an Internet connection became a practical necessity. It was only a matter of time before cars got in on the connectivity game, and now that time has finally come.

Verizon Wireless and electronics supplier Delphi have teamed up on a vehicle diagnostics and car-tracking system that allows drivers to track their car’s location, receive speed and vehicle health alerts, and decipher check engine lights; its other calling is to keep tabs on teen drivers. Parents can set speed alerts and geofences to make sure their kids aren’t driving too fast or taking the family car on impromptu road trips. If the kids do take the car, parents can check its location at any time to see if their child really went to a friend’s house or went to hit up the strip clubs with a fake ID instead.

My Real-World Test

I tested the vehicle diagnostics system for a week to see what it could tell me about my car and whether it might work to rein in a rebellious teenager.

To give the vehicle diagnostics setup access to information about my car, I plugged the vehicle diagnostics module (a small plastic transmitter) into my car’s OBD-II port, located below and to the left of my steering column. (OBD-II location can vary by car, but it’s commonly found below the steering wheel.) Then I put the device’s serial number into the app I’d downloaded from Google Play—it’s also available from the App Store—and it was off to the races.

This app’s geofencing and live tracking functions are already available in some cars—Mercedes-Benz’s mbrace system has them—but the beauty of the Delphi app is that it allows the tracking of a car that otherwise wouldn’t be technologically advanced enough to broadcast its location to a computer miles away. The boundaries I set up to alert me when my car left home or work were almost always accurate. The system missed my re-entry to the “home” geofence a couple of times but never alerted me that my car had gone somewhere it hadn’t.

My most frequent interaction with the app was the daily barrage of alerts that accompanied my morning commutes. Engine alert! 4,000 rpm! Speed alert! 75 mph! I already know that my driving style is slightly more aggressive than is typically recommended, but for parents looking to learn more about their teens' driving habits, those alerts could be a helpful step toward a conversation about the importance of a more restrained approach to driving.

A Way to Put Your Kid on "Watch"

Parents who are worried that their kids are lying about where they go when they’ve got the freedom of four wheels can check the “recent trips” tab to see where the car’s been and what time it was there. The GPS system is accurate enough that it could usually pinpoint not just my location but the parking spot I was in, although the tracker did fumble occasionally. It read a trip I made from my apartment to downtown Ann Arbor as a trip from my apartment back to my apartment. This is by no means a serious error, but it’s worth remembering that technology isn’t always accurate.

Delphi’s system might be most valuable to the nervous parents of new drivers, but it has enough uses that it’s worth a look for other drivers, too. The app’s functions vary depending on the car, but in most cases they include diagnostics, speed and engine alerts, and vehicle location and tracking services. Some cars also support remote start, locking and unlocking, trunk release, and alarm activation.

The whole system was a little sensitive for my taste (I received several “motion” alerts, which turned out to have been triggered by my shutting the door when getting into the car), but Delphi says future versions of the app will allow drivers to manage the sensitivity of these settings.

How Much?

Delphi and Verizon charge $249.99 for this vehicular peace of mind. Drivers need a Verizon data plan to use the connected car system (Verizon's data plans run from $30 to $70 a month), and a $5 monthly fee will be added to the data plan once the system is activated. Buyers also get two years of free access to a Delphi connected car account. After two years, the Delphi account will cost an additional $5 per month.

pageElements.text:
My Summer of Love

I first ventured out of Michigan by myself in the summer of 1972 when the Rainbow People's Party called for a gathering of the tribe in Colorado. I found out about it when I longed to see my boyfriend, Ben, who'd hitchhiked from Ann Arbor with his friend PK to find J. Stevens, a mysterious Latvian friend of ours who went by the name on the shirt he'd bought secondhand at St. Vincent de Paul. J. Stevens had disappeared into the mountains somewhere above Aspen and was building an illegal shack on federal land. Ben and PK had the name of a guy who lived there who might know where J. Stevens was. So off they went, by way of Idaho and San Francisco, bar to bar to bar, in search of the elusive Latvian.

After one late-night, reversed charge phone call from the boys, I decided on a whim to go looking for all of them. I was eighteen years old. It took one ride to get from Ann Arbor to Colorado, where every campground was bulging at the seams with half naked, totally stoned, and barefoot flower children and their psychedelic school buses. Being from a tiny farm town of 5,000 people at the base of Michigan's thumb, I was overwhelmed by this rich tapestry of life. Actually, I was overwhelmed that I'd actually hitchhiked halfway across the country without being murdered and was in Aspen. Now what?

Going on the same single clue that the boys had, I found J. Stevens working away on a pile of ancient scrap lumber salvaged from an abandoned cabin in a small clearing, a mile straight up Little Annie on the backside of town. I set up my tent and sleeping bag and was immediately immersed in the routine of sorting scrap wood, hiking a half-mile across the mountain to fill and carry back water jugs from the stream, and hiking down the mountain to do laundry. I would hitchhike from the bottom of the hill to town, do the clothes, spend the night in a local campground with the Rainbow People, then hitch to the base of the mountain for the return hike up. On one such foray into town, I got out of a truck on the side of the highway at the exact moment Ben and PK were emerging from a truck that was dropping them off on the other side of the road!

I'd been there a month already, so I hung out with them for another week and then decided to head for home. It took two rides. The first was from Aspen to Boulder in a Jeep with two guys in front, a German Shepherd in the back, and a box of eight-track tapes. I squeezed in with the dog. They dropped me at the top of an entrance ramp to Interstate 80 looking down over a rail yard.

I was there for a couple of hours, in such a state of despair that I was seriously considering jumping a train. At one point, a police car raced past me to pick up a guy hitching farther down the ramp. Before I had to make a decision to run, two hippies in an old red-and-white station wagon backed all the way up the ramp and saved me. A guy and his sick girlfriend were on their way to Chicago. She was laid out in the back, so I rode up front with him and helped with the driving.

We drove through the night, hitting the outskirts of Chi-town at 2:00 a.m. I was nervously awaiting the moment when they would kick me to the curb with not a dime in my pocket, 200 miles from home. But we kept driving east on I-94. "We decided back in Nebraska that we couldn't let you out in the middle of the night," my Good Samaritan said.

They took me to my door, where we together discovered that my roommates, confused by my one-month absence, had moved everything from my room, put it in the basement, and rented my room out even though I had paid the rent through the month.

We all slept for a few hours on the floor, they went back to Chicago, and I moved across the street.

Have a great summer!
Love, Jean

Laura Sky Brown's First-Time-on-the-Road Nostalgia

I was born just a tiny bit late to the Sixties party, meaning that at the age when any self-respecting hippie would have been hitchhiking to Woodstock or at least to San Francisco, I was a young preteen still linked firmly to family and home. The protest marches, Summer of Love, and Chicago Seven trials were things I watched on TV after middle school homework was done. I did my best to make up for lost time by going across country in the summer of 1976, when I was eighteen. I headed out from Michigan to Washington State. The plan was to meet up with a friend in the Earth-shoe enclave of Washougal, Washington, then drive together back to Massachusetts.

In the way that teenagers used to do—maybe they still do, but I’m glad mine haven’t (yet)—I dug up some stranger from the University of Michigan North Campus Co-ops and headed out West in his car with him. All I remember about him, besides his dented Datsun hatchback, was that he had scraggly, curly black hair and he smiled a lot while settling in each night to sleep under the stars in a sleeping bag several feet away from mine. We stopped in small towns like Blue Earth, Minnesota, and we waved at cows whenever we passed them—a joke then, but now a habit that’s almost a superstition, which I have not broken to this day and have now passed along to my children.

He dropped me off in Jackson Hole, Wyoming, at the foot of the Grand Tetons, where I felt so grown up reserving my first solo hotel room. From there, I took a Greyhound bus through Idaho and into Washington.

The trip back was a whole other story, but I do want to mention that it was the Bicentennial that year, and right after I arrived, my friend and I went to see the much ballyhooed Largest Fireworks in the U.S.A., which for some reason were in Vancouver, Washington. I wore a bizarre variant of red Converse All-Stars sneakers that extended all the way up to my knees, in honor of the occasion. After it was over, the traffic jam on the way home kept us out on the road, unmoving, until well into July 5. My friend had a brand-new car of which she was so proud (and later was unable to unload at any price): a Chevrolet Vega wagon. We were shortly to head off on a manic trip that took us to San Francisco, where somebody told us about this new thing called disco; across the South, where I had my nineteenth birthday dinner at a Chinese restaurant in Tennessee; and all the way to her parents’ home in western Massachusetts, where her mother promptly got into a screaming fight with my friend and tossed me out. Back to the Greyhound bus for home.

Does anything equal that first trip that you plan (or fail to plan) all by yourself without parental input? Sure, most trips you’ll take later in life will turn out a lot better, but your first try stepping out into the world alone is intoxicating. If I close my eyes, I can still remember the scent of that summer. I may prefer the Hampton Inn to the sleeping bag on the ground these days, but it’s satisfying to remember that there was once a time…

Molly Jean's Family Values Camping

I am a second-generation camper, and I went on my first camping trip when I was six months old. We had a truck camper, and my dad built a crib into one end of the area above the cab of the truck. We crisscrossed Michigan in that old, 1950s-era aqua Ford pickup. Obviously, I don’t really remember it, but the stories have been told so many times that I feel like I remember being put to bed in my footy pajamas high up in the air.

At some point we moved from the truck camper to station wagons, and by the mid-'60s, we bought a Chevrolet Suburban and named her Green Glory. It was the very best vacation vehicle ever made. So much room that you could bring every last teddy bear you owned.

Now that I have my own family, we have kept the tradition alive and spend at least one week a summer enjoying the rustic beauty of our state. We are the campers who bring everything. When we pull out of the driveway and I look back at our house, I always think, if anything happens to my house I have all of my favorite things with me. That includes my parents, who are closing in on eighty but are still right out there with us on almost every single vacation we take.

Christina Lawson's Relative Adventures

I’ve only taken three summer vacations: two to Florida when I was seven and nine and one trip to Arizona right before I started seventh grade. I’d have to say that despite the illnesses afflicting my mother and me for the week-long vacation, my family’s Arizona trip was my favorite.

But what made the trip truly enjoyable wasn’t the scheduled trip to the Grand Canyon or the ruins of a Spanish mission we saw on our first day or the drive my mom and I took to Gilbert, Arizona, to visit an old friend. It was the little things that made my mom and I laugh, like when she and my aunt, the daughters of a germ-fearing mother, explained to my uncle why hot tubs were always a bad idea, or when my mom and I pretended that we weren’t with my uncle while he caused a commotion while attempting to secure my then-infant cousin’s carrier into a plane seat. His movements as he yanked at the seatbelts caused the plane to sway in place; the loud crying of his son, who didn’t like to travel (and, thirteen years later, still doesn’t), only made things worse. And then there was the situation with my uncle’s three insulated canteens, each filled to the brim with water, and his ever-present tripod and video camera. My mom and I helped him carry them until my aunt realized that her husband had turned her older sister and niece into uncomplaining human pack animals and promptly took the gear from us. My mom and I giggled as we listened to her employing very colorful words as she told my uncle that he should have left the canteens and the tripod at home. Now, many years after that trip, the words "tripod" and "hot tub" still send my mom and me into fits of snorts and giggles.

Now that I’m done with school, one of my dream trips is to actually go to Mackinac Island instead of spending years talking about it; the other is to go to England. I almost had the chance to fly to England this July as a chaperone on a six-week-long trip, but I turned it down. The best I’ll be able to do is to plan to go to Mackinac before another ten or fifteen years passes by. But without my uncle along, it won’t be nearly as hilarious as it could be.

Annie White's Rooster Epiphany

I’ve done my fair share of distance driving, but not much in the way of true road trips. During my stint on the East Coast, my travels carved a triangle with Boston, Ann Arbor, and Washington, D.C. at its corners, but those frequent drives were undertaken alone and at breakneck speed, with only the destination in mind and no thought for the journey. My favorite real road trip was the one that took me from Portland, Oregon, to the redwoods in California, to Yosemite National Park, to San Francisco, back to the redwoods, and finally back to Portland. You can read about it here, but here’s a DVD extras tidbit: it was on this trip that I learned how truly horrible it is to wake up to a rooster crowing. Don’t believe the back-to-nature crowd. Humans made a huge leap forward when we invented alarm clocks with off buttons.

The road trip of my dreams would take months to do right and would go from coast to coast and north to south, hitting every possible major city and national park. This summer I’m setting my sights a little lower and hoping to fit in a camping trip to Lake Michigan (the poor man’s Atlantic Ocean) in between my frequent jaunts to Big Long Lake in Indiana (a very poor man’s Lake Michigan).

Scott Allen's Bad Influence

My fondest memory of road trips as a kid was driving to Florida every year with my parents and my brother. It was two long days of driving to get there. We always listened to Graceland by Paul Simon, and I hated it because I didn't understand it. It's funny that it's now one of my favorite records of all time.

When I was about thirteen, we brought my friend Andrew to Florida with us in our new Honda Odyssey van. This was before there were rear-seat TVs. We plugged a little boxy twelve-inch TV/VHS player into the cigarette lighter and I brought Taxi Driver without my parents knowing. We watched it in silent mode because we were too afraid they would hear what we were watching. We didn't understand until later what was going on in the movie.

My favorite part of the trip always came when we were about four hours from the Florida line. The freeway on either side felt like you were engulfed in trees. Usually it would be super foggy at night.

On that year’s trip, Andrew and I would sneak out in the golf cart that my grandfather owned and go driving around the golf course super fast and kind of out of control. We got it stuck in a sand pit, and we were freaking out because we thought we were going to get in so much trouble, so we ran back to the house and were honest and said what we did. My grandpa was pretty pissed, and I thought my dad was, too, but just recently, he told me he thought it was funny. Andrew is in Thailand now, teaching kindergarten kids.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

2013 Mercedes-Benz SL63 AMG Roadster

Vital Stats

Base price: $146,705 (includes destination)
This car’s price: $177,280 (includes destination)
EPA fuel economy: 16 mpg city/25 mpg highway (with 5.5-liter biturbo V8 engine that makes 557 horsepower and 664 pound-feet of torque, plus seven-speed AMG automatic transmission with shift paddles)
Safety features: Electronic stability control, active blind spot and active lane keeping assist, Pre-Safe braking, carbon-ceramic brakes (a $12,625 option!), brake assist and adaptive brake technology, Attention Assist, rear-view camera, active parking assist with Parktronic,adaptive high-beam assist, LED daytime running lights
Tech features: Active ventilated multicontour seats, AMG performance steering wheel with Dinamica side grips, Comand system with navigation, Harman/Kardon Logic7 surround-sound audio system, mbrace2 telematics system with MB apps
Chief competitors: Aston Martin V8 Vantage, Jaguar XKR-S

Key Points

• Luxury abounds: sun-reflecting leather upholstery, heated Magic Vision Control, a retractable panoramic roof, and the famous Airscarf neck comfort system
• So does power: the AMG performance package ($9,000) includes a power increase from the “base” 530 hp to 557 hp, but you’ll want to add the optional AMG carbon-ceramic brake system ($12,625) with that
• Top speed with the AMG performance package is 186 mph
• This gorgeous roadster also has an Eco start/stop system, because you are thinking about fuel economy, of course
• Could there be any car that makes you feel more entitled and special?

title: 11 Plant Tours You'll Actually Like
subTitle: These are not just for kids
promoTeaserSmall: See where your car was made. View Harleys or Airstreams in progress. Part of your complete vacation!

metaTitle: 11 Plant Tours You'll Actually Like - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: 11 Plant Tours You'll Actually Like is our list of vehicle manufacturers across the heart of the United States that invite you to take a tour of their production sites this summer. Read about them on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Trying to think of fun yet stimulating things to do this summer? Suppose you took the kids on an educational tour where they could see cars being built, and maybe even the same kind that you own. Drive your Camry to the Camry plant, or your Ford truck to the Ford truck plant. With the high level of robotics in today’s auto plant, things probably look very different than what you might have seen on tours of your childhood, and that's not necessarily a bad thing. Why not get out there with your kids (or without kids at all), and take advantage of the opportunity to see vehicles that are Made in America? Many automakers are offering free tours; try out one of these en route to your vacation destination, or as part of a staycation plan this summer.

1. Ford Rouge Factory Tour in Dearborn, Michigan

Ford has gone to great lengths to provide a classic plant tour experience at the historic Rouge River plant, where the F-150 pickup is made. The walking tour has interactive activities and takes about forty-five minutes. You can also take an eighty-foot elevator ride up to the Observation Deck, where there’s a panoramic view of the complex. Other educational activities include a 360-degree movie experience featuring a virtual tour of blast furnaces, paint shops, and other colorful parts of production, all set to an original Detroit Symphony Orchestra score. Tours cost $11 for kids, $15 for adults, and take place Monday through Saturday, with the last tour bus leaving at 3 p.m. The tour can be combined with an excursion to the Henry Ford Museum and Greenfield Village nearby.

2. Harley-Davidson Vehicle Operations in York, Pennsylvania

The Harley-Davidson plant here builds the Touring, Softail, CVO, and Trike models and makes parts such as fuel tanks and fenders. There’s a Kids Corner exhibit at the tour center for children under the age of twelve. A free factory tour lasts about an hour and is available Monday through Friday between 9 a.m. and 2 p.m. For $35, you can opt for the more tourist-friendly Steel Toe Tour, which takes you to such areas as the paint and polish zones, plus gives you a commemorative pin, a group photo, a safety vest, and a $5 coupon toward a gift shop purchase. This tour lasts two hours and is offered at 9:30 a.m. and noon, Monday through Thursday.

3. Mack Truck Macungie Assembly Operations in Macungie, Pennsylvania

Any Mack Truck fans in your household? There’s a walking tour of the Mack Truck plant, which mainly builds construction trucks, plus a Mack Trucks Historical Museum and a killer gift shop. Tours are offered on Monday, Wednesday, and Friday, on the hour between 10 a.m. and 3 p.m. Reservations are encouraged.

4. Airstream Factory in Jackson Center, Ohio

Airstream trailers are back in fashion, and this tour shows how they’re made. “We really do put every one of those rivets in by hand,” the company notes. Tours are Monday through Thursday at 2 p.m., with Friday tours offered after normal production hours end. No appointment is necessary, although you can make an online reservation.

5. Subaru of Indiana Automotive in Lafayette, Indiana

Subaru of America’s only U.S. plant. Its tours take you on an elevated catwalk through the facility that builds the Outback, Legacy, and Tribeca, as well as some Camrys under a deal with Toyota. The free tours are offered at 9:00 a.m. on Monday, Wednesday, and Friday. No kids under age ten are permitted.

6. General Motors Fairfax Assembly and Stamping Plant in Kansas City, Kansas

General Motors’ Fairfax plant offers a free tour that shows you the full assembly process from metal being made into body panels all the way through the first time a completed car is started. Products, which include the Buick LaCrosse and the Chevrolet Malibu, roll off the line every fifty-eight seconds.

7. Toyota Motor Manufacturing in Georgetown, Kentucky

At Toyota's Georgetown plant, check out the first U.S.-built Camry (from 1988) in the Visitor Center, then climb into an electric tram for a 1.5-hour comprehensive visit through the plant, which builds 2,000 Camry, Avalon, and Venza vehicles each day. Expect to hear a lot about the vaunted Toyota Production System while you do. Tours are free. The center is open Monday through Friday, 9 a.m. to 4 p.m., and reservations are strongly encouraged. No children under first-grade age (approximately six years old) are permitted.

8. Chevrolet Corvette Assembly Plant in Bowling Green, Kentucky

The Chevrolet Corvette is built here, and in addition to the National Corvette Museum nearby, there’s a walking plant tour (about a mile in all), during which you can watch the sports cars roll off the line. Cost is $7 per person, but if you’re a GM employee or retiree or an active military service member, you can take the tour for free. A $400 VIP tour of both the museum and the factory, which lasts up to four hours and gets you into the prep and delivery area, is also available. Reservations can be made online. Kids under seven are not allowed. Note: The tours, whether the cheap one or the pricey one, won’t be available again until late September as the facility gears up for the all-new 2014 Stingray.

9. Mercedes-Benz's only U.S. plant, in Tuscaloosa, Alabama

The Mercedes-Benz factory, which builds the GL-, M-, and R-Class vehicles, includes an “architectural showcase” of a museum with multimedia exhibits and a gift shop. Available on Tuesdays and Thursdays at 9:00 and 9:15 a.m. and 12:30 and 12:45 p.m., the tour costs $5 a head, and nobody under twelve is allowed on it. Reservations are recommended.

10. Hyundai Motor Manufacturing in Montgomery, Alabama

Hyundai Motor's Alabama plant, where the Sonata and Elantra are built, puts together 1,500 cars a day with the help of humans and “amazing robots.” The tram tour is free and kids over age six are allowed. Tours are available at 9:30 a.m., 12:30 p.m., and 2:00 p.m. on Monday, Wednesday, and Friday, by advance reservation only.

11. Nissan North America in Smyrna, Tennessee

Take Nissan’s motorized tour through all stages of production, from steel sheet cutting to carpet to the exterior paint shop. The Leaf is built here, along with the Altima and Maxima. Tours are free and held on Tuesdays and Thursdays at 10:00 a.m. and 1:00 p.m. No kids under the age of ten are allowed.

pageElements.text: Aston Martin’s newly introduced V12 Vantage S has got to be the fastest thing you’ve ever seen. From its I, Robot seven-speed automated manual transmission to its 565-horsepower engine to its latest-generation Bosch engine management, the new Aston Martin is an extremist in every detail.
You have to ask yourself: In this time of greenhouse gas awareness, eco-mindedness, and alternative-energy initiatives, should you really drool over a V-12 sports car that can hit 205 mph?
205 mph. That’s the same speed as the twister that leveled Moore, Oklahoma, earlier this month.
Think about that one for a minute.

Now think about this: The Aston Martin V12 Vantage S is a work of art. Much as you would not expect to wear what the catwalk models have on at Fashion Week, you probably aren’t going to find yourself behind the wheel of this feral Aston Martin. Probably not ever. (Sorry.) But you can admire it as the work of art it is and appreciate the feats of technology that it represents.

Here are the basic details of this new model:
• 6.0-liter V-12 makes 565 horsepower and 457 pound-feet of torque
• Seven-speed Sportshift III hydraulically actuated automated manual transmission with paddle shifters
• Lightweight sport exhaust system derived from the one on the British automaker's former One-77 hypercar
• Three-stage adaptive damping: Sport, Track, and Normal modes let you choose your suspension setting
• Black carbon fiber all over where the “normal” Vantage has aluminum
• That includes the grille, which shows off Aston Martin's new design language (above)
• Black-painted roof and trunk panel
• Lightweight ten-spoke wheels
• Lightweight carbon fiber seating, plus two grades of leather seating choices, or Alcantara if you prefer
• Carbon fiber interior package option puts the high-tech stuff onto the fascia and door pulls and adds black pedals
• And, hey, eco fans, interior noise is down 30 percent with the use of 80 percent recycled sound-deadening materials!

So, yes, go ahead and drool over this gorgeous coup de théâtre that is the Aston Martin V12 Vantage S. Aston is calling it the fastest roadgoing car it has ever made, with the exception of its One-77—which was sold in extremely limited numbers at more than $1 million. This car is expected to cost $200,000-plus. You can dream, can't you?

pageElements.text: This is the third video in a series, in which I spend some quality time behind the wheel with Elle and Rose, two teenage girls in the process of getting their driver's licenses. We've previously talked about getting set up properly behind the wheel in Part 1 and learning to drive in reverse while using your mirrors in Part 2.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/rX3w-fYIpEQ" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

What's in This Video

In this installment, Elle and Rose learn more about being smooth drivers by understanding what tires can (and can't) do. We talk about the weight transfer that happens when you accelerate, brake, and turn.

Heavy acceleration or braking while the weight is transferring upsets not only your passengers but also the equilibrium of the tires. When the tires are at their limit—that is, when they're making that terrifying screaming noise—the last thing you should do is stress them further by suddenly braking or adding gas. The tires can't take it, and they can completely lose their grip, resulting in a spin or a crash.

Watch the load transfer on the video. I think they got the basic idea after a few turns around the parking lot, don't you? I couldn't bring myself to actually spin the car and freak them out. Or make them vomit on me. Ahem.

Why Am I Doing This Series?

I’ve been racking up to 100,000 miles a year since my late teenage years, when I was a taxicab owner/operator. There is nothing I love to do more than to teach kids the driving secrets I’ve learned over the miles. Damn. I wish had me around when I was their age. I would have told me how stupid it was to drive everywhere at 100 miles an hour. I would have learned emergency maneuvers long before I actually had to make one.
Of course, there is nothing like, oh, a few million or so miles behind the wheel, with a chunk of that at high speed on a racetrack, to give you a tad of well-earned confidence behind the wheel.
At least I learned how to drive a stick before I saw my first automatic.

So here I am, ready to serve. This isn’t a comprehensive driver’s ed class. I’m aiming with the No. 1 Ladies' Driving Academy to share the things I’ve learned wayyy outside the classroom. I want kids to know as many different ways as possible of getting out of trouble on the road. Like, say, avoiding it altogether.
I will keep making these videos as long as there are kids (and don’t take that Ladies thing seriously; boys Я allowed) with new questions about how to do whatever it is they are afraid of doing.
Ask and you will receive.

Love,
Jean

I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: If you have even a passing interest in electric or other alternative-powered vehicles, you have probably noticed high-profile EV maker Tesla Motors. Lately, Tesla CEO Elon Musk has been talking strategy and making big promises. He said in an interview last week that Tesla is targeting an affordable electric car with 200 miles of range, which he hopes the company will be ready to sell within three to four years. By “affordable,” he means less than $40,000.

The least expensive incarnation of Tesla’s current offering, the Model S, will set buyers back more than $62,400 after a $7,500 federal tax incentive, so pricing under $40,000 seems a long way off. Nevertheless, this news, coming on the heels of Tesla’s announcement that it’s paying back government loans ahead of schedule, is more proof that electric vehicles are entering the mainstream. Just this week, Tesla also announced the dramatic expansion of its Supercharger network; it could let Tesla owners charge up their vehicles for free all the way across the country within a year.

Tesla is far from the only producer of electric cars aiming to lower the barriers to entry for electric car ownership. In recent weeks, several auto companies have announced aggressive leasing deals to entice consumers to try out EVs. Snag one, and you could drive off in an EV with a much lower monthly payment than you might have for a similar car that’s traditionally powered.
Here are a few things that make driving electric more wallet-friendly than you might expect.

Lease Deals

Affordable leasing deals for electric cars seem to be the latest rage in car sales. From Tesla to Chevrolet, if you’re thinking of buying an EV, there’s probably a lease deal out there for you. Here are some that are in effect now:

• Fiat 500e (right): It’s only available in California, but if you live there, the Italian automaker has a 36-month, $999 down, $199 a month lease plan for you.
• Nissan Leaf: There’s a 36-month, $199 a month lease deal for the 2013 Leaf, The down payment of $1,999 is quite a bit heftier than the 500e’s.
• Chevrolet Spark EV: The 2014 Spark EV, on sale this summer, will match the 500e’s down payment and monthly payment.

• Honda Fit EV: Starting June 1, Honda is getting in on the game with changes to the Fit EV’s lease plan: the monthly payment for a Fit EV will drop more than $100, from $389 to $259, and a new three-year lease option does away with a down payment.

Tax Incentives

Since many carmakers advertise EV prices minus federal tax incentives, those incentives alone might not be enough to banish sticker shock. But tax incentives can lop thousands of dollars off an electric car’s sticker price, depending on the car and where you live. Buyers can receive a federal tax incentive of up to $7,500 on their new EVs, depending on the car’s battery capacity. Some state and local governments offer further incentives, so if you’re lucky, you could lop as much as $10,000 off the price of your new car.

Lower Costs

At the end of the day, you can’t deny that electric cars carry an initial premium over their gasoline-powered counterparts. But what automakers are hoping is that potential buyers will do some key calculations about the cost of EV ownership. Most obviously, the drivers of electric cars don’t have to shell out for a fresh tank of gas every few hundred miles. Electric cars can typically be charged for as little as a few dollars, and some electric cars also have lower maintenance costs when compared to traditional cars since they have fewer moving parts and don’t require oil and other fluid changes.

Owning an electric car isn’t for everyone—people who drive hundreds of miles per day, for instance, are probably better off sticking with internal-combustion engines for now—but if you’re teetering on the edge of EV ownership, these savings are worth plugging into your calculations.

pageElements.text: New cars these days—even entry-level models—come packed with technology that would have been downright luxurious five years ago. That's all well and good for people who are in a position to buy or lease a new car. But what if you're still making payments on a car you bought just before sleek touchscreens and satellite radio made their way onto standard equipment lists?

As usual, the aftermarket electronics folks are here to save the day. Whether it's a full-on navigation and stereo system or just a stand to give your hands a rest from holding your iPad, there are gadgets that can improve your driving experience without (totally) breaking the bank.

In-Dash Navigation and Stereo

If you're ready to make a serious upgrade, or if you’re just sick of using your phone as a map, you can spring for an in-dash setup that will make you forget that you're not driving a brand-new car. A number of different companies make these systems (an Alpine system is shown at right), but, essentially, all have the same features: a color screen that combines navigation, stereo, Bluetooth, and a CD/DVD player. All are priced around $800, and all require professional installation. Some of the systems will allow drivers to hook up phones and use Pandora or other Internet radio apps. Some can be paired with aftermarket backup cameras, and many include auxiliary jacks or USB inputs to allow you to listen to an iPod or other music player while driving. Best Buy sells a full complement of the systems and offers installation services from the Geek Squad.

Portable Navigation

For drivers on smaller budgets, there is a seemingly endless supply of portable GPS systems that can get you where you’re going for a modest price. You can find a portable navigation system like the Magellan at right for less than $100, and even the low-end models often have features like lifetime map updates and Bluetooth connectivity. More expensive models add features like traffic information, Wi-Fi capability, and even weather updates. Garmin, Magellan, and TomTom all offer affordable systems that can solve your navigation woes.

Rear DVD Player

At Jean Knows Cars, we’re big believers in actually spending time with your family when you’re in the car together, but there’s no denying that a DVD break can keep everyone sane during long rides. If your car didn’t come with rear entertainment, a couple hundred dollars can get you a overhead or headrest-mounted DVD player (with headphone jacks, in case you don’t want to listen to Finding Nemo for the thousandth time). Overhead screens tend to be larger but are not necessarily more expensive. A couple of headrest-mounted screens (like the Audiovox example at right) with built-in DVD players can help avoid the inevitable fights that will come when siblings are asked to agree on a single movie.

Tablet Mount

If you don’t have a DVD player in your car, chances are your passengers are using iPhones or iPads to entertain themselves in the car during lulls in conversation. Whether they’re playing games or watching Phineas and Ferb on Netflix, tablets and smartphones are easily accessible entertainment options that you probably already own. So why spend $200 for a DVD player when you can just download a movie on a device you already own? If your family is maxed out on screens, consider a headrest-mounted tablet holder instead, which will keep that multi-hundred-dollar touchscreen away from your kids’ gooey little hands and prevent the hunchback position many of us assume when staring at phones in the car. Best of all, a tablet mount can be had for less than $40, making it the cheapest upgrade on this list.
Are infotainment upgrades on your wish list, or are you and your ride happily behind the times? Let us know in the comments below!

pageElements.text:
This story originally appeared in the September 1992 issue of Automobile Magazine.

"There isn’t a person in this country who thinks he or she isn’t a good driver. It’s our God-given right."—Roger Johnson, 1989 SCCA Pro Solo overall champion

Salina, Kansas—That would definitely be me. I’m a great driver. I’m so good that when I went to my first autocross event in Pontiac, Michigan, I knew it would be unfair of me to enter the ladies’ class. I mean, with my experience? My expertise at the wheel? Totally unfair.
Then again, trophies are nice.
I entered the ladies’ classs.
I finished in seventeenth place out of twenty-two women entered. Very ladylike, indeed.

Perhaps this sport called Solo by the Sports Car Club of America (SCCA) deserves a closer look. For instance, if these women are so damn good, why do they want to run in the ladies’ class and wreck my chance at a trophy?

The heart of SCCA autocrossing is Solo II, now in its twentieth year. At first blush, Solo II seems like a sissy sport: no roll cage, no five-point seatbelt, no racetrack, no wheel-to-wheel action. Just hop in your street car, exit the freeway at your local stadium parking lot, pay your thirty-five bucks, get into line, and drive around some pylons for two days. Any conehead can do that.

Lots of coneheads do do that. The SCCA sanctions more than 1,200 Solo II events (with up to 175 entrants per event) around the country each year for about 70,000 competitors, making autocrossing the third most popular U.S. motorsport in number of participants, behind drag and oval-track racing.

There are a lot of reasons for the popularity of Solo II:

• There is no big financial commitment—just a helmet, an entry fee that drops if you work the cones for a couple of hours at the event, and an occasional set of tires. You don’t even need an SCCA membership, unless you enter championship events.

• You can share your car with a friend at the events, making autocross a family affair or a pretty cool date.

• There is almost zero risk to your car and your person.

• Money is out there to be won, especially in the most serious form of Solo competition—Pro Solo—where the cream of the Solo II crop compete.

Pro Solo is also a parking-lot affair, but with a twist. The Pro Solo setup is actually two mirror-image courses run by two drivers at a time, so you have the illusion of wheel-to-wheel racing. Each driver gets three sets of runs; each set comprises two runs on both the left and right courses. Rather than trip a timer at the starting line, Pro Solo drivers do a drag-racing-style start—staging at a set of lights called a Christmas tree. Jumping the start will earn you a red light and a DNF rating for the run.

The best drivers shrug off DNF runs as necessary to finding that extra 0.00001 second that will deliver a win. I hated to DNF because there just isn’t that much racing time available to lose. The worst drawback of Pro Solo is that you get about eight minutes of actual driving for your two-day commitment—eight minutes divided among twelve sprints of roughly forty seconds each. Now, if you’re not very good at autocrossing, you can drag the fun out to, say, fifty seconds per run, which boosts total track time to ten minutes.

In truth, the worst drawback for me was that I was no good at it. No good at all. I don’t know what other people did while hanging around the stadium for two days waiting to race for ten minutes, but I spent my extra 950 minutes feeling sorry for myself.

Things would be different this weekend, though. After my abysmal debut back home, I journeyed to the mecca of autocrossing, Salina, Kansas, for the final weekend of the eleven-event Valvoline Pro Solo championship series.

All the top women Pro Solo drivers in the country were here, women who had been using up their entire vacation time autocrossing all summer, women who had won numerous Solo II championships over the years, women who work on their own cars. Women who had beaten my butt in Michigan.
It wasn’t going to happen again. I was going to learn all the secrets.

pageElements.text: The first secret, according to Lisa Kenas (1990 Solo II ladies’ class champion), a twenty-six-year-old most recently of Washington, D.C., is that you have to walk the course as much as possible before your first run, because you can’t practice and because every course is different. “I try to do at least ten laps per side before the first car goes off,” she says. This is one of the weirder scenes I have experienced: a sea of people wandering seemingly aimlessly in a parking lot full of orange cones, the early morning mist rising from asphalt that will be brutal and bubbling by noon. People holding hands, walking dogs, pushing strollers, carrying umbrellas against the heat, as they follow the twists and turns of the course. People on their hands and knees staring intently through a cone-marked corner. People running the course on foot, weaving in and out of the pylon slalom. People on in-line roller skates and bicycles. People with video cameras taking movies of the racing line, movies they will run on fast forward in their hotel rooms, looking for a clue.

Marchell Fletcher, from Colorado (1989 Solo II ladies’ class champion), says walking isn’t enough. It’s important to make accurate maps of the courses and to study them. Fletcher uses graph paper, and she marks every single cone. Then she draws a dotted line to signify the racing line. Then she walks the line. Then she revises her drawing. Then she volunteers to work out there in the cone field when she’s not racing, and she watches how the fastest men take the corners. Then she hauls out her map and revises it again.
“Nothing would make my husband, Rich, happier than if I would beat his time. He’s that kind of guy.”
“She could make money!” said Rich.

All the top drivers agreed that you need a stock car to do well, and most of them were in either a Honda Civic or a Toyota MR2. (Both Honda and Toyota pay contingency money to their winning drivers.) When you race Pro Solo in the ladies’ class, your score isn’t only based on how you do, it’s based on how you do indexed against the top men in your class. The performance envelope is very narrow in, say, a stock Civic, so a top woman driver has a much better chance of being very close to a top male driver in that car. Hence her index will be most favorable. All the girls in the know knew I was screwed, indexwise, because the co-driver of my lovely four-wheel-drive Isuzu Impulse was Grant Byers (1986-87 Solo II champion). Byers works for Monroe, and he runs whatever car he’s using for shock development work. Unfortunately, Byers is good. I just knew I would be the victim of the index.

I made my own graph paper and used a heavy pen to draw in the cones. That way, the mirror-image map would leak through on the back piece of my paper. It was a work of art. I walked the course until my feet blistered in my Nikes. (Just do it.) It was all coming together.

“I’m sorry, but that was probably a waste of time,” said Byers when he saw my map. Gasp. “As soon as the clutch goes down, that’s all forgotten. You need to walk it alone at a brisk pace. That’s the only way you can simulate the flow. All the other things you see people doing are a waste of time.”

He marched me briskly through the turns, telling me where to brake and where to stand on it and pointing out the key cones that I should memorize. “The whole idea is to keep your wheels straight,” he said. “You accelerate best when the wheels are straight. Steady speed. Let the car flow around these pylons,” he said, zipping past the slalom area. “Suck it in here,” he said, pointing to a tight 90-degree left at the finish line. I was prepared. I could do this. The course was cleared, and the race was on.

My first run was abysmal, beginning with the starting lights. You roll up to the start just far enough to light the tree’s top clear light. Then you edge farther to light the second light. You wait until the starter hits a switch and a set of yellow lights counts down to the green. Leave early, and the run is red-lighted. No score. A DNF. I stared at the starter instead of the lights. As I heard Cindy Jansen’s Chevrolet Camaro on my right roar away, I saw in horror that my light was way green. I was holding the Impulse’s revs at about 3,000, and I dropped the clutch. No drama, just an agonizingly sedate departure until the turbo snatched hold and hurtled me toward the first turn. It was a clean, slooow run.

After finishing, I went to the right-hand course. This time, I rolled out of the starting box before the light went green, earning a DNF. Round three: good start, smooth run, and I hit a cone, adding a second to my time. Round four: good start, smooth run, and I’m a full second faster. I’m thrilled. Then I find out that the woman in first place was more than four seconds faster. This, in a sport won by thousandths of a second. So much for the morning.
I sat in the staging area for the afternoon run, parked once again next to Jansen’s Camaro. “It’s demoralizing hearing you roar off next to me,” I confided to her with a smile.
“Forget about her,” barked Byers. “Concentrate on what’s in front of you. Shake your hands. Vigorously!” I did what he said.

pageElements.text: I DNF’d on one side, was slower on the other, and eventually improved my score by two-tenths of a second. I still managed to lose position, slipping down near the back of the pack for my last set of runs. The women at the front were going beserk. Marchell Fletcher shaved nearly a full second from her time, and leader Stacy Reitmeir was whittling away her score with each run. I sat in thirty-fourth place out of thirty-nine entries. Two of those never started. I was beating three women. Happy, happy. Joy, joy. It must be the index, I thought. I refigured the scores without the killer index. Oops. I was dead last.

The battle was on for last place. Judy Murray, in a white Mazda Miata next to me, laughed. “I could have done this well if I’d stayed in bed.” She was in thirty-second place. “You’re faster than I am,” I said as graciously as I could muster. “I am?” she asked with genuine wonder. She laughed harder.

“How do you keep doing this when you run so far back in the pack?” I asked Jansen, in twenty-ninth place. “As long as there’s someone in my rearview mirror” was her rationale. “This is actually unusual for me. Call me a victim of indexing. My volleyball coach used to tell me: ‘Win as if you’re used to it. Lose as if it’s nice for a change.’”
That’s it. I never lose. What a refreshing change that was.

The Pro Solo ladies’ class has only been in existence for three of SCCA Pro Solo’s seven years. “I didn’t run before there was a ladies’ class,” Kenas admitted. “I thought it was self-defeating. It’s succeeded in getting more women into the sport. It didn’t use to happen that you’d see forty women running an event. I love competing against women. It’s guaranteed good competition.”
“I’d run men’s if I had my own car,” said Jansen. “You can’t get to be the best unless you run against the best. I think the division should be between novice and advanced, not men and women.”
I really wanted Stacy Reitmeir’s opinion. She ended up winning the day and the Pro Solo ladies’ championship. In the process, she set a faster time than her husband.
“Why ladies’? Honestly? The money.” Reitmeir took home $5,100 in winnings and contingency money; her male counterpart won a mere $2,315.

I asked perennial Solo champion Roger Johnson why women weren’t running against men. “None of us can figure out why, in twenty years of autocrossing, there hasn’t been a woman who has won the open class, or a time set in a ladies’ class that would have won open.”
Oh, yuck. Are we saying that men are better drivers than women?

“I’m going to give myself the winter to think about going into the men’s class, just for the challenge,” said Reitmeir after she had collected her trophies and loot. “A woman has never done it in the men’s class.”
Go, Stacy, go. I’ll sit this one out.

Epilogue: As this story went to press in 1992, champion Stacy Reitmeir was still running Pro Solo in the ladies’ class in a new Mazda RX-7 Turbo. Cindy Jansen bought her own car, was running with the men in Solo II, and won her first three events of the season.

pageElements.text: Chevrolet’s mid-size sedan, the Malibu, is getting a redesign for 2014. It might not look much different on the outside, but Chevrolet is counting on interior and powertrain improvements to have customers flocking to dealerships.

The Malibu sits above Chevrolet’s pocket-size starter cars, the Spark and the Sonic, and the slightly roomier Cruze in the Chevrolet lineup. The new ’Bu has been tweaked to offer a roomier interior, greater efficiency, and new safety features.

image.altText: chevrolet malibu gets a face lift

pageElements.text: The Malibu gets a revised front end for 2014 that's intended to make it look more like a sibling to the big 2014 Chevrolet Impala. The Impala will also lend suspension enhancements to the Malibu, contributing to what Chevrolet describes as a “more refined” ride. Reshaped front seats will make room for a whole 1.25 inches of extra knee space for rear passengers, and a longer center console will have space for two cups and storage space for two cell phones.

In addition to the currently available rearview camera, desirable new-tech safety features on the 2014 Malibu include side blind zone alert and rear cross traffic safety alert, both of which are optional.

But the most significant changes for the new Malibu will come under the hood. The standard engine for the 2014 Malibu will be an all-new 2.5-liter Ecotec engine that makes 196 horsepower. Using start/stop technology and intake valve lift control, the 2014 Malibu will eke out an extra mile per gallon in both city and highway driving over last year’s model, earning 23 mpg in town and 35 mpg on the highway. Updates to the Malibu’s available 2.0-liter turbocharged powerplant will add fourteen percent more torque to that 259-horsepower engine.
Look for the 2014 Malibu to hit dealer showrooms this fall.

title: Surprise: Middle-Aged Car Buyers Rule

homepage.title: surprise middle aged car buyers rule

pageElements.text: Hey, Millennials, make way! Middle-aged people are by far the biggest group of new-car buyers. That’s the conclusion of a new study from the University of Michigan Transportation Research Institute (UMTRI), which compared data from 2007 and 2011 to spot a strong aging trend in car shopper demographics.

The study found that the age range of “peak probability” for buying a new car is fifty-five to sixty-four. In 2011, one in every 14.6 drivers in that age group bought a new car. Only four years earlier, the biggest buying group was those aged thirty-five to forty-four, so the car-buying public is definitely getting older.
How many cars do the under-twenty-fives buy? It’s no shock, given the economic climate, that only one in 221.8 drivers in that group bought a new car in 2011.

By percentages, buyers thirty-five to forty-four bought 22 percent of all new cars in 2011, and those forty-five to fifty-four bought 26 percent. The fifty-five-to-sixty-four crowd were responsible for 23 percent of the new-car purchases.
So, who’s closing sales at the dealership? Almost half—49 percent—are solidly in middle age, and if you add in the thirty-five and up group, the total reaches 71 percent.
The UMTRI study recommended to marketers that they focus on the AARP-eligible buyers if they want “the highest probability of success per driver.”

A side issue here is that kids are less likely than ever to hurry and get a driver’s license at age sixteen. The UMTRI study pointed out that the number of twenty-to-twenty-four-year-olds with a driver’s license is down from 91.8 percent in 1983 to only 79.7 percent in 2011. Shocking!

Meanwhile, Granny is still clutching her license, and there are more Grannys on the road with every passing day. Drivers aged sixty to sixty-four with driver’s licenses jumped from 83.8 percent in 1983 to 92.7 percent in 2011.

It’s all very well to make jokes about Medicare Sleds, but I prefer to think of it as delayed gratification. It's time to stop thinking of ourselves as aging and watching our powers slip away. The middle-aged and older buyer is in the driver's seat now, coming into her own. You younger types: well, now you've got something to look forward to.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: New Yorkers with a love for aluminum, SUVs, and art: please report to the meatpacking district. Land Rover and Architectural Digest have teamed up to create a popup architectural installation to celebrate the 2013 Range Rover. It will only be displayed from June 7 to June 9, so procrastinators are sure to miss out.

I fell in love with large outdoor sculptures when my design class from Northern Michigan University took a trip to Chicago. I had never been to the Windy City, and I remember the feeling of walking around the enormous Pablo Picasso sculpture titled The Chicago Picasso, Alexander Calder’s Flamingo, Jean Dubuffet’s Monument with Standing Beast, and Joan Miró’s Miró’s Chicago. The massive size of the sculptures with the architectural backdrop of Chicago made the experience magical. Land Rover’s project goes after the same aesthetic of mixing architecture and design on a large scale.

Architectural Digest selected the architectural firm HWKN, whose founders, Matthias Hollwich and Marc Kushner, developed more than fifty concepts to present to Land Rover. They immersed themselves in the Range Rover to draw inspiration. The aluminum of the Range Rover’s body became a muse to the designers and played a significant role in the direction of the design.
“We were inspired by the assembly, form, and performance of the 2013 Range Rover, and that dictated everything we did,” Hollwich said.

“The design of the vehicle itself is so rooted in architecture, and we wanted to translate that DNA into our installation,” Kushner said. “At the same time, we wanted to convey how strong—yet light—the all-aluminum vehicle structure is.”

Ultimately, Land Rover selected Climbing Up as the winner. The design incorporates a series of aluminum plates and the vehicle seemingly floats at a 45-degree angle. Kim McCullough, brand vice president at Land Rover North America, commented, “This spectacular public art installation speaks to the physical properties of high-strength aluminum, as well as the design aesthetic of the 2013 Range Rover, and we're excited to see how it draws attention and discussion to our next-generation Range Rover.”

Visitors to the installation will be encouraged to interact with the exhibit through social media, including Instagram, and their feedback will be shared on flat-screen monitors embedded within the structure.

In a world literally awash with vehicles—from rusty cars that have lived bland, useful lives to rock stars like the Range Rover—we rarely stop and take a 360-degree view of these works of art that dozens of designers painstakingly create for us. Even if we will never get to call this luxury barge our own, we can still appreciate it as a rolling work of art.

The installation premieres on June 7 at the intersection of Ninth Avenue and West Fourteenth Street in Manhattan. The installation will be open to the public from 9 a.m. to 9 p.m. on Friday, June 7, and Saturday, June 8, and from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. on Sunday, June 9.

pageElements.text:
The Car:

Price: $25,005 as tested (including destination charge)
Engine: 2.4-Liter DOHC 16-valve i-VTEC four-cylinder, 201 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed manual
Fuel economy: 22 mpg city/31 mpg highway
My favorite standard features: Rearview camera, Bluetooth hands-free link, USB audio interface, side curtain airbags with rollover sensor, Pandora Internet radio interface, fold-flat rear seats
Option(s) I can’t live without: XM Satellite radio (free for the first three months)

What I Think:

The Honda Civic is well known as the kind of car that a non-car-loving person would go for. It's affordable, reliable, and predictable. Let's face it: it's kind of dull.

That's why I wanted to try out the Si, the sporty version of the Civic. And in fact, I found out that it is perfect for a buyer who wants the reliability of Honda but craves more performance. Is that you?

To be honest, I generally steer away from manual transmissions, so I was apprehensive about recommending a manual as a daily driver. After lots of shifting on quick trips around town, I have a solid opinion.

From the moment I first sat in the driver’s seat of the Civic Si, it had my attention. The interior was obviously designed for a boy racer, from the red-and-black styling to the emphasis on power and performance. The dash has been split into two: the closer dash is dominated by the RPM readout. The second showcases, in a clean layout, everything from a graph that tracks your progress through the gears to a large digital display of your speed, as well as a multi-system display that shows the vehicle stats including personal information like text messages and the current song on Pandora. (Oddly, the fuel indicator shows full on the left and empty on the right.)

I was disturbed by the split dash and struggled to make it fit with my driving position; the steering wheel was blocking the lower dash. I had a hard time finding the steering wheel adjuster and bemoaned the lack of a more comprehensive seat adjuster. But once I found the steering wheel adjuster I became a fan of the clean split-dash design. The interior is wrapped in a highly textured black fabric—that is somewhat distracting —and a nice red contrasting stitching.

The Verdict:

The six-speed manual transmission obviously dictates that the driver is a fan of a sportier ride, so the automatic lover needs to stick with the standard Civic model. As I mentioned, I tend to prefer an automatic myself; however, sometimes it is fun to unleash the boy racer inside me. The Si shifted smoothly and was fun to drive, and the digital readout assisted me in getting the most out of the engine. I would definitely recommend test driving the Si if you are looking at Civics.

Besides, this car had me at integrated Pandora radio. The sporty interior and split dash coupled with the six-speed make this a no-brainer for the buyer who is looking for a less expensive performance ride.

Peanut Gallery:

Annie: I couldn’t get past the garish interior.
Christina: The manual transmission is a problem, but I'd definitely buy it if I could drive it. It's a good, reliable car, and since it's an Si, it will be fun to drive. (Plus, I already drive a Honda, and I love it.)
Laura: This would be the Civic I'd buy my teenagers, but I'd probably get the "normal" one for my boring self.
Scott: I only buy Hondas because my neighbor sells used ones. But this one lost me at manual transmission.
Jean: I like everything about the Civic Si, but then, you would expect that of me. Right out of the box, when I saw the gauges and the new interior, I was excited, and I love that six-speed. It shifts like rich creamery butter. It's the perfect stick to use to learn how to drive a manual. (Any time, Scott. I'm waiting.)

I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop). pageElements.text: Good news for people who own both General Motors vehicles and smartphones: General Motors announced Wednesday that it will make certain features from OnStar’s smartphone app, RemoteLink, standard and free for five years. Included are thirty-six 2014 Buick, Cadillac, Chevrolet, and GMC models equipped with OnStar. Owners of compatible vehicles will be able to lock and unlock their cars, start them remotely, and engage and disengage the alarm with the touch of a smartphone screen.

Free Remote Access Is Good

GM says the RemoteLink app already has more than 320,000 regular users. The company receives roughly 60,000 remote unlocking requests per month. The automaker hopes that making remote access features standard will make life just a little bit easier for their customers. As long as users have a cell phone or wireless Internet connection, they can use the RemoteLink app to connect with their vehicle, even from far away. No more running back to the car from the restaurant to make sure it’s locked—just open up the app and lock it remotely.

OnStar Plans Still Cost, Though

Free access to these basic functions is a new perk for GM customers. Use of the RemoteLink app costs current users $18.95 per month as part of OnStar’s Safe and Sound plan, which also includes vehicle diagnostics, emergency services, and roadside assistance, among other features. For the $28.90-per-month Directions and Connections plan, subscribers can get access to all of the Safe and Sound plan’s services, plus turn-by-turn navigation.
Drivers will still need to pay a subscription fee if they want access to OnStar’s full suite of features. RemoteLink is available for free from the App Store, Google Play, and BlackBerry App World.

pageElements.text: When you get a new car, you resolve to keep it sparkling fresh at all times. Am I right? Then, a few years later, you open the door one day and are revolted by how trashy you've let it become. Here are a few small, inexpensive products I've found around the Internet that can help with that. As they say in Weight Watchers, "If you fail to plan, you plan to fail." So plan to have the equipment you need to keep those messes from accumulating in the first place.

1. A hook for your purse that is just as cute as your purse. What are you doing with your purse now when you drive? You could toss your purse into the back seat, where you can’t reach it to pay for your drive-thru coffee. You could set it on the passenger’s seat next to you, where it will roll around. You could put it on the floor of the car with all the attendant dirt and grime risks. Some people’s extra-large purses could be a danger if they were to fly around loose in an accident.

image.altText: want a tidy car 5 must haves

pageElements.text: So, how about a handbag hook that looks like something the Queen would use? It snaps on to the bar of an adjustable headrest and hangs down over the passenger’s seat in front or rear, keeping your bag stylishly and neatly suspended while you drive. It holds up to fifteen pounds! Price: about $30, plus shipping, from Car-Go Handbag Hooks.

image.altText: want a tidy car 5 must haves

pageElements.text: 2. Car hooks for more prosaic functions. Here's a set of simple chrome hangers, good for everyday needs like hanging up baseball caps or plastic grocery bags on the way home from the store. Price: $4.99 for two, plus shipping, from the Container Store.

image.altText: want a tidy car 5 must haves

pageElements.text: From the same seller, a dry cleaner hook that has little notches in it to keep the wire hangers from sliding together. Carries up to fifteen wire hangers at a time. It slips into the window opening, so it’s something to put in place only while you’re using it. $3.99, also from the Container Store.

image.altText: want a tidy car 5 must haves

pageElements.text: 3. A trash receptacle that stands on its own. Bonus: This one’s waterproof. Made by Talus, this trash holder comes in sizes up to two gallons and has a weighted base and grip strips to keep it rom rolling around in the car. Side pockets hold disinfecting wipes or tissue. Where to put your nearly (but not quite) empty Styrofoam cup of coffee or juice box on a trip? Here’s where. It costs $15.99 for the big one, plus shipping, on Amazon.com.

image.altText: want a tidy car 5 must haves

pageElements.text: 4. Or, a trash receptacle that’s little and cute, so it won’t interfere with your sense of style and will encourage emptying frequently (before the items inside get too ripe). These are handmade litter bags from The ModMobile that hook over a headrest, in a variety of attractive cotton fabrics (forty-four choices, available to browse online). $19 plus shipping, on Etsy.com.

image.altText: want a tidy car 5 must haves

pageElements.text: 5. Personal-care products you can actually reach while driving. I have a dented, torn box of tissues on the floor of my car. Not recommended for hygiene! That’s what makes the unfortunately named Kiss-U Tissue Holder such a good idea. It’s sized like a Pringles can, so it fits in your car’s cup holder slot. The company also makes wet wipe containers in the same shape. The cylinders are attractive, with decorative patterns, and refillable using the company’s own refill packs. Downside: expensive. A set of four tubes and a refill (each of which has seventy tissues inside) costs $22.99 postpaid, and the wet wipes cost $27.99 for three tubes and three refills. The products are available in larger quantities for a smaller per-tube price, though. Order direct from Kiss-U Corps.

title: 2014 Toyota Corolla: Improved?
subTitle: Like or loathe its new silhouette?
promoTeaserSmall: The compact sedan's dramatic new look may (or may not) excite the millions who rely on Corollas.
promoTeaser: The compact sedan's dramatic new look may (or may not) excite the millions who rely on Corollas.
metaTitle: 2014 Toyota Corolla: Improved?
metaDescription: 2014 Toyota Corolla: New & improved? That is the question. The compact sedan gets a whole new look that may or may not be appreciated by Corolla shoppers. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Toyota has given the staid gray lady of compact sedans an edgy, almost sporty new look. Is this a great idea or a huge mistake? Time will tell, but I think the Japanese automaker deserves credit for taking a risk.

When they saw its harbinger, the Furia concept (right), at the Detroit auto show in January, our Group of Seven consumer panel was highly skeptical. “Cheesy” and “too masculine” are a couple of the nicer things that were said about it by the seven women we showed it to. A head-to-head comparison of the Furia and the 2014 Corolla shows that some of the most polarizing elements were toned down for production, as usually happens, but the same overall shape remains.

Have a look at the 2014 model. Perhaps the most interesting addition is LED headlamps (shown on the Eco model at right). All by themselves, the lights—which are standard on all models—bring Toyota into the modern age. The body is not unappealing, with long, lean sides that give the Corolla an I’ve-been-to-the-gym profile. The subtle low grille is almost as good as the ones Fords are rocking this year. There’s more space inside—Toyota says the wheelbase is four inches longer—always a plus in a market segment that puts you at risk of feeling squished.

As for technology, there’s a newly developed continuously variable transmission (CVTi-S) that’s optional. You'd choose a CVT because of performance and fuel economy, because a CVT is always at the optimum point to match engine revs. A downside is that the early ones felt kind of rubbery, but Toyota proudly claims it has developed this one to have a much more natural feel.  The CVT has Eco and Sport driving modes. Getting to make those choices might make drivers feel they are in a more expensive car. Toyota’s Star Safety System is standard, with such modern safety items as stability control, brake assist, and electronic brake-force distribution.  A little less modern is the retention of a four-speed automatic transmission. For those who want a manual transmission, that one's a six-speed, though. The LE Eco model is targeting 40 mpg, although EPA numbers won’t be out for a while.
Pricing will be announced closer to the car’s launch in the fall. The current Corolla, shown at right, starts just over $16,000.

If you’re thinking about buying a Corolla, you are not alone. The Corolla and Camry have been like licenses to print money for Toyota, decade after decade, and the Corolla is the company’s bestseller around the world with almost 40 million sold. Think about this: The 2014 is the model’s eleventh generation. The question is, are the people who shop for this car looking for edgy styling, or are they looking for a reliable appliance? Give Toyota credit for suggesting buyers can have both of those things in one car.

pageElements.text: Always wanted to travel out into the universe but never knew whom to call to arrange near-space travel? We have the answer, but you’ll have to move to Paris first, okay?

French automaker Citroën is holding a promotional drawing to celebrate the launch of its redesigned Citroën C4 Picasso small crossover. It's named the Technospace, and that's exactly where the carmaker is sending the winner of the contest....into space, riding in a MiG-29 fighter jet.

A little historical context here: Citroën is known for quirky cars and, as a proud French company, it wears its weirdness as a badge of honor. The C4 Picasso Technospace is actually pretty mainstream, and the advertising for it may be the most out-there thing about it. (Watch the commercial, in which astronauts fold up the Earth into the shape of the car.)

Available in five- and seven-passenger configurations, the redesigned model features a revised front fascia, an open, breezy cabin, and available technologies like blind spot monitoring, lane departure warning, and a backup camera.

Ground Control to Citroën

The link between a compact family hauler and a trip to the edges of the atmosphere may be tenuous, but we’ll play along as long as Citroën is footing the bill for the jet fuel. The winner of the grand prize will go 14.2 miles up into the atmosphere in a MiG-29, far enough to see the curve of the earth and the blackness of space. On the return journey, the lucky winner will get to experience loops, barrel rolls, and other maneuvers before landing safely back on the ground.

We mentioned that small detail about moving to Paris. Sadly, the Citroën C4 is not available for sale in the United States, and contest entrants must live in France. Still, it's fun to watch the video and look at the contest rules here.

Contest entrants who don’t get picked for the flight to the stratosphere will still have other chances to win. Consolation prizes include a jump in a skydive simulator, a telescope, and a home planetarium projector. Bonne chance à tous!
