pageElements.text: The Porsche 911 is a gorgeous automobile. But is it practical? That's a question you might not be asking. But we did. Back in 2011, Automobile Magazine tested the everyday usability of a Porsche 911 (in the spirit of Porsche's ad campaign "Porsche Everyday"), seeing how much we could get done with it in twenty-four hours. It made a great story and an even better video as the black-on-black 911 Carrera GTS was used for errands, golf outings, and to drive out to the riding stable. Personally, I filled it to the brim with flowers and was amazed at how many I could get in there.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/w-dLEBljNvc?list=UUKWoLlV8-sE8zQnoWHI9qoA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

For this Jean's Driveway review of the 2013 Porsche 911 Carrera S, I invited the three most white-hot auto enthusiast members of my Group of Seven to review it with me: Anna Eby, Val Luepke, and Heather Sager. Did they love the yellow Porsche? What do you think?

Vital Stats

Base price: $97,350 (includes destination)
This car’s price: $144,350 (includes destination). Among the many options are a black leather interior ($3,330), Premium Package Plus with eighteen-way seats ($6,155), sport suspension ($4,050), Porsche PDK seven-speed transmission ($4,080), Burmester audio package ($5,010), Sport Chrono package ($2,370), sport exhaust system ($2,950), ceramic composite brakes ($8520), and a SportDesign steering wheel ($490); on the list of options exclusive to this model are painted air vents ($1,710), racing yellow seatbelts ($540), leather-backed Sport Seats Plus ($1,870), painted center console trim ($290), plus a special painted vehicle key in the color and shape of the car ($335)
EPA fuel economy: 19 mpg city/27 mpg highway
Safety features: eight airbags, including knee airbags; stability control, Hill Hold
Tech features: The world's first seven-speed manual transmission in a passenger car; Auto Start/Stop technology shuts off the engine at stoplights; lightweight body with doors, hood, and roof made of aluminum, all in the name of fuel efficiency
Chief competitors: Chevrolet Corvette Stingray (base price $51,995), Nissan GT-R (base price $100,590), Audi R8 (base price $116,150) (all prices are for 2014 models and include destination)

Key Points

• Porsche is the number-one-selling brand of sports car in the world
• How fast is this car? you ask. Zero to 60 mph in 4.6 seconds; top track speed of 179 mph
• Fascinating factoid: No Porsche, including this one, made the EPA’s list of 2013 Least Fuel Efficient Cars. The Bugatti Veyron topped the list with 10 mpg combined. The list also includes the Chevrolet Camaro, Cadillac CTS wagon, and Ferrari FF
• Cool touch: exhaust button that allows exhaust sound to be funneled directly into cabin
• Purists will like retention of traditional five-gauge array on dash
• Sport Mode is now standard on 911. It adjusts the engine’s response to suit your driving style
• This car has a Sport Chrono package, which adjusts the engine and transmission for high-performance driving. The package includes a stopwatch mounted on the dashboard that shows lap distance, individual lap times, lap number and total driving time
• Porsche Entry & Drive feature lets you keep key in your purse to start car
• A recent demographic study (TrueCar, April 23, 2012) found that the car purchased by the highest majority of men was the Porsche 911. The car with the highest percentage of female buyers was the Volvo S40. Porsche statistics consistently show that the overwhelming majority of 911 buyers are men (around 90 percent) with an average age of fifty-one and a median income approaching $400,000. Porsche has described these men as “determined,” i.e., they made up their minds a long time ago that they would have a 911 when they reached a certain stage of life
• Porsche has not gone after women in any noticeable way. However, Porsche's ad agency surveyed kindergarteners in San Francisco about ten years ago and asked them to draw their dream car. Nearly every child drew a red convertible. Porsche considered it a major win since these kids would aspire to own a Porsche when they grew up

metaTitle: Lincoln's Pothole-Fighting Suspension - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Lincoln's pothole-fighting suspension in the 2013 MKS, MKZ, or MKT your car is fighting potholes while you drive. Lincoln's Continuously Controlled Damping adjusts suspension in real time so you don't feel all the bumps in the road.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: The Lincoln Motor Company is reinventing itself, and it has a few tricks up its sleeve to help remind us all that Lincoln means luxury.  One of those tricks, standard in Lincoln’s 2013 MKZ, MKS, and MKT models, is continuously controlled damping. It may not have the most exciting name, but it’ll save you from the harsh realities of pothole season, and that more than makes up for the uninspiring moniker.

The continuously controlled damping system is designed to ensure optimal ride comfort regardless of road conditions. The system uses no fewer than forty-six data inputs to analyze road conditions and adjust damping forces up to twenty times per second.

The system can switch among Sport, Normal, and Comfort modes in real time, so if you run over a pothole with your front wheels, the system will have adjusted the suspension’s firmness by the time your back wheels hit. This won’t just improve your comfort, it could also help prevent damage to your car from rough impacts. Lincoln says the system is quick enough to tighten the car’s suspension instantly on contact with a pothole. Instant means that it can prevent the tire from traveling the full depth of the pothole, and that's what you want.

Pothole Awareness Is Good No Matter What You're Driving

Even if your car doesn’t benefit from Lincoln’s clever engineering, there are steps you can take to avoid damage from pesky road imperfections. Here are a few tips:

1. Make sure your tires are properly inflated (you can find your recommended tire pressure in your owner’s manual or inside your car’s driver’s side door). This will lessen the chances that a pothole will damage your car’s wheels.
2. Try to drive slowly over potholes, but don’t brake heavily to avoid them. This causes your car’s front suspension to compress and makes it less able to handle uneven road surfaces. Check out Jean’s video about speed bumps for the full rundown.
3. If you do get into a tangle with a particularly nasty pothole, be alert for signs that it may have damaged your car. A sudden vibration or change in ride quality could indicate that something’s amiss.

pageElements.text:
This Volkswagen Passat TDI SE is a big sedan that has great fuel efficiency, especially considering its size. The reason is the Passat TDI's clean diesel engine. It's not like the diesel-powered cars you might remember from the past; this one is not smelly and not noisy, and it gives the Passat 40 mpg on the highway and an 800-mile range between fillups.

Despite these advantages, diesels still make up only a small minority of U.S. vehicle sales, hovering in the two percent region, and diesel fuel currently costs more per gallon than gasoline. There's also a major price premium to buy a diesel version of the Passat: it costs $5,405 more for the base TDI than for the base gasoline-powered Passat. The model I'm looking at in this video is the SE, with sunroof and navigation system. The Passat is fairly well equipped, and there are few options available. Among them are a lip spoiler ($375), a trunk liner ($125), and a set of wheel locks ($100). The Passat's 2.0-liter engine makes 140 horsepower, and the car is equipped with elecctronic stability control, anti-slip regulation (ASR), an electronic differential lock, and radio navigation. This one is Platinum Gray metallic with a Titan Black interior.

pageElements.text: Looking for a way to showcase your love of cars that’s a little more adult than taping a poster of a bright yellow Camaro on your bedroom wall? Yeah, we are, too. Luckily, the world has people like Sabrina Chun, the San Francisco-based artist behind Blackprints, a wildly popular Kickstarter campaign that pairs Pop Art design sensibilities with a love of classic cars. It’s just the kind of thing we’ve been hoping for.

Chun has created black-and-white silhouette prints, dubbed Blackprints, of nine classic cars. The subjects range from the De Lorean DMC-12 of Back to the Future fame to genuine supercars like the Lamborghini Countach. The designs show a pitch black background with each car’s most important design features highlighted in white. Chun hopes that the minimalist prints will bring out the most basic essence of each car and remind viewers why these cars are classics in the first place.

This isn’t highbrow concept art. True to the spirit of Kickstarter, a crowdfunding site for people with big ideas and small wallets, Chun has placed a high value on fan input. After soliciting suggestions from backers for a new Blackprint, Chun added the Ford GT40 and the BMW E30 to her list of honored cars. The artist exceeded her $5,000 funding goal within twenty-four hours of launching her campaign and has now raised nearly $70,000 for her project.

The designs will become photograph-quality prints in either mini (six by nine inch) or jumbo (twenty-four by thirty-eight inch) size. True to her San Francisco roots, Chun has assured shoppers that the whole project will be environmentally friendly, with the designs printed on recycled paper in soybean-based ink. Backers can order a single print or multiples, and everyone who buys a print through the Kickstarter campaign will receive a bonus print featuring the Ford GT40.
Check out the Blackprints Kickstarter page here.

pageElements.text: Pretty big week in Ann Arbor, following Sebastien Vettel’s decisive Formula 1 win in Montreal last Sunday—his first win at that circuit after several attempts, and his third win this season. If you don’t follow Formula 1 racing like I don’t follow Formula 1 racing, you’ll have many questions, as I did. First of all, why was it a big day in Ann Arbor? Well, because he came here to the Automobile Magazine/Jean Knows Cars offices to give us an interview. The list of questions was the subject of intense back and forth between Vettel’s Red Bull Racing team handlers and our editors.

They wanted to vet all Vettel questions and, of course, we said no. We wanted to ask our readers and Facebook fans what they wanted to know from him. This was not necessarily anything that he’d want to answer.

The first question might be, why should anybody care about Sebastian Vettel? Who is he? He’s a slightly built, curly-haired German kid, twenty-five years old, who has won the last three Formula 1 championships in a row. He is dominating the points lead after seven races out of nineteen, with a major lead (see below) of thirty-six points on his nearest competitor, Ferrari’s Fernando Alonso from Spain.

The next question might be, why is the team called Red Bull Racing-Renault when he was coming to see us was in his new role as Infiniti’s performance director? Well, it goes like this: Renault owns Nissan, and Infiniti is part of Nissan.  The engines are from Renault, which has been in Formula 1 racing for a long, long time. Infiniti is trying to become a bigger entity in Europe, and Formula 1 racing is the number-one automotive billboard for the rest of the world outside the United States. So it makes sense that Infiniti would buy into a sponsorship of the team and Vettel to amp up its presence.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/c6G3IvGcgfM" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

You might wonder why they wanted to vet our interview questions. Why would they care? Because Vettel’s first win this year, in Malaysia, came at the closing moments of the race when the driver separating him from his teammate, Mark Weber, who was running in first place, dropped out. Vettel then ignored team orders, passed Weber, and won the race. He later apologized, but the die was cast, and the fans have been unruly ever since. In fact, when he won in Canada, he was booed loudly by the crowd. We actually did ask him about his reception after the Canadian race. He rightfully pointed out the huge number of Ferrari fans and said he was encouraged by the increasing number of blue-hatted Red Bull fans in the crowd. Watch the video for the answers to this and other questions from our Facebook fans and readers.
Then he was gone, leaving behind a big stack of Red Bull/Infiniti hats with a big, fat number 1 on each bill.

metaTitle: 2014 Subaru Forester 2.0XT Touring - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: 2014 Subaru Forester 2.0XT Touring: read our "should you buy it?" review and comments from other staffers up in the Peanut Gallery. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text:
The Car:

Price: $36,220 as tested (including destination charge)
Engine: 2.0-liter DOHC turbocharged horizontally opposed four-cylinder, 250 horsepower
Transmission: Continuously variable
Fuel economy: 23 mpg city/28 mpg highway
My favorite standard features: Panoramic moonroof, 6.1-inch touchscreen with navigation system
Options I can’t live without: Adaptive cruise control and pre-collision braking (both part of EyeSight driver assist package, $2,400)
You might also be considering: Ford Escape, Honda CR-V, Kia Sportage
See more specs in our Car Guide.

What I Think:

Subaru makes a business out of catering to two very different clientele: the boy-racer types who lust after sporty BRZs and Impreza WRXs, and practical, active drivers who put a high premium on safety. The all-new 2014 Subaru Forester 2.0XT Touring services the latter population and does an admirable job of it.

The 2014 Forester immediately sets itself apart from the crowd with its outstanding safety ratings from the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety (IIHS). The Forester was a Top Safety Pick Plus winner and was one of only thirteen small SUVs to receive an overall Good rating on the IIHS test. The Forester we tested was packed with extra safety features as well, including lane departure warning, pre-collision braking, and the Subaru EyeSight system, which uses cameras to monitor the road and recognize hazardous situations.

Safe doesn’t have to mean boring, though. Our Forester’s 250-horsepower, 2.0-liter turbocharged engine provided plenty of steam to get this small SUV off the line, and the continuously variable transmission means that the Forester can constantly alter its gear ratios to operate at the engine’s most efficient revolutions per minute at a variety of speeds. The 2.0XT Touring model gets an impressive 28 mpg on the highway despite its all-wheel-drive system.

Standard all-wheel drive means the Forester will have characteristic Subaru surefootedness in bad weather, and the top-shelf models include features like hill descent control to give you an extra measure of confidence on tricky slopes.

Our Forester came with attractive leather-trimmed upholstery, which gave the cabin an upscale feel. The premium Harman/Kardon infotainment system looked like an aftermarket afterthought but it sounded like a dream. Subaru went the extra mile to win over drivers with the power liftgate and one-touch folding rear seats. Just a touch of a button in the trunk will give you a nearly flat load floor in seconds.

The Verdict:

Our 2.0XT is a no-brainer. The $36,000 price is a little hefty, but this crossover comes packed with the kind of safety and comfort features you'd expect in a luxury vehicle. Of course, you could always opt for a lower trim level, which still includes Subaru's confident all-wheel-drive system and enough airbags to keep anyone happy. But I think it would be a real shame to lose the turbo engine to a bout of frugality.

Peanut Gallery:

Molly: The first thing that struck me when I opened the Forester's doors was the floor mats. They are rubber with large lips that look like they could hold a couple liters of liquid. The interior was also predictably smart; everything felt like it was built to be driven well over the century mark on the odometer. I expected the driving experience to be the same feeling—prudent and slightly dull. I was proven wrong on a quick trip to Target. The 2.0-liter turbocharged engine was actually fun to drive and will make me think twice about this car.
Christina: I come from a Subaru-driving family. I love Subarus and I love the way this one drives. However, I didn’t feel comfortable behind the wheel at all. The steering wheel blocked the gauges. The color display over the touchscreen was distracting. The climate control knobs were confusing. And the ceiling? Despite the fact that I’m short, I felt my head was up too close to the headliner once I adjusted the driver’s seat so that I had a good view of the road. I'd hate to be a tall person driving this one.
Laura: I have known lots of people who drove Subarus, since we live in a wintry, and also a hippieish, climate here in Ann Arbor, Michigan. I haven’t considered owning one myself until now, because none of my friends’ cars were this good. This Subaru is utterly practical: I love the power liftgate, the stealth storage cubbies under the cargo floor, and the rubber mats everywhere that manage to look good while they make you start thinking about owning this Forester for ten years. The best part: while you’re driving around feeling smart and capable, like the kind of person who reads Consumer Reports for fun, notice how much fun you are having in this car.
Jean: I've recommended a Forester to three different people in the past month. That was before I knew it had—wait for it—a power liftgate! The Forester has been solid from Day One, ten years ago. It now feels a lot bigger and a lot more grown-up-looking inside (although the exterior still looks awkwardly adolescent). But it has a power liftgate!

metaTitle: John Oates and Me - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: John Oates and Me: a video interview with the great John Oates of Hall and Oates fame, an old friend of mine for some 30 years. See it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: John Oates is an old friend of mine, and I’ve seen Hall & Oates perform many, many times, in venues from concert halls to open-air amphitheaters. It all started almost thirty years ago, when the phone rang. "Hi, this is John Oates. I like your writing, and I would love it if you’d come to our concert."
"Who is this?" I asked.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/FvoQPkDLniE" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
"It’s John Oates, from Hall and Oates."
"Oh! I thought that band was called Howlin' Oats!"
"Nice," he said.

At first, I tried to beg off, being a hard-core Pink Floyd sort of girl, and he shamed me by saying, "We're going to be playing several dates. Surely you can make one of them, and I'll give you backstage passes." So I said, "Okay, sure, that sounds cool."

So six of us went. We had fantastic seats looking straight at the band, which was—Oh My God—the Saturday Night Live band with guitarist G.E. Smith fronting it and legendary bass player T-Bone Wolk. The band kicked off, and all night it was the rockingest show. I kept saying, "Oh, they do that? Oh, that's theirs?" and I was absolutely as hooked as all the rest of the fans who have made this duo the number-one duo in all of history. They’re bigger than Simon and Garfunkel, bigger than Jan and Dean, and still at it.

After that concert I really cemented a relationship with Oates when we both raced in the Renault LeCar Cup support race that backed one of the first Formula 1 races in downtown Detroit. He went on to club racing and raced karts and in Formula Ford, the Pro Sports 2000 series, and IMSA GTU, and he is a huge car fan. One year I even ran into him walking around the Detroit auto show with his wife and son. He was in town to perform at a black-tie auto function.

Over the years, I have seen them play an outdoor venue in Ohio in a field, I've hung out with band on their tour bus while it was parked in front of their hotel ready to leave, I’ve been with them in New York City in the recording studio while they worked on a Christmas special, and I have been to endless concerts. They never, ever get old. Now when they tour they add on a lot of casino shows, which can be surprisingly nice venues, including Motor City Casino in Detroit and FireKeepers in Battle Creek, where we interviewed him for this video. The backstage amenities here were pretty funny, as you can see when John offers me the perks of his stardom.

John and Daryl have developed distinctly different solo careers. John's is based out of Nashville, and his love of old R&B and blues is really in line with the kind of music I like. Daryl, on the other hand, developed an online show called Live from Daryl’s House in his farmhouse, where he invites every kind of musician from reggae kings Toots and the Maytals to the legendary Smokey Robinson to the electric Sharon Jones of the Dap-Kings. The series has just expanded to be on VH1 cable TV on Saturday mornings. His voice is only somewhat dimmed over the years; it is still pretty monster.

When John called to say he was going to be in town, he gave us passes for the Jean Knows Cars staff, and as usual, we had the time of our lives, surrounded by a roomful of people who were on their feet. On this video, he talks about what a rock star drives and his favorite music.

I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text:
The Car:

Price: $23,195 as tested (including destination charge)
Engine: 1.4-liter SOHC 16-valve turbocharged four-cylinder, 160 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed dual-clutch automatic
Fuel economy: 27 mpg city/37 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Hill start assist
Options I can’t live without: 8.4-inch Uconnect touchscreen ($595) with navigation ($495) and SiriusXM satellite radio ($195); racetrack taillights ($225); leather-wrapped steering wheel (part of Popular Equipment group, $495)

What I Think:

The Dodge Dart is one of Chrysler’s first big collaborations with new owner Fiat, and it's Dodge’s first compact sedan this decade, so the 2013 Dart is important for Chrysler Group. (See our Jean's Driveway review from last fall.) Starting below $20,000, it could also be an important addition to the good-cars-for-people-on-a-budget category. The Dart I drove, the SXT MultiAir Turbo, was pushed above $20,000 by the addition of a six-speed dual-clutch automatic transmission and a 1.4-liter four-cylinder turbocharged engine, but it still came in well under $25,000.

Those pricey options—each adds more than $1,000 to the price of the car—aren’t my favorite aspects of the Dart. The dual-clutch transmission feels slow and a little jerky, while the turbocharged engine sips expensive premium fuel and offers only modest power increases from the standard, non-turbocharged engine. Luckily, the Dart assuages some price concerns with its impressive fuel economy: 27 mpg city and 37 mpg highway. Without the engine upgrade, the Dart would still manage 25 mpg in the city and 36 mpg on the highway.

Fuel economy isn’t the only place the Dart stands out. Its exterior styling sets it apart from its compact-sedan competition. The aggressive front grille and angular headlights help the Dart stand out from the crowd in a segment that rarely excites, and the optional racetrack taillights lend the car an appealing, sporty character.

On the inside, the available 8.4-inch Uconnect touchscreen infotainment system feels like a necessity. It looks great, works smoothly, and controls everything from the cabin temperature to the radio station. It’s hard to imagine the Dart’s cabin without this command center. It makes the car feel more expensive than it is—always a good quality in an optional upgrade.

The Verdict:

For what it is—a starter car with hypermiling fuel economy ratings—the Dart does very well. If I were shopping for a Dart, I would consider opting for the standard 2.0-liter Tigershark engine and manual transmission to avoid the premium-fuel requirement, but I'd keep our tester’s Uconnect system and racetrack taillights. If the Dart’s strong styling alone isn’t enough to keep you interested, consider one of the Dart’s outlandish paint colors, like Citrus Peel (a bright lime green) or Header Orange.

If you’re looking for something sportier, check out the special edition Mopar '13 Dart, offered through Chrysler’s aftermarket parts brand. The Mopar Dart will be available this summer and will feature a black exterior with a bright blue racing stripe, black rims, and an all-black interior with blue contrast stitching and a Mopar blue driver’s seat. Performance upgrades include a lowered suspension, recalibrated steering, and a performance-tuned exhaust. Starting at $26,480 including destination, the Mopar '13 Dart will be powered by the same 1.4-liter turbocharged engine in our test Dart, this time mated to a six-speed manual transmission. Mopar is only making 500 of these Darts, so you’ll need to act fast if you want to snap one up, but it might just be worth it.

images.caption: Interior of 2013 Dodge Dart SXT MultiAir Turbo

pageElements.text:
Peanut Gallery:

Molly: The Dart is close to getting my personal seal of approval, but the six-speed dual-clutch automatic transmission is a deal breaker. The idea of a dual clutch is to achieve quicker, smoother shifting, but it is definitely not the result I experienced. Rather, the shifts were slow and very noticeable, resulting in a choppy ride. I do really like the styling and interior accoutrements, and the price point is perfect for my pocketbook.
Christina: The exterior does nothing for me, but the seats are really comfortable, and I like the price. I wouldn't buy our test car, but I'd buy the version that takes regular gas.
Laura: I walked in to the Peanut Gallery already biased: my first car was a Plymouth Duster, and I have a Dodge Dart Swinger in my past that reminds me of all kinds of teenage fun. With that disclosure in mind, I appreciate the traditional American feeling of this new Dart. The seats are comfortable, particularly the headrests, and the feeling both inside and out is simple and no-nonsense. I wouldn't buy it for myself, but I'd feel good about having one of my kids own it.
Scott: I really like the simplicity of the interior. The gas door release button is right there on the door. I don't have to bend to reach it. And the climate control buttons are easy to use and easy to see.

Jean: Love the ride, the handling, the braking, and absolutely adore the steering. But for an enthusiastic thumbs up, buy the limited-edition Mopar ’13 Dart in pitch black with a blue stripe streaking across the roof from stem to stern. The body is lowered and racier, the tires are meatier, and the seats are swathed in dreamy black-and-blue Katzkin leather, which helps fix the boring interior. Then again, I am a twelve-year-old boy.

title: Ford Driving Skills for Life
subTitle: Could you or your teenager use this?
promoTeaserSmall: I was a texting fail on Ford's cone course. Even Jean struggled. Our eyes are open now.
promoTeaser: I was a texting fail on Ford's cone course. Even Jean struggled. Our eyes are open now.
metaTitle: Ford Driving Skills for Life Turns 10 - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Ford Driving Skills for Life Turns 10. The teen driving course, which includes a segment showing how wrong it is to text while driving, has already reached a half million students online and in person. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: What’s the scariest part of being a parent of teenagers? Speaking as a person with a house full of them, I will tell you: it’s the idea that they are out on the roads with their friends, driving around feeling young and impervious to danger. Are they or their friends texting while behind the wheel? Are they playing the music at bone-shattering speeds (perhaps literally, if they get into an accident because they can’t hear traffic sounds around them)? Are they remembering a single thing they learned in driver ed class? If I text them, “Be careful on the roads,” or “Please come home,” will they read it while driving, thereby making any accident my fault? I know the statistics about teen drivers. How about this one, courtesy of Ford: a sixteen-year-old is ten times more likely than an adult to be involved in a crash.

It’s with that parental angst at the forefront of my mind that Jean Jennings and I attended a sampling of the Ford Driving Skills for Life program for teenagers. Now celebrating its tenth anniversary, the program’s printed materials, website, and driving program are meant to allay fears of parents like me—while building real understanding and skills among the kids.

Operated in conjunction with the Governors Highway Safety Association, the program focuses on what director Jim Graham calls “the four skill areas that teens lack.” (Insert your ironic comment here!) Graham identifies those skill areas as: speed and space management, hazard recognition, vehicle distractions, and handling.

Ford has increased its commitment to the Driving Skills for Life program, which has already reached more than a half million users either in person or online. In 2013, Ford's high school tour will put some 40,000 teen drivers behind the wheel. Online, there's a new interactive portion due out in August, including a game, co-developed with Michigan State University, that simulates the in-person program. While waiting for that, try going through the Ford Driving Skills for Life Academy online program. It's not quite the same as getting behind the wheel in Ford's program, but it can't hurt, and it's good for both teens and adults.

image.caption: Lead facilitator Mike Speck high-fives a student.

pageElements.text:
How the Program Helps

Smart idea #1: Ford hires cool drivers as teachers. That ought to help teenagers pay closer attention to what they say. We were teamed with Hollywood stuntwoman Susan Purkhiser and with lead facilitator Mike Speck (right), who is a former kart racer, military special operations instructor, and fifteen-year faculty member of the Bob Bondurant School of High Performance Driving.

You don’t have to be a parent of teens to know that they can be overconfident. Mike pointed out that some of that confidence is understandable. “The actual task of driving, day to day, is not hard,” he said. “The decision about how to drive is what’s hard.” Mike told us they don’t try to scare kids—just get them to see what can happen so they can start to make informed decisions about their behavior.

Smart idea #2: The “handling car.” The program works with four vehicles, prepped differently. One has a looser back end to teach teen drivers how a vehicle behaves in a slide and how to get out of it.

Smart idea #3: Parents and teens can go through the program together. Seeing what actually happens to your driving ability when you text while driving is an eye-opening part of the Ford program, and that's a behavior that people of all ages are guilty of. Sadly, parents are not always good role models when it comes to driving. Teens tend to emulate what the parents are doing—so, parents, are you teaching safe behavior while you drive your kids to soccer practice?

And Now, About Our Texting Fail...

Jean and I tried out the automaker’s short but attention-demanding cone course inside the Ford test track complex in Dearborn, Michigan. There were sudden stops, sharp turns, and a tight roundabout. We didn't have to drive fast, just accurately. The challenge: to text the words to the Gettysburg Address while driving. On the first, non-texting pass around the course, Jean’s form was impeccable. (Mike, in the front passenger’s seat, even requested an encore, and she dutifully drove around it again.) Then she tried it while texting and did…less well, as you see here (right). My own performance was nothing to write home about even while I wasn’t texting, and shockingly bad while I was. As my teens might say, I got owned by the cones. It showed me in no uncertain terms why not to take the smartphone out while driving.
Interested in participating in the program? You can sign up online to be notified when the driving program is coming to a school near you.

images.caption: Seeing the effects on driving skills of texting is an eye opener for all ages.
Handling is one of the big four skills that Ford's program tackles.
Jean drove the course while attempting to text the Gettysburg Address.

pageElements.text: Are you excited about the prospect of a car that can park itself? Then today is your lucky day, because Volvo has introduced its new Autonomous Parking technology and showed off the way it can find an open parking space and park your car, all without your input or even presence in the car. Like all the most fun new things, the technology works by commands from your smartphone.

Just pull up to the entrance of a parking structure, click, and walk away while the car finds its own spot. So far, Volvo has only rolled out the technology in the video demonstration shown below, but a live demo is scheduled to happen before the end of the month.

image.caption: Detection and auto brake keep the car from hitting pedestrians or other vehicles.

pageElements.text: Volvo combined the autonomous driving technology with detection and auto braking. That's to ensure your car doesn't barrel into a space while endangering other cars or pedestrians in the parking lot. It works using sensors and "Vehicle 2 Infrastructure technology," which means it communicates with transmitters set up along the roads. Obviously, the infrastructure is not yet in place to make this feasible on a large scale, but just wait.
Only a few months ago, Volvo announced its cyclist detection technology, one more in a long line of safety technologies the Swedish automaker has made its name with.

Coming Sooner Than You Think

Impatient to try it? Volvo will roll out autonomous steering on its all-new 2015 XC90, coming in late 2014. This is just a preliminary step in Volvo's campaign to make cars that are capable of driving themselves. So stand by!
Do you like this idea or hate it? Perhaps you're deeply conflicted about it? Comment below.

pageElements.text: So you’re ready to head out to your local dealership and start car shopping. Congratulations! We’d love to help. Since it’s always a good idea to get information straight from the source, we went to a very successful saleswoman right here in our town and asked her what she’d like her customers to know before they walk in the door.

Beth Bashert (right) has been a top salesperson at Dunning Toyota in Ann Arbor, Michigan, since her first year there, in 2006. She describes her profession as “relationship based” and says up to 70 percent of her customers are repeat clients or are referred by satisfied customers. Since Beth also told us she’s on track to sell more than 200 new and used cars this year, we figured she knows what she is talking about.
Here are her five tips for you, if you are getting ready to walk into a dealership in pursuit of your next vehicle.

1. Do the amount of advance research you feel comfortable with.

Beth says she finds the average customer has already done eleven hours of Internet research before coming in to the dealership. “That’s the tool the Internet has given people. Do as much or as little research as you want before you come in,” she says, but understand that your salesperson is “actually there to help you. We have a fair amount of information that augments the research you’ve already done.” Having said that, she points out that she always invites her clients to confirm whatever information she gives them, if they want to. “I want my customer to feel comfortable at the end of the process.”

2. Get referrals from people you know and trust.

“Ask your friends. Where did they buy their car, who did they buy it from, and would they go back there again? Even if you’re new in town, you know somebody you can ask: coworkers, neighbors, your dentist. If they wouldn’t go back to the same dealer, that’s a useful answer, too.”

3. Focus on getting the salesperson you want.

“Eighty percent of new contacts are now e-mail initiated,” Beth explains. “A lot of times, unless you initially ask for a salesperson, you’ll get round-robined to whoever’s turn is next in the queue. Sometimes there’s a business development center in the dealership that handles e-mail queries and does initial contact until you make an appointment. At any time in there, if you have a preference—male, female, age, a used-car expert—you can specify. People are often thinking, ‘I want a blue car,’ not ‘I want a certain kind of salesperson to help me through the transaction,’ ” Beth says. Remember what stage of the transaction you're in and get that job done.

Next? “Once you get to the appointment, unless the salesperson warrants it, it’s not necessary to treat them like the enemy. You need to be willing to share with me, which means you have to trust me,” she says. But, she adds, if you find that your salesperson is not treating you well, or just isn’t going to make you feel comfortable, get up from the desk and ask for a different one. “Trust me,” Beth says, “we have thick hides.”

Not comfortable speaking up? If the relationship is not going to work, one way Beth has seen clients handle it is to end the appointment, then call the dealership from home to ask for a different salesperson. “That works!” she says.

4. Understand your financial situation and be ready to consider various options.

Beth remarks, “A shocking amount of what I do with people is financial planning.” Look at the salesperson as an informed resource who can help you find the best solution for your needs, she says. “Some people come in with a plan in place about how they’re going to buy the car—X money down, Y payment, Z equipment, pay off over A number of years—and sometimes I can help them see different ways of going about it that make it possible not to have to wait to have that down payment, or to pay a lower interest rate by getting a better car and saving money down the line.”

5. Don't stress out and ruin the experience.

“Don't be in your head 100 percent,” Beth says. In that, she is definitely on the same page with JeanKnowsCars.com. Like us, she sees that buying a new car is a treat, and you should let yourself appreciate the indulgence. “The numbers have to line up—size, fuel economy, specs—but don’t let that be the only factor. Let the salesperson help you enjoy the big purchase. Part of a purchase is emotional. If you don’t enjoy it, you’re not going to get the most out of it.” How to do that? Beth advises, “Relax, follow your instincts, and buy from someone you feel good about working with.”

After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: This is starting to feel like the golden age of safety technology. It’s exciting to think that such basic operations as braking can be optimized by the use of advanced wireless communications technology. That’s just what Ford is doing with its research to improve brake lights.

We’ve had our eye on connected vehicles for a while now, and we’re always excited to hear about new applications for car-to-car communication. This week, the excitement comes from Ford’s experimental brake light warning technology, currently in testing as part of the Safe Intelligent Mobility-Testfield Germany (simTD) project.

The technology consists of a high-tech brake light that can communicate with other cars in emergency braking situations to help reduce reaction time for other drivers. The Electronic Brake Light works by transmitting a wireless signal to cars behind it, alerting them of episodes of heavy braking by illuminating a light on their dashboards.

In 41,000 hours of testing, Ford has seen that the technology can help drivers react faster to the emergency braking of cars ahead and help them “mitigate or avoid” collisions. The testing was done with specially equipped versions of the Ford S-Max (right), a small three-row vehicle sold in Europe.

The brake light is just one of twenty safety systems that Ford is testing in Aachen, Germany, as part of the simTD project. Other systems include in-car Internet access and a public traffic management system that would give drivers an exact traffic prediction based on existing traffic scenarios and travel time. These technologies may still be a long way off from real-world implementation, but it’s nice to know that in-car technology won’t stop with touchscreen navigation systems.

pageElements.text: Looking for an eco-friendly vehicle for quick trips around town that’s even more eco-friendly than a bicycle? Or are you interested in solutions to the transportation needs of people in developing countries? Look no further than Cardboard Technologies, which has just launched a campaign to crowdfund a bicycle made mainly out of cardboard. This ultra-low-cost bike has the potential to "change the world," says the Israel-based company.

If you think a functional bike made of cardboard sounds impossible, you’ve got company. The first engineers that inventor Izhar Gafni talked to about the project told him it couldn’t be done. But Gafni didn’t take impossible for an answer and developed techniques that allowed him to build a bike that could easily support the weight of its rider and stand up to riding on actual road surfaces. The bike is coated with a water- and fireproof varnish for durability. It is a single-speeder. And it can hold up to 300 pounds, which is not bad for a twenty-eight-pound bike.

Cheap Wheels

The ultimate selling price of the cardboard bike is expected to be around $30, with the cost of parts under $10. It's easy to picture people all over the world making this bicycle the first personal transportation they've ever owned. Even in Manhattan, where a one-week pass for the heavily publicized new Citi Bike rental fleet (right) costs $25 plus tax, that $30 bike looks pretty good.

The team at Cardboard Technologies hopes that the cardboard bike will lead to other cardboard products; plans for baby strollers and wheelchairs are already in the works. The company believes its innovative manufacturing techniques will help build a world in which transportation is cheaper, more accessible, and more environmentally friendly. "It's strong. It's durable. It's cheap," says Gafni. And yes, even the seat is made from cardboard, but it looks fun to ride on anyway.

The cardboard bike campaign is hosted on Indiegogo.com, a website that helps connect entrepreneurs with funding sources. Cardboard Technologies is looking to raise $2 million for the construction of the cardboard bikes, and the project had pulled in more $7,000 in funding from backers by the end of the first day.

Pledge levels start at just $1, and rewards for larger donations include organic T-shirts, posters, and a mini push bike for kids. For $250 plus $40 for shipping to the United States or Europe, backers can own one of the first 5,000 bikes to roll off the production line. The bad news? That production line doesn’t exist yet, and bikes won’t be delivered until 2015.

pageElements.text:
The Car:

Price: $32,135 as tested (including destination charge)
Engine: 3.5-liter DOHC 24-valve V-6, 270 horsepower
Transmission: Continuously variable
Fuel economy: 22 mpg city/31 mpg highway
My favorite standard features: Leather-appointed seats, nine-speaker Bose audio system, rearview camera
Options I can’t live without: Seven-inch navigation display, blind spot monitoring, lane departure warning (all part of $1,090 Technology package)
You might also be considering: Ford Fusion Titanium, Honda Accord EX-L V-6, Toyota Camry XLE V-6, Hyundai Sonata Limited 2.0T
See more specs in our Car Guide.

What I Think:

Redesigned for 2013, the Nissan Altima has a newly distinctive exterior—note the kinked taillamps and the larger front grille—and more available technology than ever before. The Altima is one of the bestselling cars in its segment; more than 140,000 of them have left dealer lots since the start of 2013. We decided to take one for a spin to see what all the fuss is about.

The top-of-the-line Nissan Altima 3.5SL we tested has every option that’s available for this mid-size sedan. The SL trim level is decked out with a nine-speaker Bose audio system, leather seats, keyless entry and push-button start, and a heated steering wheel. The 3.5SL’s standard 270-horsepower V-6 engine offers an 88-horsepower boost over the base Altima’s four-cylinder engine but still manages 31 mpg on the highway, thanks to a fuel-saving continuously variable transmission. The optional technology package gives this Altima a seven-inch navigation display, blind spot monitoring, lane departure warning, and moving object detection for just $1,090.

All that technology could get overwhelming, but the Altima doesn’t feel bogged down with buttons or blinking lights. The driver information display in the dash allows the driver to toggle through the various systems and their settings with ease, and the infotainment system was simple to operate, even though I didn’t spend fifteen minutes in the parking lot with an owner’s manual figuring it all out.

The Altima feels spacious and luxurious inside, a vehicle designed for family trips or long commutes. Driving the Altima around town, the V-6 engine provided more than ample power to accelerate off red lights, but its true calling is as a slightly sub-luxury daily driver. The whole car—from the wide, soft seats to the smooth ride to the steering—feels a little soft. But that’s not necessarily a bad thing. With its floaty ride and somewhat ponderous steering response, the Altima isn’t the right car to take around a handling course, but it’s perfect for eating up highway miles in total comfort.

The Verdict:

The Altima 3.5SL manages to deliver a lot of luxury for a fairly affordable price. The $32,135 model we tested is the most expensive Altima money can buy, but it makes up for it by being absolutely packed with content. The powertrain is powerful and satisfying without guzzling gas, and the interior is comfortable and attractive. This car isn’t quite right for my lifestyle, but if you are a person who has a longer commute or needs something with a usable rear seat, the Altima should have your attention.

Peanut Gallery:

Molly: The exterior styling is rather dull, and the interior was ruined by the shiny, pattern-printed, glittery plastic details. However, the Altima quietly won me over with its V-6 engine. It is fun to drive and offers plenty of power yet still manages to have decent fuel economy numbers. And the "zero gravity" NASA-inspired seats are amazingly comfortable.

Scott: I was surprised by how spacious this sedan's trunk is; I can put all my junk in it. As Steve Carell's character said in The 40-Year-Old Virgin, "I hope you have a big trunk, 'cause I'm putting my bike in it." Seriously, as a videographer, I need to travel with a lot of equipment, and the Altima would allow me to drive a mid-size sedan and still take everything I need. Seriously.

Christina: The Altima's exterior may be dull to some, but that doesn't matter to me. It's a comfortable car, and it has a nice, smooth ride, a powerful engine, and great fuel economy. With the one-hour commute I have, that's all I need (well, that and the heated seats for winter).

Laura: Boy, you really can't tell how much fun it is to drive this car by looking at it. Both inside and out, it is unremarkable in every way. But then you accelerate on an open stretch of roadway, and all you can do is chuckle at the brilliant subterfuge while you enjoy the experience. To own this car (and you should definitely only own it with this engine), you need to be the kind of person who isn't looking to impress other people, just yourself.

Jean: The Altima used to be dowdier, and it's still fairly bland to look at. But you're going to be inside, right? That's just one place where the Altima—especially in SL trim—really shines, with juicy standard equipment like heated seats, heated outside mirrors, and a heated steering wheel, the dreamiest feature of all to us northerners. The cabin is trimmed in leather, and there's a nine-speaker Bose audio system, fog lights, and high intensity discharge (HID) xenon headlamps. The auto power windows also have one-touch auto up as well as down.

The carpets on the floor and in the trunk are an extra $185. Whatever. But the really must-have option is the technology package. For a mere $1,090, you get a nav system with a seven-inch color display, blind spot warning, and lane departure warning.

I hate to sound like a broken record, but the Altima with my personal JeanKnowsCars.com Buy This Car seal of approval has this 3.5-liter engine. It's a honey, and it will still manage 31 mpg on the highway.

title: A Weekend with 30 Women and 10 Cars
subTitle: Do you like or loathe being marketed to?
promoTitle: A Weekend with 30 Women and 10 Cars
promoTeaserSmall: Women drive purchase decisions about cars! And automakers know that, as this all-woman event proved.
promoTeaser: Women drive purchase decisions about cars! And automakers know that, as this all-woman event proved.
keywords: A Weekend with 30 Women and 10 Cars
metaTitle: A Weekend with 30 Women and 10 Cars - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: A weekend with 30 women and 10 cars: An Aston Martin DB9 and several more prosaic vehicles were up for the driving at the third annual Heels & Wheels event in Oregon. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: When people ask me how I started writing about cars, I tell them I'm from Detroit. I tell them about my father, who was a Chrysler engineer, and the crazy cars he would bring home to test drive. But before I discovered the glamorous life of an automotive journalist, I was a writer living in the Motor City, covering music and art in the Nineties. Things changed when I became curious about the industry that made the city tick and interned at AutoWeek magazine. I moved to New York City in 2003, where I’ve worked as a freelance writer for almost a decade. I’ve written for more than 100 magazines, newspapers, and websites, including the New York Times, Rolling Stone, Forbes, Jay-z’s Life and Times, Vibe, Automobile Magazine, AutoWeek and the Detroit Free Press. I finished an MFA in creative writing at the New School this year. I live with two car buffs, Lee Quiñones and our four-year-old son, who both think what I do is pretty cool.

pageElements.text: As soon as I arrived in Portland, Oregon, for the third annual Heels and Wheels event, I jumped in a car and headed southeast. Cold rain obscured my view of Mount Hood from the windshield of the Aston Martin DB9. I wondered if the foul weather was going to put a damper on the event that brings together thirty women in the automotive industry to focus on car coverage for and by women. For the record, I was impressed with the way the DB9 handled the wet roads, although I confess that my knuckles were pale from gripping the wheel through the sharp bends. But suddenly, the landscape shifted dramatically, and I was cruising along smooth, dry roads in the Oregon desert, dotted by a backdrop of snow-capped mountains. At last, the accelerator and I were one as the driving euphoria kicked in, the scenery vast in the foreground. A caravan of women followed me onto the road, and suddenly I knew that Heels and Wheels was going to be fun.

I pulled into a rest stop tucked within the boundaries of the Warm Springs Indian Reservation off U.S. 26. A man emerged from the rolling stream in waders, fishing pole in hand. We had officially left the city and found our way back to nature. I switched to my next ride, a Mazda 6 sedan, and sped along to my destination in central Oregon, passing by wild horses galloping out yonder. When I arrived at the Brasada Ranch, about twenty minutes from small-town civilization in Bend, I found myself nestled in some kind of wild western paradise. It felt like the right kind of environment for the ladies to kick up their heels.

The setting of Heels and Wheels set the tone of the conversations that occurred over three whirlwind days. We take it for granted that women have been writing about cars for some time now, best embodied by the careers of hall-of-famer Denise McCluggage and one woman who is the editor in chief of an influential automotive magazine and who shapes and defines the way men and women learn about, discover, and see cars. (We see you, Jean.)

Yet, the idea that women read car magazines is still hard to sell to the mainstream. The idea of how to talk about women and cars is still being debated by marketers and car dealers on a daily basis. Yes, we women make most of the decisions about car ownership, but how do we expand the conversation? That’s where programs like Heels and Wheels become important. The auto industry is still overwhelmingly a boys’ club, and far too few women are a part of this conversation. It certainly doesn’t hurt to gather and discuss what car journalism for women means in the era of blogging and social media, and how the playing field is changing as the world around us does, too. Our media niches define us as consumers, whether we read mom blogs or hunt obsessively for automotive deals online. Sometimes our audiences don’t overlap, but often our intentions do. These themes came up in both formal and informal conversation at Brasada Ranch.

Also, as women know, an all-ladies trip is fun. Take women away from their busy lives and give them some open road and the chance to speak freely, and the soundtrack soon turns to laughter. The event organizer, Heels and Wheels CEO Christine Overstreet, opted to make the gathering more experiential than business specific. This format allowed for attendees to focus on their cars of choice. Overstreet invited presenters from AutoPacific, Kelley Blue Book, Jeep, and Cooper Tire to talk about ideas specific to the women’s market. Some of the information was familiar, but I picked up tidbits that were news to me. For instance, did you know that more women than men are licensed to drive (a fun fact presented by the representative from Cooper Tire)? Female representatives from Aston Martin, Buick, Hyundai, Jeep, Kia, Mazda, Mitsubishi, and Volkswagen were in attendance to answer questions about the vehicles available for test drive and to contribute to the conversation. Jeep sent Chris Barman, vehicle line executive for Chrysler’s C and D segments, to talk about the 2014 Jeep Cherokee. She provided detailed explanations on matters of technology and interior options.

For many of the bloggers in attendance, Heels and Wheels was their first chance to test out the new vehicles. The car candy available for testing included a Jeep Grand Cherokee, a Volkswagen Jetta Hybrid, a Mini Roadster, a Hyundai Santa Fe, a Mitsubishi Outlander, a Kia Cadenza, and a Dodge Dart GT, in addition to the DB9, the Mazda 6, and the Cherokee.

After lunch on the second day of the program, Hyundai brought ultramarathon runner Jenn Shelton to speak to the group about her adventures and quests to push her body and mind to the limit. In a rare moment of stillness, the women listened to Shelton read from her memoir. Then it was back out to the expansive desert landscape for more driving, where, under a bright blue sky, everything felt possible.

pageElements.text: Are you thinking of buying a brand-new Mercedes-Benz but are worried that your expensive luxury car just won’t be eye-catching enough? It’s a fair concern. Mercedes-Benz is very good at building capable, attractive, luxurious cars, but they do tend more toward understated elegance than flashy excess. You worked hard for that car, though. Why not brag a little?

For the less discreet Mercedes owner, the company now offers an Illuminated Star accessory, which is just what it sounds like. The add-on turns the bold Mercedes-Benz sport grille, featuring a large three-pointed star, into an LED-laden, light-up announcement of your taste in cars.

The carmaker’s website describes the illuminated star as “subtle” and “sophisticated.” Those aren’t the first adjectives that jumped to my mind, but we can at least all agree that this accessory is subtler and more sophisticated than, say, a Lamborghini Gallardo. See it here.

Adding this piece of bling to your Mercedes will run you $480. It is available for installation on model year 2006 and newer CLS coupes and 2014 or newer E-Class, 2013 or newer GL-Class, and 2012 or newer M-Class vehicles. Leased cars, too! Mercedes says the light-up star will come to even more models in the future.

Fortunately or unfortunately, U.S. government lighting regulations say the star can’t light up while you’re driving, so it’ll only shine when the car is parked and unlocked for forty seconds or for five seconds after a door is opened. Still plenty of time to make sure everyone knows you’re riding in the lap of luxury.

title: WreckCheck Smartphone App
subTitle: From the insurance industry to you!
promoTeaserSmall: This is what we call planning ahead: a smartphone app that keeps you ready to file accident reports.
promoTeaser: This is what we call planning ahead: a smartphone app that keeps you ready to file accident reports.
metaTitle: WreckCheck Smartphone App - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: WreckCheck Smartphone App is a post-crash tool for documenting and reporting accident information. It's from a national insurance industry organization. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: The National Association of Insurance Commissioners (NAIC) doesn’t sound like a group that would do anything warm and fuzzy for the average citizen. After all, the Gallup polls of the most and least trusted professions put insurance salespeople somewhere between lawyers and senators. But let’s set all that aside for a minute and look at this great app NAIC has just come out with!

Its name, WreckCheck, reveals all. The app lets you begin to document an accident and start filing an insurance claim on your phone. You can even send in the documentation to your insurance company via e-mail. If you’ve ever spent time milling around at the roadside, unable to do anything about the accident that has just happened, and then followed it up with hours in an insurance office cubicle watching someone s-l-o-w-l-y fill out paperwork, you will appreciate WreckCheck.

Simply click through to complete the checklist of questions provided on the app: Time and place? What happened? What vehicles, people, and police are involved?  You can also take photos and recordings inside the app that attach to the report. There’s even a Call 911 link that you just have to press—perfect for those rattled moments right after impact.

Enter Information Ahead of Time

The MyInfo tab is a place to enter your vehicle information, license plate number, VIN, insurance company and agent name, policy number, and contact information. That way, you can show the details (or send a screen shot via text) to the other parties to an accident without fishing through your glove box for it. Even if there is no other vehicle involved (such as in a car-deer incident), it's a good place to store all the numbers in one place for your own use.

WreckCheck goes beyond being a simple form filler to offer helpful advice. “Stay Calm. Call an ambulance if needed. ALWAYS call the police….STAY COURTEOUS. DO NOT ADMIT FAULT.” Music to the ears of your agent, while it calms you down at the same time.
The WreckCheck app is free and available through the App Store for iPhones or Google Play for Android phones.

I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: The Ford F-150 is one of the bestselling vehicles in the United States, so any time Ford announces changes to its star pickup, it’s big news. Yesterday, Ford’s big F-150 news came in a smaller than usual package when the company announced it's bringing out an F-150 Tremor, the first sport truck to use Ford’s V-6 EcoBoost engine.

The Tremor will feature a regular cab, a short bed, "stealthy" black accents, sporty body-side graphics, and twenty-inch flat black wheels. Ford is billing the vehicle as a performance truck. It offers V-8-style power from the 365-horsepower turbocharged V-6, along with a rear axle optimized to help the F-150 Tremor accelerate quickly. With the EcoBoost engine, the Tremor is expected to yield fuel economy of 16 mpg city and 22 mpg highway, and it will run on regular gasoline.

The F-150 Tremor will come with some unique design features, like bucket seats, a flow-through console, and a floor-mounted shifter. The interior style follows the sporty exterior: you'll find red stitching on the steering wheel, brushed metal accents, and leather-trimmed seats with colored piping and Alcantara inserts. Infotainment needs will be met by the MyFord Touch system. As in other Ford trucks, there are added buttons in the center console so that drivers who are wearing work gloves can still change the radio station.
No word yet on pricing for the F-150 Tremor, which will hit dealer lots this fall.
