contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text:
The Car:

Price: $66,290 (sedan) and $69,230 (wagon) as tested (including destination charge)
Engine: 3.5-liter direct injection V-6, 302 horsepower
Transmission: Seven-speed automatic with shift paddles
Fuel economy: 20 mpg city/29 mpg highway (sedan); 19/26 mpg (wagon)
My favorite standard feature: Attention Assist—monitors the driver for fatigue
Option I can’t live without: Lane Tracking package—includes blind spot assist and lane keeping assist ($875)
You might also be considering: Audi A6, BMW 5-series, Infiniti M, Lexus GS
See more specs on E-Class models in our Car Guide.

What I Think:

I have owned a range of vehicles, but my favorite by far was a 2001 Mercedes-Benz E-Class wagon. In 2010, my husband and I drove it around Lake Superior on a camping trip with two other adults and a dog. We were stuffed in like sardines, and when we returned home, I demanded that we buy a bigger vehicle before I would go on another driving vacation. So we did, and I have regretted that decision every day since.

When Mercedes invited Jean Knows Cars to drive the 2014 E-Class sedan and wagon, I jumped at the chance. The E-Class has received extensive updates, both on the inside and the outside, but most notably in their assistance systems. They shared with us a PowerPoint presentation that highlighted the new standard technologies, such as a collision prevention system that actually senses impending accidents from both the front and rear and prepares the interior of the vehicle for impact. I immediately thought, “How could I not buy this car to protect my daughter?” I could cash in her college fund and pay for the E-Class in cash—she wouldn’t have a college degree, but she could live in this car and be safe.

I drove the E350 4Matic sedan with a 3.5-liter V-6 engine. It has a combined fuel economy of 24 mpg and requires premium fuel or E85—however, be aware that using E85 will lower your fuel economy by as much as thirty percent. I remember cringing every time I filled my tank during the halcyon days of owning my E-Class. However, there is good news on the fuel efficiency front for the E-Class: the 2014 models will also be available in diesel (E250 BlueTec) and hybrid (E400) form.

The E-class is offered in two distinct versions. The sport model’s badge is integrated into the grille and is nearly the size of my head, while the luxury model’s badge is the distinctive hood-mounted version. The bumper design is new and has a chrome-colored edge that seems to scream, “I will need to be replaced multiple times.” Both versions have beautiful new five-spoke wheels and LED headlights and taillights. They generally have a much more aggressive stance than the 2013 models.

Obviously, much has changed in the twelve years since my E-Class was born. But the 2014 has not forgotten its heritage. The far back seat of the wagon remains the same, with the addition of squared-off chrome handles that reveal the hidden seat; the middle seat has the same basic feel. As the driver, I felt like I was coming home. The instrument panel was the same but with modern materials and a much sleeker appearance. The steering wheel in both the sport and luxury models has been redesigned and has the flat bottom that gives the driver a smidge more legroom, and it looks great. There is a keypad integrated into the instrument panel that seems outdated. I wonder how safe it is to take your eyes off the road long enough to actually dial the phone with those small buttons that are almost out of reach?

Enough already; let’s talk about how it drives. In a word, it drives like buttah. The entire time I drove this beauty, I was grinning. The route we took highlighted why the Mercedes-Benz holds the number-one slot among luxury brands in R.L. Polk's 2012 brand loyalty study. Our drive took us on a surprisingly twisty route for southeastern Michigan. The lane keeping assist would vibrate the steering wheel whenever I would wander slightly out of my lane. Note to self: this car would keep an eye on my daughter when she is out of my sight.

The seven-speed automatic transmission with shift paddles made the drive even more enjoyable and allowed me to experiment with the paddles to eke even more power out of the engine. If you love to drive a manual but would like the luxury of not having to apply the clutch, paddle shifters are fantastic. And just in case you weren’t aware, 4Matic means all-wheel drive. Yankees, take note: this is a great winter driver.

Mercedes had cleverly driven us through about a two-mile patch of the worst road you have ever experienced, and then we came upon a road crew that was actually repaving the road. Mercedes claimed this was a happy accident. Although it was noticeable when the surface changed, it also highlighted the smooth ride regardless of the road surface, which is a real plus on Michigan’s pothole-riddled roads. The steering felt sporty and responsive and allowed me to really enjoy driving.

Two weeks after I drove the sedan, Mercedes dropped off a wagon version for our whole staff to test. My drive was much shorter and not over the same twisty roads, but the wagon was fun to drive and made me long for one to have at home in my driveway again. It felt a little heavier and was not quite as fun to drive as the sedan, but that could be due to the difference in the roads we drove on more than the vehicle itself. If I were in the market for a wagon, this would be the one.

The Verdict:

Obviously, I have a sweet spot for the E-Class, but it would be difficult to match the sporty yet luxurious ride with the available safety upgrades in another marque. Its competitors all have a lower base price, but only the A6 offers a diesel engine.

If I already owned an SUV, I would go for the sedan version of the E-Class. Otherwise, I would probably look at the wagon for its cargo-carrying ability. If you are in the market for a mid-size luxury sedan or wagon, then this is a vehicle you should consider.

Peanut Gallery:

Note: the Peanut Gallery had a go with the wagon, so we speak to that version only.

Annie: I'm a big fan of the E-Class's 2014 redesign, and I found the wagon to have just the right mix of power and comfort. But I can't quite stomach the nearly $70,000 asking price, especially when I imagine hypothetical children grinding Cheerios crumbs into all that beautiful leather.

Laura: The E-Class wagon is an old-money car. You would buy this to keep it twenty years. You'd be right at home driving it to the Philadelphia International Flower Show, or along Seventeen-Mile Drive at Pebble Beach, or just enjoying negotiating the curves on the way to your weekend place. It's not ostentatious, not trying too hard, just perfect. If you aren't old money, well, you've got to start building the image with something. How about with this?

Jean: An E-Class wagon? Always a classic, and I've loved them since the first one I ever drove: to the 1981 Daytona 500 with my first husband. I met Miss Linda Vaughn there, and we became fast friends. My husband lost control of his cigarette and burned a hole in the seat. Before I gave it back, I ran it through a car wash to make up for the burn, and it emerged clean, but without its three-pointed star hood ornament. Horror!
I've driven the old 500E Hammer wagon, and the new modern version at the Abu Dhabi Formula 1 circuit, Yas Marina. There continues to be nothing like one. I'd buy one in a heartbeat.

title: Minivan Buyer's Guide
subTitle: Get one of these while you still can
promoTeaserSmall: Feeling reluctantly practical? A chauffeur of many kids? Join me in shopping the classic minivan.
promoTeaser: Feeling reluctantly practical? A chauffeur of many kids? Join me in shopping the classic minivan.
metaTitle: Minivan Buyer's Guide - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Minivan Buyer's Guide tells you about all the true minivans on the market and what I like best about each. Read it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Talk about your culturally loaded terms. “Minivan” is right up there, dividing families, causing people to apologize or self-deprecate while they drive. Not me. I proudly stand behind the big-box transporters and tell the world that I love minivans.

I don’t just love them because I have a family of six, and we need the space. I don’t just love them because I happen to fit the demographic of the Earth Mother/field trip driver. I love minivans because they are truly a living room on wheels, able to give each passenger his or her own personal space, able to carry it all and still, with their front-wheel-drive setup and great visibility, feel like you’re driving a car. They’re not the sportiest or most fun to drive. Hey, as I say to those who ride in my second and third seats, life isn’t always just about fun.
And then I laugh maniacally, and it turns out that life is about fun after all.

Whether you are a minivan partisan or a reluctant convert, here is your rundown on all the current minivans that fit the strict definition of the category. They seat seven with three rows of seats; the seats reconfigure easily for various uses; they’re more or less refrigerator shaped. There are fewer than there used to be. Having said that, this is a collection of time-tested, tried and true vehicles. Their makers have been at it a while and know how to make what you want and need.

But we may be at a crossroads here—and I am talking to you other minivan fans out there who gave the rolling rectangles the best years of your lives. Rumor has it that the some of these minivans may be coming to the end of their life spans. There are rumors about Chrysler moving on to a more crossover-like vehicle and the Sedona going away altogether soon. None of that is happening for 2014, but we're just saying: grab on to the tail end of a legend, and enjoy these true minivans while they last.

2013 Chrysler Town & Country

Feel like Patrician Mom carrying a full set of Honor Roll bumper stickers in your designer handbag

This is probably the one you think of when you think “minivan.” Now in its fifth generation, its history goes back to the late 1980s when it rolled out as the luxury version of the Dodge Caravan and Plymouth Voyager.  It’s still the top-end Chrysler, with items such as rain-sensing wipers, Nappa leather, and a heated steering wheel that you normally find on luxury cars. You’ll see lots of these minivans lined up at the swim club and the local private schools. Sadly, it no longer comes with those fake-woodgrain sides. They’d look nice and retro now.

Base prices: $31,525 (Touring), $32,990 (S), $34,525 (Touring-L), $41,740 (Limited)
Engine: 3.6-liter 24-valve V-6, 283 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 17 mpg city/25 mpg highway
Safety: Seven airbags, SafetyTec package ($1,695 on Touring and S, standard on Touring-L and Limited; includes blind spot monitoring, rear park assist), backup camera
Accolades: 2013 IIHS Top Safety Pick, 2013 Detroit News Readers’ Choice Awards Best Family Hauler, top-ranking minivan in 2013 J.D. Power Initial Quality Study
My favorite standard features: Backup camera, Stow ‘n Go easy-flip-down seating (as shown at left), three-zone climate control, four rear storage bins, second-row video screens with DVD player (standard on the Touring and Touring-L models)
Options you should be sure to get: Navigation for the standard touchscreen media center ($895 on S, $995 on Touring and Touring-L, standard on Limited), blind spot monitoring ($1,695 in the SafetyTec package on Touring and S models, standard on Touring-L and Limited), heated second-row seats to lull your little guys to sleep ($430 in Driver Convenience Group package on Touring-L, standard on Limited)
How much space? 143.8 cubic feet maximum; 33.0 cubic feet behind the third row of seats

2013 Dodge Grand Caravan

Your ride if you’re saving up for college…or a trip around the world

Budget-conscious parents can choose this version of the Chrysler minivan, which starts way down in economy-car price territory and tops out where the Town & Country begins. Despite its rational price structure, the Grand Caravan is available with lots of the same features as the Town & Country, such as park assist, rain-sensing wipers, and heated front and second-row seats, if you’re willing to pay the option prices. It’s worth doing the math in detail, since many options on the lower-end Grand Caravan models become standard on the higher trim levels. Down at the base American Value Package end of the lineup, there are old-school manual sliding doors. Hey, don’t complain! I remember the days when minivans only had one manual sliding door, and I drove them five miles in the snow, uphill both ways…

Base prices: $20,990 (American Value Package, or AVP), $24,190 (SE), $27,690 (SXT), $29,790 (Crew), $30,990 (R/T)
Engine: 3.6-liter 24-valve V-6, 283 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 17 mpg city/25 mpg highway
Safety: Seven airbags, Safety Sphere package ($1,400 on Crew and R/T; includes blind spot monitoring, front and rear park assist), backup camera (SXT)
Accolades: 2013 IIHS Top Safety Pick
My favorite standard features: Stow ‘n Go easy flip-down seating (on all but AVP model), dual glove box, dual power sliding doors (only on SXT, Crew, and R/T)
Options you should be sure to get: Second- and third-row video screens with BluRay/DVD player (shown at left; $2,490 on ST, Crew, and R/T), or economize with second-row-only video and DVD ($1,495 on SXT, Crew, and R/T), UConnect hands-free package ($590 on AVP, $194 on SE and SXT, standard on Crew and R/T)
How much space? 143.8 cubic feet maximum; 33.0 cubic feet behind the third row of seats

2014 Honda Odyssey

So nice! And so many of them everywhere you look!

The first Honda Odyssey seen in the U.S. market was more like a tall wagon, and it didn’t pose much of a threat to the dominant Chrysler minivans. The current full-boat Odyssey came out in 1998, a little late to the U.S. minivan party, but it has become ubiquitous since then. If you don’t believe that, go look in the parking lot of any preschool or any middle-school sporting event. It is also available as an eight-passenger vehicle if you get a second-row bench seat. Only the Toyota Sienna can say the same. With a slick exterior, a high level of interior amenities, and the Cult of Honda hanging over it, it’s the go-to minivan choice for the same people who would only look at Honda sedans. The 2014 Odyssey will be in dealerships on July 2.

New for 2014: Standard Bluetooth HandsFreeLink, Pandora interface, SMS text messaging, and four-way power passenger’s seat; every Odyssey also gets a six-speed automatic transmission
Base prices: $29,655 (LX), $32,955 (EX), $36,455 (EX-L), $38,055(EX-L RES), $38,455 (EX-L Navi), $42,710 (Touring), $45,280 (Touring Elite)
Engine: 3.5-liter 24-valve SOHC i-VTEC V-6, 248 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 19 mpg city/28 mpg highway

Safety: Six airbags, rear-view camera, active head restraints, electronic brake-force distribution, vehicle stability assist with traction control, Lane Watch blind spot display (EX models and up), forward collision warning and lane departure warning (EX-L, EX-L RES and up)
Accolades: 2013 IIHS Top Safety Pick, 2013 U.S. News & World Report Best Minivan for Families
My favorite standard features: One-motion folding third-row “magic” seat (Touring and Touring Elite models also have folding center armrest), cool box under the instrument panel that holds a six-pack of drinks (standard on EX-L, Touring, Touring Elite), Ultrawide 16.2-inch rear entertainment system with a split screen (on Touring Elite only), removable center console with (get this!) a flip-up trash bag ring (shown at left; EX models and up), multifunction second-row seat that slides up so the front passenger can reach back to the child safety seat installed on it (EX models and up)

Options you should be sure to get: What you need to do with the Odyssey is move up to a higher trim level to get the best goodies, such as: push-button start (EX and up); multi-angle rear-view camera (EX-L Navi, Touring, and up); and that already iconic on-board vacuum (standard on Touring Elite only)
How much space? (2013 model) 148.5 cubic feet maximum; 38.4 cubic feet behind the third row of seats

2014 Kia Sedona

Plain vanilla, but sometimes vanilla is a good flavor

The pundits declared the Sedona dead, but it’s got a pulse, after its own fashion. The 2014 Kia Sedona is available already because the Korean automaker took 2013 off and didn’t make a Sedona last year. Its pricing is up from the structure of past model years, but it’s still competitively reasonable. However, the looks are not; this might win the crown for least interesting design. Those of you who want a non-tarted-up, basic minivan that gets you there and fits everyone and everything, here you go. I have to admit that I like knowing it’s still out there.

Base prices: $26,750 (LX), $31,650 (EX)
Engine: 3.5-liter V-6, 269 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 17 mpg city/24 mpg highway
Safety: Six airbags, backup warning system, auto-dimming mirror with backup display (part of $1,900 Power package for LX, standard on EX)
My favorite standard features: Backup warning sensor that beeps when you get too close to an object, front-row extendable side table, LED running lights (new for 2014)
Options you should be sure to get: Dual power sliding doors (part of $1,900 Power package for LX, standard on EX)
How much space? 141.5 cubic feet maximum; 32.2 cubic feet behind the third row of seats

2013 Nissan Quest

Your kids might feel slightly less embarrassed to be seen with you. Or, depending on their design sensibilities, slightly more

Nissan is trying really, really hard to make its minivan look unlike a minivan. Give it up; it’s a minivan, folks. On the plus side, the Quest has lots and lots of glass, which shows that Nissan takes people seriously when they say they want good visibility in a minivan. Which is what every minivan owner I know says they want. The back-seat passengers will appreciate optional dual opening glass moonroofs (below left) and second-row power windows, because in most minivans they get little to no fresh air back there. They’ll also like the fact that the second and third rows raise gradually like theater seats. Clean-air types will enjoy the Advanced Climate Control System with a grape polyphenol filter and a purifier, meant to cut down on allergens in the cabin. My standards must be low, but this wouldn’t be a deal maker for me. Then again, it probably would be for anybody dealing with allergies in their families. It’s on the LE model.

Base prices: $26,835 (S), $30,585 (SV), $34,365 (SL), $43,485 (LE)
Engine: 3.5-liter 24-valve V-6, 260 horsepower
Transmission: Continuously variable
Fuel economy: 19 mpg city/25 mpg highway
Safety: Six airbags, rear-view monitor, blind spot warning, Around View monitor (LE only)
My favorite standard features: Second-row power windows will be a hit with kids, especially on long rides; tire pressure monitor with an Easy-Fill alert that tells you when you’ve hit proper tire inflation; power rear liftgate (standard on SL and LE)
Options you should be sure to get: DVD entertainment system (optional on SV and SL, standard on LE) and eleven-inch color monitor; manual blinds for the second and third row (LE)
How much space? 108.4 cubic feet maximum; 37.1 cubic feet behind the third row of seats

2013 Toyota Sienna

So many versions, choices, price points, there’s got to be one of these for everybody

The Sienna comes in front- or all-wheel-drive versions. That’s a big differentiator between it and its competitor. Another is the availability of a “sporty” SE model with side skirting, nineteen-inch alloy wheels, a lower stance with a sport-tuned suspension, and smoked taillights. And yet another is that you can configure the Sienna as an eight-passenger vehicle by having a second-row bench seat (the Odyssey has this, too, but the others don’t). From under $28,000 for the base model all the way up above $40,000 for the Limited, if you have any desire for a minivan, you should be able to configure one of these to suit you.

Base prices: $27,430 (L), $30,980 (LE), $34,570 (SE), $34,355 (XLE), $40,950 (Limited)
Engine: 3.5-liter 24-valve V-6, 266 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 18 mpg city/25 mpg highway (FWD); 16/23 mpg (AWD)
Safety: Seven airbags; Star Safety System, which includes electronic brake-force distribution, brake assist, vehicle stability control, traction control; rear parking assist (front and rear on Limited model), blind spot monitor with cross-traffic alert (on XLE and Limited)
Accolades: 2013 IIHS Top Safety Pick; 2013 IntelliChoice awards for Best Overall Value of the Year, Highest Retained Value in Its Class, and Lowest Maintenance Costs
My favorite standard features: Tip Up and Long Slide second-row seats that move to suit your cargo- or people-carrying needs; three-zone automatic climate control, rear sunshades, multi-information display with backup camera (all three are standard on LE and up)
Options you should be sure to get: Ten-speaker premium JBL sound system with voice-activated navigation (on XLE), rear-seat Dual View Entertainment system with split 16.4-inch screens, independently powered dual sliding moonroofs (included on Limited)
How much space? 150.0 cubic feet maximum; 39.1 cubic feet behind the third row of seats

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

I thought you’d like to see my new girlfriends again, the G-7 consumer panel who won our contest (in which they had to pay for everything themselves) to join me at the Detroit Auto Show last January. Four of our seven fab friends jumped at my offer to fly them back in to test cars in The Driveway, the very same driveway that old Louie wishes I would pave all the way down the lane to ease her old paws.  (The other three had unavoidable conflicts. Next time!)

Anna Eby came from Texas, Val Luepke blew in from Minnesota, and two of the original Michigander panelists—Dolly Tittle and Jacqueline Dufek—welcomed three local friends of JKC, Janet Popper, Terri Barker, and Heather Sager, to test some of the hottest crossover vehicles on the market. I expected a day of friendly disagreements, budding friendships, and unladylike behavior. The tone was set by senior editor Molly Jean, who chauffeured the G-7 around all weekend in a party van, the fifteen-passenger Mercedes-Benz Sprinter, with irrepressible good humor.

Then it was time to drive. The Group of Seven spans a variety of ages and lifestyles, from young and entry-level buyers through parents of small children to the middle-aged and empty nesters. Our plan was to try out the Ford Escape, the Honda CR-V, the Kia Sportage, and the Buick Encore from a consumer’s point of view. We spent a long day taking turns driving them around the country roads and on the interstate, loading up the vehicles with typical family gear, and scrutinizing window stickers.
The women got to know the four crossovers inside and out, checking everything from highway acceleration to cabin amenities, along with ride and handling and, of course, price.
And, of course, they had very strong opinions. Watch the video to see what they thought of the cars.

It was never our intention to pick a winner—instead, we had a great time talking about the pros and cons of each of these crossovers. I hope it helps you get to know the four vehicles and the seven members of our G-7 a little better. More adventures are being planned as we speak. Stay tuned.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

metaTitle: Group of Seven: Janet Popper - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Meet Janet Popper, a member of the Jean Knows Cars Group of Seven reader panel, and read some of her thoughts on life with cars. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Janet, 61, lives in Ann Arbor, Michigan, where she is a retired elementary school teacher. Her car is a 2002 Volvo S60 in “mint condition.” Her family also owns a 2013 Volvo XC60. Her dream car is a Volvo C70 convertible.

She has a master’s degree in social work from the University of Michigan in addition to her education degree. Her family includes her husband, Steven, a pediatrician, and three daughters, 38, 25, and 21. Janet plays tennis and has just started playing golf. She’s also learning to speak Italian. She says what she likes to do most is “hang out at my lake house on Lake Michigan and kayak and bike and entertain my friends in the kitchen.”
We asked for her thoughts on auto-related issues:

Distracted Driving/Texting while Driving: “I’m afraid all the time that somebody’s going to cross the line when they are texting. It frightens me. I do not text while driving. With my kids, I’m worried about them looking at their phones. I lost a friend of mine who was killed by a twenty-one-year-old girl who was texting behind the wheel on U.S. 23. The problem of distracted driving is very real for me.

“In some ways, I blame the cars, not just the drivers. There are so many buttons. The radio is different. Sometimes I haven’t touched any buttons, and the mirrors start moving. The cars have gotten more complex, and that’s very distracting to me. I said to my husband, ‘They need a step-down vehicle for older people!’ A car that is less complicated. There is a message flashing, ‘You have a message,’ and I’m driving! That’s not it for me. Things aren’t intuitive anymore.”

Auto Styling: “I think they all look the same–or at least, a lot look the same. There should be a distinction between brands. You should know that’s a Volvo or that’s a Ford. When I drive the XC60, I feel like I’m swimming in it. A car needs to fit me. Sometimes you get behind the wheel, and it feels like you’re wearing a dress that’s too big. I like a car that fits me. The new Honda CR-V is darling. That’s where I would branch away from my Volvo. I like visibility. One thing I liked about the ’02 Volvo [is that] I didn’t have clear vision with the headrests, but you hit a button and they drop down. My daughter has a Honda CR-V, and visibility is good.

“Vision, fit, minimal buttons–those are all important things to me. I like a car that accelerates, too. That’s a safety feature, you know. It will get you out of trouble on the highway. I love a stick shift, but they are hard to come by!”

Gas Prices: “I just had this discussion with my husband. What can I do about it? I need gas, I get it. I could look at the high gas prices all the time and worry, but I would get my blood pressure up. It’s so out of my control, I don’t worry about it.”

Technology/Autonomous Driving: “To me, a self-driving car might be better than the way some people drive. In the past, you and the machine were working together and making it happen. I feel like I don’t know enough about this—the whole issue of self-driving cars. The thought that a person with disabilities could drive and have that freedom sounds exciting to me. But is it safe? Can a fourteen-year-old get in the car and drive it? Will it be simple? I have too many questions.”

Electric/Alt-Fuel Vehicles: “We are talking about a hybrid for one of our children. We are looking at the Toyota Prius. We talk about cars, including hybrids, a lot in my family. Should we encourage our daughter to get a fuel-efficient car, especially if the cost of gas keeps going up? We are on the fence. We’re just starting to explore it. We just don’t know. The Subaru XV Crosstrek is a possibility. Safety is one of our important factors, especially with cars for our kids.

“Electric vehicles? I remember when I was teaching third grade, they did an article about the Chevrolet Volt in Time for Kids, a Time magazine publication for kids. There was a little graph with how many trees are being saved. That’s how I found [out] about the car. I’m no dummy, but I don’t know a lot about these cars.”

metaTitle: Group of Seven: Terri Barker - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Meet Terri Barker, a member of the Jean Knows Cars Group of Seven reader panel, and read some of her thoughts on life with cars. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Terri, 50, is a native of Jackson, Michigan, and currently lives in Ann Arbor, where she works for the Institute for Higher Learning. She drives a leased 2013 Chevrolet Equinox, but her dream car is a Jeep Wrangler.
“I want one with a hard top and a soft top,” she says. “I’ve always wanted one. It fits my personality.”
Terri’s family is composed of her husband, Jeffrey, and their three dogs, Mocha, Coal (both miniature pinschers), and Jax (a chihuahua/terrier mix). When Terri isn’t working, she enjoys playing golf.
Here’s what she has to say about some important issues in the auto world:

Distracted Driving/Texting while Driving: “It’s a concern that other drivers do it, but I don’t participate in it. I don’t text while driving because I’m too old to read my phone while driving. My eyesight is too bad. Why bother? I see other drivers doing everything, but texting is the worst. I would hate to see the federal government step in and do more to us, but somebody has to do something. I would like to see cell phones disabled when the car is running so you can make incoming and outgoing phone calls, but you couldn’t read texts and e-mails or check Facebook. Build it into the car.”

Auto Styling: “It’s copy-cattish. The minute you buy it, every other manufacturer does it. I am in favor of fewer options for car buyers—every manufacturer has twelve cars right now. They should be good at two or three, and that’s what they sell. No more. That makes the cars more unique.

“But, I do like what I’m seeing now. There are attractive options on the road. Nissan’s got quite a few. Chryslers are attractive. Ford has a lot of very attractive ones. Eye-catching ones. The Fusion and Escape have taken a good turn. I like the looks of the Ford C-Max Energi. That Kia Soul—you know, the one with the hamsters—is so ugly. Don’t like the squares. I don’t like boxes. The Honda Element was ugly, too.”
Gas Prices: “Way too high. I don’t understand it. Oil companies like Exxon should not be posting their profits while we are paying $4 a gallon. It costs $60 to $70 to fill up my Equinox.”
Technology/Autonomous Vehicles: “No, never! I’m a control freak. My heart starts racing just thinking about that.”
Electric/Alt-Fuel Vehicles: “I am not willing to buy one. It’s not convenient enough for me. I’m not sure how I would charge it. It would be a hassle doing all the research on those cars.
“I’m not concerned about green issues. Why? I don’t have a good answer for it. Maybe because I’m not leaving children behind and I’m not worried about that legacy.”

metaTitle: Group of Seven: Heather Sager - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Meet Heather Sager, a member of the Jean Knows Cars Group of Seven reader panel, and read some of her thoughts on life with cars. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Heather, age 37, is a born-and-bred Ann Arbor resident. She makes her living as a salesperson for Sysco Corporation. She leases a 2012 Lexus CT200h, but her dream car is a Bugatti Veyron.
“I saw it at the auto show and went crazy for it,” she says of the Veyron.

Heather attended Eastern Michigan University and studied art appreciation and business. Her family includes her four-year-old son, Sebastian, and one dog, a Borzoi named Boris. Heather loves fashion, but also enjoys painting and making jewelry (she has a jewelry business called Mabella), listening to music, and gardening.
These are her thoughts on auto-related issues:

Distracted Driving/Texting while Driving: “This is an important issue for me because I get called while driving constantly. I have Bluetooth, but I do not text while driving. I’m not allowed (corporate regulations).

“I drive in Ann Arbor and [drivers] are crazy! They run stop signs all the time. I’m scared about bad driving. I’ve seen my kid go after a ball in the street. I’m trying to teach him not to run in the street. I’m worried that somebody might not notice him if they are texting.

“I think it’s good that the feds want to limit distractions in cars. From what I can see with myself, I’m getting e-mails in the car, and it’s hard not to look at them. The radio is on—it’s all a distraction. I’m in the car a lot, and it’s nerve-wracking. When you get an e-mail that’s cryptic, your mind goes to that. My mind can be on other things besides driving. I’m trying not to be a distracted driver, but it’s hard. I’d be lying if I said I wasn’t distracted.”

Auto Styling: “I think it’s come a long way, and it’s getting better and better. I’m only drawn to certain cars. I only like cars that are styled sleekly. A minivan has no draw for me. I’m drawn to the fashion of the car. My dad has always driven Infinitis or Lexuses, so I like a lot of foreign cars. I like a lot of the hybrids because they are smaller and fashioned sleekly. The Fords have more styling to them. I like Mini Coopers. I like small cars; I feel like they are better for the environment. The green movement is appealing to me.”

Gas Prices: “They don’t faze me that much because I have a hybrid. But I was paying $25 to fill up in October, and now I’m paying $29 to $30. I’m not as upset as other people because I don’t burn through as much gas.”

Technology/Autonomous Driving: “I think a self-driving car would concern me. I’d be e-mailing and texting, and that’s scary. I don’t know how a car could be completely in control. But maybe they’ll be safer. [The automakers] would have a big job in convincing me the cars are safe.”

Electric/Alt-Fuel Vehicles: “I love that. I think it’s amazing. I think it’s the direction that we need to go in. I’m willing. It’s something I started thinking about when I became a mom. I think about the future for my son and his generation being dependent on foreign oil. I’d be willing to pay the price for green technology. Absolutely.

“My car is not cheap to lease or buy [because it's a hybrid], but it’s better for the environment. I probably drive ten miles a day, and I wanted to go to a hatchback to have a smaller car. The cars I looked at included the Ford Fiesta hatchback. I could have leased it for $165 a month. I pay $400 a month for my Lexus because of the hybrid system. It’s a better-made car. It’s very presumptuous of me to think people with big families and one income would look at hybrids, but it’s something they should look at. It’s all about what you value.”

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text:
Did you know that you can cut your cost of ownership by thousands by making one simple move: buy a diesel-powered car or truck.
That's right! A new study by the University of Michigan Transportation Research Institute (UMTRI) shows that many diesel cars have a cheaper total cost of ownership than their gasoline counterparts, thanks to lower fuel costs and better resale values.

UMTRI’s study, released at last week’s Alternative Clean Transportation Expo in Washington, D.C., showed that diesel vehicles tended to save their owners between $2,000 and $6,000 in total ownership costs over a three-to-five-year period. The costs included in the calculation are depreciation in value, fuel costs, repairs, insurance, and maintenance costs as well as taxes and fees.

UMTRI included twelve cars in its study, ranging from Ford’s F-250 Super Duty pickup truck (right) to the Volkswagen Golf (below). In nearly every case, the diesel vehicles retained their value better than gasoline versions of the same car. Mercedes-Benz’s GL-Class diesel did particularly well, retaining its value 46 percent better than the gasoline GL over a three-year period. In fact, only four of the vehicles tested didn’t hold their value more than fifteen percent better than their gasoline counterparts.

The greater efficiency of diesel vehicles was also a major contributor to their lower overall operating costs. Despite the fact that diesel fuel is typically more expensive than gasoline, diesels are about twenty to forty percent more efficient than traditional gas engines. This means that drivers can go farther between fill-ups, negating the higher fuel cost. All twelve of the diesel vehicles tested had lower fuel costs over both three- and five-year periods.

Diesel's Comeback

More and more companies are offering diesel-burning variants of popular cars, and American automakers are finally getting in on the game. Diesel was long neglected by American buyers, but these days it looks poised for a comeback in the U.S. market, and a study like this will surely help.

Still, although UMTRI paints a rosy picture for oil burners, diesel still has a long way to go before it can claim victory in the U.S. market. In 2011, clean diesel represented just 2.7 percent of light-vehicle sales in the United States. Then there’s the fact that gasoline vehicles are closing the gap in efficiency, thanks to stricter government fuel economy requirements. On the other hand, greater proliferation of diesel vehicles could shrink the up-front premiums owners pay for those vehicles, making diesel an even smarter choice.

What do you think? Is diesel the next big thing or just a blip on the radar? And would you buy one?
Read more about diesel shopping here.

metaTitle: 2013 Honda Odyssey Touring Elite - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: 2013 Honda Odyssey Touring Elite: read our "should you buy it?" review and comments from other staffers up in the Peanut Gallery. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text:
The Car:

Price: $44,755 as tested (including destination charge)
Engine: 3.5-liter 24-valve V-6, 248 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 19 mpg city/28 mpg highway
My favorite standard features: Tilting power moonroof, ultra-wide 16.2-inch rear DVD entertainment system with wireless headsets, integrated sun shades (second and third rows on Touring and Touring Elite; second row only on EX and EX-L models)
Options I can’t live without: Blind spot information system (only on Touring Elite model)
You might also be considering: Chrysler Town & Country Limited, Nissan Quest LE, Toyota Sienna Limited
See more specs in our Car Guide.

What I Think:

Hikers have shoes with Vibram soles; rock climbers have rope and carabiners; attorneys have briefcases; and the well-equipped mom has something like this Honda Odyssey Touring Elite. With this minivan as your base of operations, there is no field trip, no trip to a travel soccer game, no weekend at the beach or commute to school for which you will be unprepared.

And that had better be the case for a vehicle that, in this top-of-the-line form, costs almost $45,000. For that kind of money, I want to feel cosseted in luxury and prepared for anything, and I had both feelings while driving the Odyssey.

You won’t be mistaken about whether you’re in a minivan or not. From the time you pull the door open, you are confronted by acres of plastic, which is only somewhat ameliorated by the leather seating. That cavernous feeling may be foreign to the person who is used to a small, sporty car, but it’s part of the roominess and versatility that a minivan is all about.

Driving it, you are also not mistaken about the size of the thing. You are driving a 4,500-pound, 16.9-foot-long van. Having said that, it accelerates nimbly, handles smoothly, and has light, intuitive steering—although almost too light for my comfort. I was driving across town in this Odyssey when a tremendous rain whipped up, flooding city streets in what was later called a once-in-fifty-year storm. The next day, the Ann Arbor News displayed photos and videos of people kayaking down side streets. I felt absolutely protected inside the Odyssey as I navigated around the city, seeking out the highest-sitting neighborhoods and avoiding the high water. The ability to calmly manage adverse conditions is a great test of any vehicle, and the Odyssey won my trust right then.

Among the can’t-live-without amenities that you’d get used to quickly are a “cool box” below the stereo controls, big enough to keep your Diet Coke and yogurt or a dozen juice boxes nice and cool while you drive; a truly tremendous number of places to plug in and charge (no more fights over the outlet up front; there are two); and the flip-up trash bag ring, solving the constant problem of a trash receptacle that doesn’t roll around on the floor of the van or get tipped over.

The second-row seats roll forward and back into place, making it easy to gain access to the third row. The center seat in that row folds down into a center console for two passengers, eliminating fights about personal space. Don’t worry, they’ll think of something else to argue about!

The Odyssey comes in LX, EX, Touring, and Touring Elite trim levels. The 2014 model has just gone on sale, with pricing for the base model only about $150 higher than its 2013 counterpart, and all models now have a six-speed automatic transmission. (For 2013, only the Touring- and Touring Elite-level Odysseys did.) The Touring Elite model I drove has several features you don’t get on the entry-level model, but the base LX’s price is a reasonable $29,655 for 2014, including destination, and you still get the capable 248-horsepower V-6 and a whole lot of great safety and convenience features.

There are several good reasons to spring for the higher-end Odyssey, though. The EX-L and Touring/Touring Elite models have the ultra-wide 16.2-inch rear DVD system, the high-end audio, that cool box up front, and, on the top Touring Elite for 2014, the awesome integrated vacuum (right) in the back. Less frivolously, they also have lane departure warning, forward collision warning, and a blind spot information system. I think a big reason to go out and buy a new car or minivan this year is that all these technologies are becoming available. There’s nothing a distracted minivan pilot needs more (besides a trip to Starbucks) than systems that help keep her as aware as possible and her passengers safer as a result.

The Verdict:

If I were shopping for a minivan right now, and price were no object, I would get one of the higher trim levels (Touring or Touring Elite) of the 2014 Odyssey without a backward glance. Then I’d enjoy finding ways to use all the seat configurations, the cup holders, the outlets, and the video capability while going on lots of long road trips in it. A minivan this versatile kind of makes you want to go out and have a bunch of kids, or start a band, or gather four or five old friends and go on a long, long drive.

Peanut Gallery:

Molly: Love the design of the center instrument panel; the angle is perfect for quick access while keeping my eyes on the road. The navigation screen's location is perfect for actually reading the screen because it is not affected by glare, but it is really far away from the driver. I also liked the "title" button that brought up song titles, but I would prefer to have the radio screen integrated with the navigation screen.

Christina: If you're going to have a minivan, this is definitely the one to have. I love the way the seats slide back and forth and fold down by just pulling a lever or a strap. You can do almost everything with one hand! The rear visibility is fantastic, and the car is spacious enough to offer you and your passengers enough room to be comfortable, but not enough to feel like you're driving a yacht down the road. This one is a winner.

Annie: I'm still a long way off from the Married With Children portion of my life, so it's hard for me to imagine a minivan as my car of choice. I wasn't a fan of the Odyssey's big, boat-like attitude, but I was duly impressed by the wide array of comfort features this top-of-the-line Odyssey offered. From a drink cooler built into the center console, to the dual-screen DVD player, to the acres and acres of space between passengers, it's easy to see why families fall for the Odyssey. Ask me again in ten years.

Scott: I took the Odyssey on a 150-mile round trip carrying my video equipment on the way there and the equipment for myself and another videographer on the way back. It was a lot of stuff. Everything fit snugly, and nothing was rolling around, yet there was still room for two passengers in the back. I have always driven Hondas and always liked them because they’re durable; you can run them into the ground. So maybe I’m biased, but I think the Odyssey is great.

Jean: I like how refined all the controls are, especially for the people in the back. I don't personally like the video screen hanging down, because I can't bend my neck back like that without getting dizzy, and tilting the seat back, although a great feature, doesn't much help. If you're looking for a minivan, this Odyssey is great, but if you think adults will be comfortable looking at the screen in the second row, guess again. The video screen would be much better just in the back of the headrest, even for a kid.

title: Thumbs Down on Texting
subTitle: Cute, ironic-cute, or a dumb idea?
promoTeaserSmall: 1, 2, 3, 4, we declare a thumb war. Nonprofit invents thumb covers to help teens not text and drive.
promoTeaser: 1, 2, 3, 4, we declare a thumb war. Nonprofit invents thumb covers to help teens not text and drive.
metaTitle: Thumbs Down on Texting while Driving - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaKeywords: Thumbs Down on Texting While Driving
metaDescription: Thumbs Down on Texting while Driving: a nonprofit organization, DoSomething.org, is offering teen drivers a free set of thumb covers, with the idea being to discourage texting while driving. Do you like this idea? Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Texting while driving is something nobody should ever, ever do. However, speaking as the mother of several teenagers, their phones are pretty much a part of their bodies, and texting is as natural to them as breathing. What’s more, they would all say the same about me and my phone.

We all know how unsafe it is, but in truth, texting in the car is more the sign of a constant habit that’s hard to break, and less a conscious decision to flout safety rules. You have to wonder, do the scary statistics and stories work about as well as the “Just Say No” abstinence campaigns?

With that in mind, the nonprofit DoSomething.org is going at teens from the ironic angle they most appreciate. With a splashy online campaign, the group is trying to make cute little knit thumb socks into a Thing.

The idea is sort of the equivalent of tying a string around your finger: you have a pair of covers for your thumbs that make it all but impossible to text. Put them on when you get behind the wheel, and you won’t forget you’re not supposed to be texting.

From now through July 19, teens can go to the Thumb Wars site and sign up to get two free pairs of thumb socks. To get them, they have to explain why they want them and what other people they’ll share them with. They’re also encouraged to send in photos of themselves and friends wearing the thumb socks. The campaign has “trying to go viral” written all over it, and best of luck, since this is a great cause.

I took a little survey about these thumb socks, asking teens and middle-aged women, the two groups you most often see texting on the road, if they’d use them in the car. It’s interesting to note that the driving-age teens mainly think they should be forcibly prevented from texting by a cutoff device or setting. Legislators, are you listening?

Rose (18): I personally would put them on because I think it's helpful to have a reminder like that. Teenagers are really impatient, so they probably would be too lazy to do it. I think you need something in the car or actually in your phone that stops you from texting and not rely on teenagers to do it themselves.
Emery (13): Adorable. I would wear them personally. Yes I would give them to other teenagers. Not sure if they would wear them or not because of their "sense of style.”
Rebekah (17): I would wear them and give them to other teenagers, but I'm not sure how responsible other teenagers would be with wearing them.

Zoie (16): It seems kind of stupid. I wouldn't wear them. I wouldn't give them to other teenagers because I think they would respond similarly. I think it should be a setting in your phone that stops you from texting.
Jonathan (15): They’re stupid. I wouldn't wear them and I wouldn't give them to other teenagers. I'm not a very responsible person.
The middle-agers had a more practical response that, in itself, shows that texting is more of a youth thing (and that older drivers definitely should not be texting in the car):
Judy: It must be ‘cause I’m so old, but I don’t text with my thumbs. These might keep me from biting my nails, though.
Julie: I don’t text with my thumbs, either. Cute gimmick, I suppose, but gloves would probably work better.
Another Julie: They would get lost in my car after being removed. No question about that!
Do you love this idea? Think the socks are cute, ironic-cute, or hideous? Would you use them?

title: 2013 Hyundai Sonata Hybrid Limited
subTitle: Should you buy this car?
promoTeaserSmall: I like its dynamic looks; driving it didn't thrill me. But what does the Peanut Gallery think?
promoTeaser: I like its dynamic looks; driving it didn't thrill me. But what does the Peanut Gallery think?
metaTitle: 2013 Hyundai Sonata Hybrid Limited - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: 2013 Hyundai Sonata Hybrid Limited: Should you buy it? Here's what we think. Read our review on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text:
The Car:

Price: $32,490 as tested (including destination charge) 
Engine: 2.4-liter DOHC four-cylinder, 159 horsepower
Electric Motor: Permanent magnet synchronous, 47 horsepower, 199 total system horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic 
Fuel economy: 36 mpg city/40 mpg highway
My favorite standard features: Heated front and rear seats, SiriusXM satellite radio (three-month trial subscription)
Option I can’t live without: Panoramic sunroof ($1,000)
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Volt, Ford Fusion Hybrid, Kia Optima Hybrid, Toyota Camry Hybrid
See more specs in our Car Guide.

What I Think:

Hybrids have come a long way since the first Honda Insight and Toyota Prius graced our shores. No longer total niche vehicles, there are now hybrid versions of everything from the Cadillac Escalade to the Porsche Panamera. If you’re looking for a green machine that falls somewhere in between a massive family hauler and a six-figure performance sedan, the Hyundai Sonata Hybrid is worth a look.

I drove a Sonata Hybrid Limited around town last week and was impressed by the sedan’s upscale leather interior and dynamic exterior styling. The seats were wide and comfortable, and there was plenty of room in the back seat for extra passengers. The optional panoramic sunroof is pricey at $1,000, but it gives the cabin a more spacious feeling.

This car’s hybrid system means that it gets stellar fuel economy ratings, especially in city driving, where it earns 36 mpg. The Sonata Hybrid can operate in electric vehicle (EV) mode for short periods at speeds of up to 75 mph. The transition is fairly smooth from EV mode (when the car is powered only by its battery) to normal driving powered by the internal combustion engine. You can feel the engine kick in if you’re paying attention, but you could easily miss it if you aren't.

The Sonata Hybrid isn’t exactly thrilling to drive, but it has enough power on tap for drama-free passing on the highway, thanks to the combined efforts of the gasoline engine and the electric motor.
 
If you want to keep tabs on how efficiently you’re driving, the driver information display can tell you how green you’re being. You can choose from several different displays, including a real-time representation of which source (engine or electric motor) is powering the wheels, a somewhat confusing eco score tally (you earn points for green driving and are rewarded when plants appear on the display), and a reading of average and immediate miles per gallon.

I mostly relied on the power distribution screen. This showed me that the Sonata was saving fuel by switching to EV mode fairly frequently during normal driving, whenever I allowed the car to coast or applied the brakes (regenerative braking technology has become de rigueur in hybrids). Around town, the car switched to battery power at stoplights and stayed in electric mode under light acceleration.

Perhaps the best news for drivers who have been worried about switching to a hybrid vehicle is Hyundai’s lifetime battery warranty, which will cover the replacement of a failed battery pack at any point in the Sonata Hybrid’s life cycle.

The Verdict:

The 2013 Hyundai Sonata Hybrid Limited gives its drivers the best part of hybrid technology—the ability to sail by gas stations—without asking them to sacrifice looks or comfort. If you're looking for an easy way to increase your range between fill-ups and can learn to work with the Sonata Hybrid's fussy information displays, this could be the car for you.

Peanut Gallery:

Laura: My comments are mainly aesthetic. On the outside, I love the sharp lines along both sides that look like you could slice a piece of cheese on them. On the inside, I don’t love the feeling of sitting down low inside a pod, exacerbated by the swooping front console. But I do appreciate that people who like this kind of car can get one as a hybrid.

Molly: As with all hybrids, the lack of sound when you start the car is disconcerting. I am constantly wondering if the car is started. The steering on the Sonata was very responsive, and the engine was surprisingly peppy, providing a fun driving experience. However, I found the ride harsh and the road noise very loud.

Christina: I wasn't too excited about hybrids until recently. I liked the idea but didn't like how they drove or how they were priced. This car made me want to buy a hybrid. You only know when you're in EV mode when you see the EV indicator light up in the information display; the shift from engine powered driving to EV mode is smooth. The price is reasonable. The interior is comfortable. This car was a pleasant surprise.
Scott: I felt like a cut in the passenger's seat because the interior looks like a giant Band-Aid…however, the drive was the Neosporin. When I got behind the wheel, I was instantly healed.

title: 2014 Fiat 500L
subTitle: A drive in Baltimore, its future port of entry
promoTeaserSmall: Design basis for the larger 500? The original 1936 Topolino, modernist architecture...and America.
promoTeaser: Design basis for the larger 500? The original 1936 Topolino, modernist architecture...and America.
metaTitle: 2014 Fiat 500L - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: The new, bigger Fiat 500 is the 2014 Fiat 500L. I drove it in Baltimore and learned about its history and design philosophy. Read the whole story at JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
Sheer serendipity.  That’s how I became a contributor to Jean Knows Cars.  Well into a lovely dinner party, I received a most unlikely suggestion:  “You should write about cars from your perspective – a 4’11” single mother with a ten-year-old minivan who drives around three overactive children and a Bernese Mountain Dog.  Theatre, swimming, hockey, lacrosse, figure skating, field hockey… You love to tell stories. Tell them about cars.”  I suggested that my background possibly lacked necessary expertise – B.A. from Duke in art history and medieval/Renaissance studies; Fellow of the American Academy in Rome; Ph.D. from the University of Michigan in medieval architecture --  nothing about cars there!  My friend persisted, “You may be an art historian, but you are also a hockey mother who can whistle like a trucker, a runner, and a lover of good food, wine and the written word.”

I pondered.  The auto industry and I did have a long, if tangential, history.  I did a stint as an executive secretary to the president of a car dealership and spent fifteen years negotiating a dual identity as an academic and as auto company spouse.  I have always suffered from car envy, particularly acutely when I lived in Europe.  (As envy and lust are amongst the seven deadly sins, I’m in trouble.) Automobiles, functional objects that often shape image, are fundamental elements of today’s society.  This would be another mode of cultural analysis and critique.  Couched in that light, it made perfect sense!

(And, I really can whistle like a trucker, but louder. I may be an art historian, but don’t sit next to me at a hockey rink.)

pageElements.text:
Looking Back and Moving Forward

I was dashing out of the building, on my way to grab an espresso before heading to the airport. Of course, it was the perfect moment to run into a friend whom I had not seen in months. We know each other from Espresso Royale, one of Ann Arbor’s longtime coffee shops, where we both used to spend endless hours writing. He was launching an online literary journal; I was working on articles about Rome. We now spend more time behind desks than at coffee shop tables. “I can’t stop,” I said. “I’m on my way to Baltimore.”
Baltimore?
“Yes, Baltimore. I’m going for the launch of the new Fiat 500L.”
Fiat 500L?
“A new Fiat. A five-door car. A bigger sibling, as it were, of the Cinquecento.” That look crossed his face. I was going to have to stop.

That look: the face softens, a slight and wistful smile develops, and the eyes become dreamily unfocused. I call it “Fiat nostalgia,” and it is usually accompanied by a tale from those magical days of being a poor graduate student in Europe.

“Ahhhh, a Fiat,” my friend said. “I once pushed a Fiat up a mountain in Greece. There were four of us, and the engine couldn’t handle us and our luggage. We took turns pushing it up the road. One would drive, and three would push. It was 1997 in a 1977 Fiat.  It was sage green…”

It sounds like a scene that could have been in Mamma Mia—four strapping graduate students pushing a 500 up mountain with the Aegean shimmering in the distance. I kept returning to that image and the issue of Fiat nostalgia in general as I flew to Baltimore. The Fiat 500 consciously tries to evoke a sense of longing for a European way of life—small, sexy cars, mountain roads, and beautiful vistas. This romantic image leaves little room for the hassles, if one cares to see them that way, inherent to that way of life—cars too small to carry more than two or three people, no place for luggage or groceries, an engine lacking power to see you over the next hill. I was curious to see how this new introduction to the Fiat lineup, the 500L, was going to attempt to maintain the ethos and history of the 500 while addressing the limitations of a three-door vehicle.

Baltimore might seem an odd place to introduce an Italian vehicle to a disparate group of writers, but the city was the port of entry for the Fiat 500 when it was first introduced to this country in 1958, as well as the port of entry for the 500L, so the locale seemed appropriate for the introduction of this new member of the Fiat brand. At dinner the first evening, I happened to sit with the lead product engineer. He quickly surmised that I was not exactly an automotive journalist of the usual sort and wouldn’t (well, couldn’t, actually) grill him on specs, torque, and suspension. My interests were in the history of the vehicle and its design—how does one maintain design continuity with a vehicle that fundamentally differs from the initial iconic product? The response: “You must meet Fabrizio.”

A couple of hours later during after-dinner drinks on the terrace, a similar conversation with another engineer: “Have you met Fabrizio?” At the bar at the Four Seasons, another Chrysler/Fiat engineer and “Let me introduce you to Fabrizio.”  This Fabrizio was quickly becoming legendary.

Fabrizio Vacca, an interior senior designer from Fiat, is a tall, lithe, dark-haired, and soft-spoken Italian, flown over from Turin for the event and for his first visit to the United States. When we finally did meet, our initial conversation was not about cars, but rather about the history of the Italian landscape. Another journalist, upon discovering that I had lived in Italy, was asking advice about his honeymoon. His touring plans were ambitious—Venice, Florence, Rome, Sicily, and Greece in two weeks leaves little time for … sleep. We turned to Fabrizio, and I was struck with the manner in which he could extol the virtues of different Italian cities with a sensitivity to language that captured their individual essence while painting a vibrant visual image. I suspected that this was a designer deeply immersed in history.

My intuition proved correct the next morning, as Fabrizio presented the trajectory that drove the design of the 500L. The marketing pitch for this car focuses on hip and urban, directed at those in their twenties and thirties with friends or young families who want the Fiat association but need more space for their way of life. The names of the different models—the Pop, the Easy, the Trekking, and the Lounge—evoke a certain joie de vivre and an active urban lifestyle. The tie to the ethos of the 500 could become tenuous if the marketing folks are not careful.

However, it is the history of the Cinquecento and of modern design that seems to have influenced the conception of this car. Acutely aware of the implications of introducing a new vehicle to the Fiat brand, Fabrizio opened his presentation with the very first Fiat 500—the Topolino (right). Produced in 1936 under the dictatorship of Benito Mussolini, the Topolino was meant to be a car for the masses and a form of affordable transportation for Il Duce’s modern industrial nation. It was, in fact, the precursor to Germany’s Volkswagen, which means “people’s car.” A term of endearment—the name Topolino means “little mouse” and is what Italians call Mickey Mouse—the name was meant to evoke association with the advanced modern society of America and the American way of living.

In an interesting turn, the American way of living is also the basis for the articulation of the 500L. Spatial considerations, not hard edges, shaped the outlines of the vehicle. Such an approach toward space and design drove the design of the Italian palazzo and villa for centuries—utilitarian spaces on the ground floor; spaces for living and socializing on what is called the piano nobile, the broad and spacious first floor; and then more utilitarian spaces above on the second floor. The Italian palazzo essentially evolved from the inside out, and so, too, did the design of the 500L.

Recognizing that the car is a space for more than driving, the designers began with consideration of the interior spatial activities: how does one use the inside of the car? How does the interior space relate to and reflect lifestyle? These are distinctly Italian questions. There, the car is not just a means of transportation but also is often considered an additional room and exterior space to the house. Indeed, the inspiration for the spatial organization of the 500L was not a past vehicle, but the modernist iconic interpretation of the Italian palazzo/villa design, Le Corbusier’s Villa Savoye. Built in 1928 in France, the Villa Savoye sought to reduce the villa design to its fundamental elements and translate that expression with the most modern of materials. The emphasis focuses on the piano nobile and articulates that space of living with steel and glass, the modern materials allowing a panoramic view that takes in the countryside around it.

When Fabrizio put up the slide of the Villa Savoye, the overall design of the 500L suddenly made sense. While the slightly quirky and bulbous exterior of the 500L pays homage to the exterior lines of the Topolino, the interior draws directly from the history of modernist architecture. The frame alludes to the steel structure, and the rest is filled with windows. Their glass wraps the car, providing an exceptional panoramic view that mimics the living spaces of the Villa Savoye.

How does the thought given to design translate into the driving experience? I drove a black 500L through the streets and highways of Baltimore. The exterior takes getting used to, but, like the Cinquecento itself, its quirky lines quickly became charming in comparison with the prosaic lines of so many other vehicles on the road. The spatial effect of the interior conceptualization struck me immediately. The panoramic view opens the space and is, in fact, quite liberating. One does not feel constrained in a “small car space,” and I found my viewpoint from the driver's seat equal to the spatial experience and open field of vision one gets sitting high up in an SUV. That delighted me, as a small woman who can rarely see the hood of the car she is driving.

I was worried that the size of the gearshift, designed to maintain proportion with the voluminous interior, would be far too big for my hand, but instead it was remarkably comfortable, and I could shift with ease. Having always had five-speed manuals, the six-speed dual-clutch transmission required me to adjust my driving patterns, but I did so quickly. My driving partner and I have quite eclectic tastes in music, and the Beats audio system responded so sonorously with all genres that it made me realize that it might be the guilty pleasure in which one must indulge, particularly if we agree that the car is an extension of the house.

To continue that theme, how many of us have had to chastise a teenager for putting dirty feet on the sofa? Although it is not safe to put your feet on the dash, my dashboard is scuffed from teenage transgressions. The dash in the 500L is covered with a fabric that echoes the fabric of the seats. The fabric may be tough, but could it withstand snagging and scuffing from heels? Like the modernist aesthetic that drove the design, the interior has a crisp, clean feel. But it’s fair to say that the modernist aesthetic often ignores the realities of teenage living, and this is no different. It’s an impractical spot for fabric. Fabric in general is impractical with children, and were I to get the 500L, leather seats would be a must. These are niggling complaints, though, for what otherwise is a car that brings a certain flair and difference to this particular segment of the market.

It would seem, then, that the 500L brings the history of the Cinquecento full circle. At its price points, starting at $19,900 for the Pop and going to $24,995 for the Lounge, it is not exactly a people’s car. However, it is priced aggressively to bring in the young urban buyers looking for the ease and convenience of a small car but wanting a vehicle that sets them—and their lifestyle—apart from the usual car-buying public.

From a practical standpoint—drive, interior layout, audio systems, seating, and manipulation of space—this car works well. From a sense of style and history, it certainly distinguishes the driver from the rest of the pack. The 500L continues the entwined relationship between Italian and American culture: Italians evoking the American lifestyle and Americans evoking their own Italian associations.

But what of the Cinquecento itself? How will this bigger sibling fit in to the picture?  The year 2013 is a different time and era. I expect less tolerance in general for the romantic and nostalgic moments of a car that can’t get a group of graduate students up a mountainside, and the 500L answers that need. In terms of the bigger picture, however, the question is, have we moved forward, or is the sense of nostalgia a sense of loss of a different time and era?

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. pageElements.text: Ford is using a new tool in its battle to fight road noise, and while it’s new to the car industry, it will be familiar to watchers of TV crime dramas. Traditionally, auto companies used strategies such as filling a car with smoke and watching for leaks or circling a vehicle with a nonmedical stethoscope to pinpoint pesky air leaks. Instead, Ford is now seeking out weak spots using the same thermal imaging technology that law enforcement and military personnel use to locate criminals.

Ford is using the thermal imaging to identify places where noise or air could leak into or out of a car, leading to increased road noise during driving. In order to check for leaks, Ford pumps test vehicles full of hot air, then trains a thermal camera on them to check for so-called hot spots, areas that show up as red spots on a car’s otherwise blue-green exterior.
Areas most at risk for unwanted noise leakage are moonroofs, window glass, door trim, the trunk lid, doors, and the base of the windshield.

Once weak points have been identified, engineers can take steps to correct the problem. A Ford video shows engineers tacking pieces of padding into the insides of doorframes to better insulate the cabin.

This may seem like an extreme measure to avoid a little road noise, but interior noise levels are no laughing matter to Ford. The company has identified road noise as a key factor in a customer’s perception of quality, so creating a quiet cabin could help improve a car’s overall image. Ford says its 2013 Fusion already has a 67 percent approval rating for interior quietness, compared with 58 percent approval for the 2012 Toyota Camry. And you know that has to give the automaker a nice, warm, insulated feeling.
