pageElements.text: I’ve never smashed someone’s car window to rescue an overheated dog inside. Not that I wouldn’t; I’ve just not been in that position, thankfully. No numbers exist on the thousands of animals that suffer and die every year from being overheated inside cars parked by oblivious owners. It is truly tragic. Tragic and preventable.

I’m especially sensitive to the subject because we have especially thick-coated Chesapeake Bay retrievers, one of whom (Bob, at right) spends a lot of time at outdoor dog shows in the summer. We quickly learned how to create the best environment for Irish’s GCH Robert Garcia de Padua (short of keeping him in an air-conditioned motorhome like his better heeled competition has been seen enjoying) to endure a long day outside, waiting for his few minutes of ring glory.
First we arrive early enough to find the shadiest spot. Barring that, we create shade with a pop-up awning we erect to cover the back of the vehicle and our camping chairs.
We open all of the windows and throw a reflective mesh netting over the windshield and two front doors. This beats back the sun’s rays while allowing breezes to blow through.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/BCVh36ykv7U?list=PLDtKaZSQcnJDBKK4xQsBeRQm1nY0FMAyv" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

After an exhaustive search of portable fans, we settled on four large Ryobi fans with built-in stands and hooks that allow two of them to be hung directly on Bob’s cage. The two others are spares waiting with fresh batteries at the ready if the first fans die out. The Ryobi fan’s battery is huge and snaps directly into the back of the fan. Just to be even more anal about our precious pooch, we have a Ryobi charger that works off the car’s cigarette lighter.

The last thing is bringing a small cooler full of mostly ice, preferably made at home from the water that Bob’s delicate system is used to. He drinks directly from the cooler, the same way most dogs drink directly from the toilet. So, of COURSE we put his name on it in indelible ink. (This is Bob's friend Bizee at right.)

Seriously, though, think twice before you “just run in the dry cleaner for a second” and leave Scruffy waiting in the car. As I say in the video, temperatures can go skyhigh in a shockingly short amount of time.
We really want to hear your tips. Please share them with us here!

pageElements.text:
The Car:

Price: $49,735 as tested (including destination charge)
Engine: 3.6-liter DOHC V-6, 321 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic 
Fuel economy: 19 mpg city/28 mpg highway
My favorite standard features: Leather seating surfaces, head-up display
Options I can’t live without: Cold Weather package, including heated front seats and heated steering wheel ($600)
You might also be considering: Audi A4, BMW 3-series, Infiniti G37, Mercedes-Benz C-Class
See more specs in our Car Guide.

What I Think:

The Cadillac ATS is an all-new model for 2013, but it’s already the best-selling car in Cadillac’s lineup (although it still trails behind the SRX crossover in overall sales). The ATS is a luxury performance sedan at heart, with standard rear-wheel drive and an available 321-horsepower V-6 engine. Cadillac is hoping that the ATS will draw new, younger buyers to the brand, which suffers from an aging demographic. I’m normally turned off by Cadillac’s boxy, angular design language, but the ATS caught my attention, so I took one for a drive to see if it would change my mind.

The ATS I tested was a Premium model, with standard leather seats, an eight-inch touchscreen with Cadillac’s CUE infotainment interface, and magnesium paddle shifters. Our test car also included a $1,050 power sunroof; the Driver Awareness package, which includes lane departure warning and front collision alert; and the $600 Cold Weather package, which gets you heated front seats and a heated steering wheel.

The ATS’s striking exterior, with its long, teardrop-shaped headlights and tight angles, is a perfect companion to the sleek, luxurious interior. The ATS is the smallest Cadillac, so it’s not exactly spacious, but it’s not unacceptably cramped, either. The ATS I tested had a Morello Red interior, a pleasant burgundy shade reminiscent of red wine, contrasted with black trim.

The standard CUE infotainment system was somewhat less pleasing. I appreciated the clear, legible display, but found the system drawing my attention away from the road for tasks as simple as changing the radio station. The physical buttons for climate and volume control weren’t as consistently responsive as one might hope. The standard head-up display, which projects vehicle speed and navigation information onto the windshield, was an interesting and helpful touch that helped make up for CUE’s shortcomings.

The 3.6-liter, 321-horsepower V-6 engine makes the ATS genuinely enjoyable to drive. Our test car’s performance suspension, brakes, and precise steering gave the car a sporty feel. The V-6 isn’t available with a manual transmission, but the automatic transmission has a manual shift mode and optional paddle shifters that can give you a measure of control over the driving experience. When shifting manually, the transmission automatically rev matches on downshifts, producing an exhaust burp that is strangely gratifying despite the risk of making other drivers roll their eyes.

The Verdict:

I’m still not totally sold on Cadillac’s design language, but I am attracted to the ATS’s dynamic exterior and slightly softer lines in spite of myself. The interior is attractive and luxurious without losing its sporty attitude. I think Cadillac has accomplished its goal of creating a car that will catch the eye of a younger buyer. To me, the V-6 engine and performance features are what make this car. I’m not sure how I would feel about the significantly less powerful 2.5-liter, 202-horsepower base engine, for instance.

Yes, $49,735 seems like a lot of money to spend on a small sedan, even one as loaded as this. But if you have the money and are looking for performance and style in a package that's not quite as predictable as, say, a BMW 3-series, this Cadillac could hit the spot.

Peanut Gallery:

Molly: My short time in the ATS was not long enough to familiarize myself with the CUE system, but it was long enough to frustrate me. I found it difficult to even turn up the volume on the stereo. I finally resorted to using the button on the steering wheel. The silver toned bars and buttons are aesthetically beautiful, but I would need much more time to really explore and understand all of the capabilities. Once I returned to the office, I found a plethora of videos that would have really helped.

Christina: The interior of this car is beautiful! I love the two-tone leather in the car and the way the cockpit wraps around the driver and the passenger. I was most excited about the head-up display; it was nice not having to look down at the speedometer all the time. The only thing that would keep me from buying this car (besides the price) is the way it rides on rough roads. Performance suspension just isn't for me.

Scott: The head-up display is awesome. I love that feature. It makes me feel like RoboCop or Terminator. For me, navigating around a city, I don’t want to be looking around at the GPS. You don’t have to tilt your head; all you have to do is glance. As for the looks and the driving experience, I felt like I was inside a delicious red velvet cake. I like that it doesn’t look or feel like a boat anymore, which is how I remember my grandfather’s Cadillacs.

Laura: I recall running down the street as a kid to marvel at a brand-new Cadillac that somebody's dad or grandpa had just brought home, and watching in fascination as gewgaws and gadgets were explained and tried out. "You just push THIS, and THIS happens!" "Wowwww!" Commercials that show the ATS performing on the mountain roads of North Africa notwithstanding, I still see Cadillacs that way: a treat somebody gets for him- or herself later in life. Nothing wrong with that. What a pleasant experience, then, to see that this ATS has an interior color scheme, instrument panel trim, and display that are just as wild and different from the routine as ever. Because we're Americans! And that's what we do. Somewhere in middle Ohio, a new ATS owner is showing it off to the neighborhood kids. I hope their mouths are dropping open. They ought to be.

Jean: If you like luxury, if you like a bit of edge and performance with your luxury, and if you like to buy American, then you should look at the ATS. The steering is a precise, finely tuned weapon, and the engine adds a little dramatic background noise. Shifts are better in manual mode, though still a tad lazy. Brakes are the best—Brembos—and the suspension damping is very refined, although it’s best at high speeds than lower. The space age interior controls, high-gloss carbon fiber trim, and iPad-like CUE navigation screen give the ATS a dash of techno that blends surprisingly well with the luxe leather. (I didn’t say I liked CUE, did I?) Altogether, it’s a cozy place to be, especially if you’re single.

pageElements.text: Ford promised to make a big splash in the hybrid market when it launched the C-Max Hybrid and C-Max Energi late last year, and now the automaker has the numbers to back up that promise. Since the C-Max went on sale last fall, it has helped Ford increase its electrified-vehicle market share to 16 percent, twelve points up from last year.

Ford is perhaps even more proud that many of those points were picked up at the expense of the Toyota Prius. Ford says that the Prius was the most popular trade-in vehicle for the C-Max and that Toyota has lost eight points of electrified vehicle market share since last year. Overall, 64 percent of C-Max buyers were "conquest" buyers, meaning their last car came from outside of Ford’s brands.

The Fuel Economy Fix

Customers are clearly buying these cars, but a point of controversy has been the claimed fuel economy. Ford has just announced that it will take steps to increase the fuel economy of its hybrid vehicles. The C-Max Hybrid's much-hyped fuel economy numbers of 47 mpg city and 47 mpg highway came under fire shortly after the car’s launch. Many owners have reported lower results and, most notably, Consumer Reports said the C-Max (above) and Fusion Hybrid (right) it tested earned overall fuel economy numbers in the high thirties.

Ford stands by the original fuel economy numbers but hopes some tweaks can push them even higher. In August, the company will make software updates available to owners of the 2013 C-Max Hybrid, 2013 Fusion Hybrid, and 2013 Lincoln MKZ Hybrid (right) that will increase the maximum pure electric speed to 85 mph from the current 62 mph. That will let drivers use electric-only mode more during highway driving.

The update will also optimize use of the cars' fuel-economy-aiding active grille shutters and the climate control system, among other things. The upgrade will be available for free to owners of the cars.

title: Datsun Is Back!
subTitle: Do you have Datsun memories? I do
promoTeaserSmall: It has been Nissan for years. Now India is getting the Datsun Go. Do you have Datsun memories? I do.
promoTeaser: It has been Nissan for years. Now India is getting the Datsun Go. Do you have Datsun memories? I do.
metaTitle: Datsun Is Back! - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Datsun Is Back! The celebrated name dates back a century but was changed to Nissan in the 1980s. Read some memories about the brand on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Datsun is back! Although not for the U.S. market. Still, we're glad to see the return of a great automotive name.

What does the name Datsun mean to you?
Maybe nothing, unless you’re a late Baby Boomer or early Gen-Xer, in which case it likely brings back a flood of memories from your teenage and early adult years. Two of the most influential cars of my twenties were Datsuns. The lame “The Name Is Nissan” campaign that pushed the name out the door in 1981 did nothing for me.

The all-new Datsun Go (above) is a sub-$7,000 hatchback that will be sold in India, Russia, and Indonesia starting early next year. It made a splashy debut on July 15 in New Delhi alongside its slogan, “the badge of the risers,” which presumably means something to prospective customers in India who are shopping for a car for the first time. The new little car is economical, simply designed, and seats five.

Sounds a lot like the B210 Honey Bee my friend owned in the 1970s. One summer evening after dinner, three of us were going west on I-94, taking the quickest route to a shopping center. I was in the back seat. My friend was minding her own business in the right lane when a semitruck driver cut right into her without signaling. I saw the giant slab sides of the truck getting closer and closer, and then bam! The tiny Datsun spun around, hit the truck again, and spun twice more, before ending up on the shoulder, facing in the right direction. Miraculously, nobody in the car was seriously injured. All that, plus (arguable) good looks and dozens of mpg!

image.caption: Datsun Li'l Hustler pickup, long-bed version

pageElements.text: The other important Datsun in my life was a truck. It was a 1979 Li'l Hustler, the dumb name of a very smart product: the small pickup, which used to be seen everywhere. It had a long wheelbase and white stripes along the sides. Brilliant red at first, after several years it had faded to a matte color like the rouge on the face of a dance-hall girl in a cowboy movie. The Datsun truck went to the dump so often, it could probably have found its way on its own. It was on the job to help tear apart and rebuild entire houses inside and out, after which it would head downtown to dinner at the Central Café with aplomb. It bit the dust after many years of loyal service, and they just don’t make something like it anymore.
Except, I guess, in India, where aspirational buyers may be about to have the same kind of memorable experience with small, can-do cars that my friends and I had all those years ago.

It may be thirty years since the U.S. has had Datsuns, but the very first one actually came out in Japan just about 100 years ago. It was named the Dat-Go. “Dat” in Japanese means “lightning fast,” but let’s not follow that idea too far down the road when looking at the new Go, shall we? The “Dat” nowadays stands for “Dream, Access, and Trust,” according to Nissan.
The new Datsun Go gets a 1.2-liter engine and a five-speed manual transmission. Although it’s not going to knock anyone out with high-tech add-ons, there is a mobile docking station for smartphones.

Nissan anticipates bringing out more models under the Datsun name, but you other nostalgic Americans shouldn’t hold your breath about getting one here. Spoiled by more modern rides, we probably wouldn’t appreciate them as much anymore, anyway.

pageElements.text: Honda was the first automaker to bring a hybrid to the United States, giving us the Insight hybrid in 1999. Since then, the company has offered a slew of hybrid vehicles and one fully electric offering, the Honda Fit EV. The newest addition to Honda’s lineup of green cars is the 2014 Accord Plug-in, on sale now in California and New York.

Like other plug-in hybrids, the Accord Plug-in aims to provide the efficiency of an electric vehicle without making you give up the convenience of a gasoline engine. The Accord Plug-in's roughly thirteen miles of electric range aren't nearly as useful as the Chevrolet Volt's thirty-eight miles of range. However, the Accord makes up for its short range with a very short charge time: Plugged into a 240-volt charger, the Accord can recoup its battery life in less than an hour. That makes recharges during shopping trips a real possibility, so those thirteen miles of range could—theoretically—be replenished multiple times per day.

How It Is to Drive

I recently drove the Accord Plug-in and was surprised at how useful I found the car's electric range. Since I have a short commute and access to a charging station at work, I could eke out twenty or more miles of zero-emissions driving in a typical day.

The Accord Plug-in has two selectable driving modes. The default mode, which I used most often, allows you to drive the car in EV mode until the battery charge is depleted and then switches to hybrid mode, in which the car operates like a normal gas/electric hybrid. If you would prefer to save your electric range (say, if you're spending two hours on the highway before you end up in a city), you can press the HV (for Hybrid Vehicle) button on the dash, and the car will maintain its battery charge until you opt to run on the battery again.

image.caption: Honda Accord Plug-in's Eco Assist feature

pageElements.text: Driving the car feels a little like a chore, but not because it's slow or unresponsive. In fact, the car has perfectly respectable acceleration, direct steering, and a fairly nimble feel on the road. But anything other than very modest acceleration causes the dashboard, usually backlit in bright green, to glow blue. It's as if the car is telling you that driving a hybrid shouldn't be fun, an idea manufacturers will have to get over if they want EVs to go mainstream.

How Much?

As we’ve come to expect for hybrid and electric vehicles, the Accord Plug-in carries a hefty price premium over its gasoline counterpart. The Plug-in starts at $40,570, compared with $34,220 for the Accord Touring model it’s based on (prices include destination). The Plug-in qualifies for up to $3,334 in federal tax credits and earns 47 mpg in the city, quite a difference from the Accord Touring’s 21 mpg, which should help ease the pain for buyers.

What won’t help? The Plug-in sacrifices a lot of trunk space to the battery pack, making it impractical for even the most modest weekend trips, and the eco-friendly fabric seats are cheesy and feel wrong in a car that tops $40,000.

The Plug-in's Future

Honda hasn't announced plans to add EVs or PHEVs to its overall vehicle lineup, though the automaker is preparing for the release of the Accord Hybrid this fall. It’s expected that the Hybrid will fall between the Touring V-6 model and the Plug-in in price. The Accord Plug-in and the Fit EV (right) are both available only to limited markets. The Plug-in is only for sale in California and New York, where emissions regulations mandate the sales of zero-emissions vehicles. The Fit EV has slightly wider availability, with cars available in Oregon and several East Coast states. The company hasn’t announced plans to expand sales beyond those markets. Honda has given the Fit EV aggressive lease pricing to encourage buyers to adopt the technology but so far hasn't reduced prices on the Accord Plug-in as a similar incentive.

Honda has said that it aims to sell 1,100 Fit EVs over two years, and the automaker has the same goal for the Accord Plug-in. So far, about 200 of the Plug-ins have been sold since they went on sale in January, according to a company spokesperson. Careful readers will notice that this puts Honda on track to sell just under 600 of the Plug-ins per year, but, of course, there’s no telling what the future may hold.

Next: Hydrogen?

Honda's next big EV project could be something completely different. The company has announced that it hopes to bring hydrogen fuel cell technology into the mainstream by 2020. To that end, Honda and General Motors are joining forces in the race to manufacture an affordable fuel cell vehicle, hoping their combined efforts will hasten the development of such a car.

title: Driving Aunt Mimi
promoTeaserSmall: 2014 Aston Martin Rapide S: fun at the track, with an irrepressible 85-year-old along for the ride.
promoTeaser: 2014 Aston Martin Rapide S: fun at the track, with an irrepressible 85-year-old along for the ride.
metaTitle: Driving Aunt Mimi - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Driving Aunt Mimi: A day at Atlanta Motorsports Park in a 2014 Aston Martin Rapide S, with my 85-year-old aunt along for the ride. Later, we configured her dream Rapide. Read about it and admire the photos on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: Holly has reported on cars, lifestyle, travel, and everything else for publications including the New York Daily News, Redbook, Elite Traveler, and Fox TV. She lives in New York City with her family, including Jack, a toy poodle (and test driving partner!).

pageElements.text: When I asked Mimi, my eighty-five-year-old aunt, if she would like to join me at the Atlanta Motorsports Park and take a ride in the 2014 Aston Martin Rapide S, she didn’t hesitate. “You bet!” she exclaimed. “I want to know what all the fuss is about those cars.”
I asked Mimi, who has a pacemaker, “Would your heart doctor say it’s OK to drive around a track?”
“As long as I don’t have to drive!” she quipped.

A little something about my animated Aunt Mimi: an Atlanta resident for more than sixty years, she is an avid tennis player, a published author, an actress (her first film role was in Driving Miss Daisy), a painter, an award-winning stone sculptor, a grandmother, and a fabulous cook! And Mimi has never been on a racetrack or driven in a car like an Aston Martin Rapide S.

Like Mimi, the 2014 Rapide S is stunning. The 100-year-old company (only fifteen years older than Mimi) has produced the most powerful four-door Aston Martin to date. The Rapide S has a 6.0-liter V-12 engine that makes 550 horsepower and 457 pound-feet of torque. This year’s model lost 0.4 of a second to give it a 0-to-60-mph time of 4.7 seconds with a top speed of 190 mph.
When Mimi first saw the Aston Martin, profiling in front of our hotel in Atlanta, the Mandarin Oriental, she said, “I’m naming her Scheherazade.”

When I asked why, she responded, “When I picture the ballet Scheherazade, I see the dancers with seven flowing veils. The look of this car seems to flow from front to back, and the rear looks like a woman with beautiful hips…like Sophia Loren!”
Her description was spot on. The Rapide S moves with grace and dances on the pavement.

The course at Atlanta Motorsports Park—two miles long and consisting of sixteen turns—is one of the more difficult circuits I’ve encountered. My instructor, Les Goble, performance driving executive for Aston Martin, reminded me to just breathe and let it go. I did, and the experience was empowering.
When Mimi got her turn in the Volcano Red Rapide, she was glowing. As she slid down into the plush leather seat, she joked, “These cars aren’t made for old folks with bad knees.”

However, after numerous spins around the track with an Aston Martin instructor, Mimi was transformed. She removed her helmet expertly and stated, “We did a mediocre 120 mph, and it felt like we were driving on cotton batting.”
 
As she reapplied her red lipstick in the carbon fiber side mirror, she cracked: “It is such a quiet car. When you pull up in my car, it’s so noisy.” Granted, Mimi’s beloved car is a 2003 Toyota Camry, but I don’t need to comment on that.
“We did a mediocre 120 mph, and it felt like we were driving on cotton batting.” - Aunt Mimi

After a day of driving and chatting up all the male journalists, Mimi was asked by Matt Clarke, Aston Martin’s PR and brand communications manager in North America, ”If you were going to buy one of these cars, how would you want us to customize it?”
The following is what Mimi chose for her fantasy bespoke Aston Martin Rapide S.

The Exterior

Matt explained, “Aston Martin is the only manufacturer in the world that hand paints its cars.” (In fact, it puts on seven coats of paint.) Matt showed us the inside of the door, and we saw that the paint quality inside was the same as the outside. “So, Mimi, what color do you want?”

Mimi’s daughter, Jenny, and I talked her out of black. She decided to go with Goodwood Green, a classic Aston Martin color also known as British racing green, although it is not currently part of Aston Martin's exterior paint palette. Mimi also added carbon fiber trim, black tailpipes, and polished twenty-spoke alloy wheels to her dream car.

The Interior

Mimi picked Winter Wheat leather for the dash (with a darker shade of wheat closer to the windshield so that it wouldn’t reflect the sun) and Ivory for the Alcantara headliner. Matt suggested bamboo for the center stack, with darkened buttons and a smoked titanium trim. The steering wheel? Mimi chose Winter Wheat leather again. Ditto for the seats, with coarse stitching in the same color.
Matt asked, “Do you want stitching along the inside roof of the car with your initials on it?”
“No,” Mimi answered. “It would be bad for trade-in.”

The Details

The configuration of the Rapide S continued. Cooled seats with a perforated inside layer? Yes. Aston Martin wings on the headrest? Yes. Carpet color and stitching? Dark Beige with matching stitching. Rear seat entertainment? Yes. The seatbelt—Silver, Flint, or Warm Charcoal? Flint. Do you want the leather straps on the parcel shelf to be Winter Wheat?
At this point, Jenny and I were so over the beige that we tried to talk her into something sassy, like purple. Mimi stayed true to Wheat.

Last, Mimi asked for a sunroof. Matt explained that since they weren’t offered in the Rapide S, Aston Martin would have to redesign the entire car to incorporate a sunroof. She replied, “OK, I’ll live without the sunroof.”
“So, what’s the date of delivery?” Mimi inquired.
Matt replied, “We’d have to test your special paint first, so it should be about nine to twelve months.”
Not missing a beat, Mimi asked the cost. Matt answered, “The Aston Martin Rapide S starts just under $200,000. This one would run around $250,000.”
Mimi didn’t even flinch. After a day at the track, she understands what all the fuss is about.

title: 2014 Buick LaCrosse
promoTeaserSmall: I think sedan shoppers should give this nice car a chance. But what does the Peanut Gallery think?
promoTeaser: I think sedan shoppers should give this nice car a chance. But what does the Peanut Gallery think?
metaTitle: 2014 Buick LaCrosse - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Should you buy the 2014 Buick LaCrosse? My dad and I think you should give it a chance, but what about the peanut gallery? Find out on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text:
The Car:

Price: $47,295 as tested (including destination charge)
Engine: 3.6-liter V-6
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 18 mpg city/28 mpg highway
My favorite standard features: Power rear sunshade, rear-view camera
Options I can’t live without: Plethora of safety features including forward collision alert, lane change alert, lane departure warning, rear cross-traffic alert (Driver Confidence I package, $2,125); tasteful leather and synthetic suede interior plus real wood trim (Tamo ash) (Ultra Luxury package, $2,495)
You might also be considering: Acura TL, Chrysler 300, Kia Cadenza, Lexus ES350, Lincoln MKZ, Nissan Maxima, Toyota Avalon
See more specs on the LaCrosse lineup in our Car Guide.

What I Think:

I am a lifelong Michigander, so I am biased in favor of the traditional Big Three. Nevertheless, I am realistic. I know what “Buick” means to most people: “old man car.” (Except, of course, in China, where it’s a highly desirable brand that lifts all of General Motors with it.) But back here in Michigan, I wondered: How far in the direction of modern luxury did Buick take this face-lifted LaCrosse? Did the company go too far and alienate the base of retired guys who play a little golf? Or not far enough, and eliminate itself from competition with newer mid-luxury brands that are more attractive to modern shoppers?
To find out, I went to the source: my dad, whose garage contains a 2002 Buick LeSabre. Would he buy this car? Should you?

My dad is a card-carrying retired guy; he plays a little golf; he likes his Buick just fine. When I  pulled up in the 2014 LaCrosse, his first impression was favorable, and I can see why: the updated look of Buick’s luxury mid-size car starts at the slanty LED headlights and continues with the shiny nineteen-inch wheels (there’s a twenty-inch option, too, with the Premium 2 package). As for me, I like its looks, too, with one exception: the unfortunate Buick portholes may be traditional, but they’re style demerits as far as I am concerned. They age what is otherwise a pretty good-looking exterior.

On the inside, the seats are improved, legroom and interior space are great, and the interior is truly gorgeous. I wouldn’t normally say I would be into Sangria as a leather color for my car (or anything else), but it’s tasteful in the Buick. The model we tried came with the Ultra Luxury interior package (a $2,495 option), which includes real wood accents (that actually look like real wood), a sunroof, and attractively soft-looking synthetic suede headliner and trim.

We climbed in. “There’s no way Shaq fit inside here,” my dad had to say. I watched that commercial, too, and if you call the way he squashed into the car “fit,” Shaq did. But I try never to argue with my dad! The seats are supportive and comfortable, not squashy. I especially approve of the wide cupholder console that opens up in the center of the back seat, for when you are carrying two instead of three back there. Almost (almost!) kid friendly, but you wouldn’t want them spilling their juice boxes on these seats.

Perhaps in a nod to the older, less tech-savvy customer base—and perhaps just because it’s the right thing to do—the LaCrosse’s instrument panel and controls are laid out in a clear, intuitive way, with an eight-inch information screen. There’s a height-adjustable head-up display, now in color, and I’m a big fan of those for how they cut distraction while driving. The IntelliLink infotainment system is newly upgraded and made its debut at the New York Auto Show this spring; I had no trouble figuring it out.
Aside from the V-6 version I drove, the 2014 LaCrosse is available in an eAssist mild hybrid with a four-cylinder engine. You can also get a four-wheel-drive version, but only with the V-6.

The LaCrosse’s safety features are bang up to date. Side blind zone alert, forward collision alert, lane departure warning, rear cross-traffic alert, adaptive cruise control, a backup camera…I love all of that, and I would love to see my dad driving a car with all of those justly lauded safety features on it. They are part of a Driver Confidence package (a $2,125 option); there’s also a $1,745 Driver Confidence II package that adds adaptive cruise control and a driver's safety alert seat.

Speaking of which: I was driving down narrow West Huron Street in Ann Arbor, having very positive feelings about the liveliness, comfortable ride, and even (can I say this about a Buick?) agility of the LaCrosse, when…bazinga! A vibrating feeling in my left thigh that about made me jump out of my skin. Did I trigger the weight limit on the side bolsters or what? It took a few minutes to register, then I realized it was the famous Safety Alert Seat that’s a GM exclusive. It jiggles the side of your leg when you stray too close to the edge of the lane. Too far to the left? A left jiggle. The right? A right jiggle. An appreciated, if squicky-feeling, safety feature. So much more tolerable than an annoying chime sound. I prefer the way Mercedes-Benz’s Active Lane Keeping Assist alerts you, by vibrating the steering wheel—a more dignified place to jiggle a person, in my opinion.

The Verdict:

Not to put too fine a point on it, but you can buy a lot of car in the $47,000 range. You can get a Lexus ES, an Audi A4, or a Volvo S60, and probably a lot of mid-luxury shoppers will. For a few thousand more, you’re in Mercedes-Benz E-Class territory. It is important to mention, though, that the base 2014 LaCrosse starts at $34,060, including destination. That one has a 2.4-liter four-cylinder and much better fuel economy (25 mpg in town and 36 mpg on the highway), although you can also get the V-6 at no additional charge over the four. If my dad actually shocked the family by deciding to replace his LeSabre with a new car, that’s the one he would get. His verdict was, "I'd consider this new Buick if I were still driving long distances like when I used to go down to Florida. Now I mainly just go over to the grocery store."

If somebody is already interested in the Buick brand, this is one impressive Buick. I’m not sure it will excite the person who is also looking at the Lexus ES, though. But let me sound like my dad for a minute and offer you a word of advice: Get over your Buick bias and at least try this, if you’re shopping for a sedan in this price range.

Peanut Gallery:

Molly: This is a car for Mr. Spock: everything is logical. The buttons and readouts are large and conveniently placed. It appears that the user's experience was the guiding principle when the interior was designed. I especially liked how the window control panel on the door is tilted so the driver can see the buttons easily. The passenger's-side A-pillar combined with the large dash created an enormous blind spot. I felt like right turns required a leap of faith, which is a deal breaker for me.

Christina: This car was just what I expected it to be: comfortable to drive, easy to use, and spacious without being overwhelming. Speaking of being overwhelmed, I was particularly pleased that the center stack wasn't filled with oodles of buttons and switches that required a consult with the owner's manual in order to use. The temperature was easy to adjust and it was easy to switch from the satellite radio to the AM/FM radio and back again. Just press the radio button. It's as simple as that.

Scott: In this car, I felt as if the windshield was farther away from me than in other sedans I've driven in the past. In driver ed, they tell you to look twelve seconds ahead of your vehicle to maintain a safe distance between your car and the one in front of you. Driving the LaCrosse, I felt that I had to look twenty-four seconds ahead.

Annie: The first thing I noticed about the LaCrosse was its extremely high beltline and teeny, tiny windows. They look fine from the outside, but from the driver's seat it can feel like you're sitting in a hole. An attractive hole, but not one with great visibility. I'll admit I wasn't expecting to like the LaCrosse and was for the most part pleasantly surprised by it. But even if Buick keeps building interesting cars, they've got a long way to go before they've solved their branding problem.

title: Hyundai Blue Link by the Numbers
promoTitle: Hyundai Blue Link by the Numbers

metaKeywords: Hyundai Blue Link by the Numbers
metaDescription: Hyundai Blue Link by the Numbers: the automaker has released graphic details about how many people are using their services. Must-read for numbers junkies. Read it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: Ever wonder if all those monthly subscriptions people buy for in-car telematics systems ever go to waste? I have an OnStar subscription that I have never, ever used—although I do like knowing that my car would call an ambulance for me if I got in a serious accident.  Am I the only one wasting my monthly payment? A recent internal Hyundai study of more than 400,000 Blue Link subscribers suggests that I might, indeed, be in the minority.

Hyundai Blue Link provides a bevy of services including emergency alerts, roadside assistance, navigation, and vehicle safeguard tools like curfew alert, geofencing, and stolen vehicle recovery. Since its launch nearly two years ago, Blue Link customers have interacted with the system an impressive 6.8 million times. Of those interactions, 2.9 million were for remote locking, unlocking, or starting, and 3.2 million were for monthly vehicle health reports.

Other features were less ubiquitous but still helped thousands of drivers. Blue Link users scheduled 300 vehicle service appointments per day. More than 10,000 Blue Link customers have needed emergency support. Nearly one million customers have received a smartphone alert letting them know that their car alarm was going off. If that car alarm was going off for a good reason, the owner could be better off than someone without Blue Link. Hyundai says that 88 percent of stolen Blue Link vehicles are recovered, compared with 57 percent of all stolen vehicles.

The highest rates of calls to SOS Emergency Assistance came from Michigan and Vermont, while the highest rates of use for Blue Link’s weather services came from Wyoming, Alaska, West Virginia, Kentucky, and Montana. Drivers in Southern and Mid-Atlantic states had some of the highest rates of Blue Link interactions per subscriber, while Alaska and the Plains states had some of the lowest rates.

Blue Link users have downloaded points of interest to their navigation systems more than two million times, and (perhaps predictably) the fifth most searched for restaurant was McDonald’s, coming in behind Italian, Mexican, Starbucks, and American.

These figures are interesting to the casual observer, but Hyundai will no doubt use them for more than just interesting anecdotes. The company says it will use the information it has gathered to improve the Blue Link platform and “find new ways to delight” its customers.

pageElements.text: July 16 was the ten-year anniversary of an incident in which an eighty-six-year-old man drove through a farmer's market in Santa Monica for hundreds of yards, running down and killing ten people. More than sixty were injured.

In the Melbourne, Australia, area this week, there have been three separate cases in eight days in which elderly drivers have plowed into buildings. Five passers-by were injured, and one of the drivers died.

The AARP says car accidents are the leading cause of injury-related deaths among sixty-five-to-seventy-four-year-olds and the second leading cause (after falls) among seventy-five-to-eighty-four-year-olds.

Now, obviously, these are nightmare scenarios. Most people will be able to drive safely, well into retirement years, without incident. But it's important for everyone to keep tabs on his or her own driving skills and to reevaluate whether any skills are slipping. It's equally important for us to look around at our parents and our older relatives and friends. There are several resources that are intended to help older drivers check up on themselves and thereby, perhaps, postpone as long as possible the day when they can no longer drive.
The AARP has just published a guide for physicians to counsel older patients about driving.

There's also a wealth of information on the AAA Senior Driving website, including a self-evaluation questionnaire available for download. The AAA Foundation for Traffic Safety also has an online tool, Roadwise Review Online, that helps drivers over age sixty-five evaluate their own physical mobility, flexibility, memory, and reaction time.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Here's an interview with Scott by CBS Detroit in July 2013:

Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
Vital Stats

Base price: $45,185 (includes destination)
This car’s price: $57,400 (includes destination)
EPA fuel economy: 18 mpg city/27 mpg highway (with 3.5-liter V-6 engine that makes 290 horsepower and 267 pound-feet of torque, plus six-speed automatic transmission); SH-AWD stands for Super Handling All-Wheel Drive
Safety features: Lane keeping assist, adaptive cruise control, multi-angle rear-view camera, expanded-view driver’s-side mirror, forward collision warning, lane departure warning, collision mitigation braking system (all come with Advance package, included on the Acura we tested)
Tech features: Advance and Entertainment packages (which together add nearly $6,000 to the MDX’s price) include DVD rear entertainment system with 16.2-inch screen, HDMI port for HD viewing or video-game console hookup, voice-recognition Acura navigation system with surface-street traffic data, “jewel eye” LED headlights, heated steering wheel, 12-speaker Acura/ELS Studio audio system, and more
Chief competitors: BMW X5, Cadillac SRX, Lexus RX350, Lincoln MKX

Key Points

• This is the third generation of the MDX, which was launched in 2001 as the first seven-passenger luxury crossover
• The second generation, in 2007, introduced a brand-new V-6 and SH-AWD. This was a much better riding and driving vehicle and included, for the first time, standard torque vectoring, which aids the car when it’s going through turns
• The third generation has an all-new body and a proprietary platform, whereas the last two were based on the Odyssey’s platform. The MDX’s platform will be adapted to other vehicles later
• Like the second-generation MDX, the 2014 model was tested at the famous Nürburgring racetrack in Germany, where many hot performance cars are tested. It’s Acura’s internal benchmark proving ground. And it was eight seconds a lap faster than the last one
• The Acura team considered the third row as extra seating and didn’t make it bigger because most of their customers don’t use a third row: they want to know it’s there, but most of them fold it down
• The MDX is now an inch narrower to make it easier to park. At the same time, the space between the front and back wheels (the wheelbase) is three inches longer, which gives the cabin more flexibility
• The corners of the car are more visible, the A-pillars are thinner, the size of the side mirrors is bigger, and the instrument panel is set higher—all to make it easier to maneuver for shorter people
• The holy grail of engineering is removing weight. The engineers at Acura are most proud that they were able to take 300 pounds of weight out of the structure, yet make the entire vehicle stronger. When you remove weight, fuel economy is better: the EPA says you can gain 2 mpg for every 100 pounds you remove from the car
• Forty percent of new MDX buyers are replacing an MDX they already own. That’s a huge loyalty number and the best among all Acuras

metaDescription: An SUV Bentley, destined to be the most expensive and luxurious of its kind, goes on sale in 2016. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Newborn Prince of Cambridge, meet another new Brit that’s destined to rule: a 2016 SUV that will join the three existing Bentleys in the lineup. In more welcome news this week for Great Britain, Bentley announced that the company will build the new vehicle at its headquarters in Crewe, England, creating more than 1,000 U.K. jobs, even though Bentley is the property of the Volkswagen Group.

Details on the upcoming SUV were sparse, although VW Group chairman Martin Winterkorn characterized it as “powerful, exclusive, and successful” and “the most luxurious and most powerful SUV in the market.” He also said the Bentley SUV will feature styling that will “set it apart from any other SUV on the road and will be true to the Bentley design DNA.” So you can expect every luxury, and then some.

The Bentley SUV has been talked about for some time, and reportedly some 2,000 people have already pre-ordered the future model. A concept was shown at the 2012 Geneva Auto Show, the EXP 9 F (right). Our friends at our sister publication, Automobile Magazine, say its name is likely to be the Falcon; a V-8 is expected to be standard, with a twin-turbocharged W-12 as an option.

Bentley is far from a mass marketer, having sold 4,279 cars in the first half of 2013, but the Americas are responsible for nearly a quarter of sales, so adding an SUV makes sense. The current model lineup includes the Flying Spur, the Continental, and the Mulsanne.
Are you going to start saving up for a sport-utility Bentley?

title: Turbo Movie: Go See This Escargot
promoTitle: Turbo Movie: Go See This Escargot
promoTeaserSmall: The movie about the motoring mollusk is utterly charming. Bonus: thrilling Indy 500 action.
promoTeaser: The movie about the motoring mollusk is utterly charming. Bonus: thrilling Indy 500 action.
metaTitle: Turbo Movie: Go See This Escargot - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Turbo Movie: Go See This Escargot! Sorry, had to say it. The animated Dreamworks film is not "Citizen Kane," but it's fun for the whole family. Read our review on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: A lot of people will be happy when they walk out of the new Dreamworks animated movie Turbo: little kids, who will have had an exciting hour and a half watching the action; older kids and teens, who will appreciate the party music and the voices of Snoop Dogg, Samuel L. Jackson, Michelle Rodriguez, Ryan Reynolds, and others; and adults, who will enjoy the physical comedy and the racing action coupled with a refreshing lack of the usual cartoon vulgarity and toilet humor.

But nobody will have more fun watching this than the Indianapolis Motor Speedway and IndyCar marketing people. You have never seen product placement like this. If this movie, with its Land of Oz depiction of Indianapolis and the speedway, doesn’t increase the fan base, I don’t know anything about America.

I found myself thinking, “Wow, I want to go visit Indianapolis,” a thought that never occurred to me on any of the 1,564 times I have driven past Indianapolis in the past several years. And not just that, but suddenly I do want to go see the Indy 500 live. The crowd scenes were a feast of color and movement that made you want to be in the midst of that animated jungle, and the racing action was first-rate.

The story of Turbo is nothing unusual for a modern animated feature: the underdog character dreams too big, is ridiculed, persists, goes on a quixotic adventure, meets a motley collection of characters, and eventually prevails. I wouldn’t have been surprised to see the motoring mollusk break into “I want to be where the people are” from The Little Mermaid. Only he wanted to be where the IndyCars are. Without giving away the obvious and well-worn plot, he gets there at 200-plus miles per hour, which is pretty fast for any kind of creature, let alone a snail.

You don’t want to think too long and hard about the fact that it was a drug (nitrous oxide) that he mistakenly ingested that gave him the ability to win.  Nor do you want your kids to think too long and hard about that. Could there be a Tour de France sequel starring a Daddy Longlegs?

Setting all of that aside, snail up and get to your local theater, and if you are any kind of racing fan, you will have a blast watching this movie. So will your kids, but don’t feel obligated to drag them along. In a snail shell: We think Dreamworks snailed it.
Laura Sky Brown and Molly Jean

metaDescription: 2013 Chevrolet Tahoe LTZ: Should you buy it? Here's what we think. Read the review and Peanut Gallery responses on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text:
The Car:

Price: $61,505 as tested (including destination charge)
Engine: 5.3-liter SFI V-8, 320 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic 
Fuel economy: 15 mpg city/21 mpg highway
My favorite standard features: Rear-vision camera, heated and cooled front seats, power liftgate
Options I can’t live without: Rear entertainment system (part of $2,435 Sun & Entertainment package)
You might also be considering: Ford Expedition, Nissan Armada, Toyota Sequoia

What I Think:

As a single person living and working in a college town, I don’t often find myself wishing I drove a full-size SUV. Most weeks of the year, a Chevrolet Tahoe would be a poor match for my lifestyle and needs. It just so happens that the recent weekend I spent with a 2013 Tahoe LTZ was the same weekend that the lease on my apartment ended. And was I ever glad to have the Tahoe in my corner.

The optioned-out Tahoe I tested was packed with luxurious features like heated and cooled leather seats, a rear entertainment system, and a touchscreen infotainment system, but the only thing I really cared about comes standard in all Tahoes: 108.9 cubic feet of cargo space behind the front seats.

Making use of all that space wasn’t as easy as it should have been, since the Tahoe’s third-row seats don’t fold flat and must be removed and stored separately if you need a flat load floor. Luckily, once you’ve hauled the back seats away, a power-folding second row makes freeing up the rest of the space a breeze. If you’re still worried about space, don’t be. The all-wheel-drive Tahoe is rated to tow 7,300 pounds (the rear-wheel-drive version is rated to tow 7,100 pounds), so you can hook up a trailer to fit whatever doesn’t make it in the car itself.

At 5,694 pounds, you can hardly blame the Tahoe for feeling large on the road. It is neither quick nor nimble, but that isn't a deficiency so much as it is a fact of driving something this large. A rearview camera makes parking a breeze, and the side blind zone alert takes the drama out of lane changes.

The Tahoe has standard active fuel management to shut down cylinders that aren’t needed during light driving, helping it earn 17 mpg combined. That’s not bad for a car this size, and a twenty-six-gallon fuel tank means you can make it more than 400 miles between fill-ups. But that doesn’t stop the $80-plus trips to the gas station from feeling like a punch to the wallet—a big change from the $35 fill-ups I’ve grown accustomed to in my hatchback.

The Verdict:

The Chevrolet Tahoe is not a car for city dwellers or people who need a big car for two weeks out of the year. It’s fairly expensive, a little unwieldy, and not efficient enough to make sense if you don’t genuinely need the hauling space. But if you do find yourself carting around a passel of kids (the Tahoe can be configured to seat nine) and their stuff frequently, it’s hard to imagine a car that would do it more comfortably than a nicely equipped Tahoe. The leather seats, infotainment and entertainment systems, and acres of space make it perfect for families, while the hefty tow rating gives it credibility as a utility vehicle. True, cargo space is lacking behind the third row, but then, what are trailers for?

Peanut Gallery:

Molly: The Tahoe is a difficult vehicle for me to wrap my head around. Why not spend a few thousand more and get the Suburban? You only gain a couple of miles per gallon with the Tahoe, but you lose cargo space behind the third row. In order to make the Tahoe usable as a hauler, you really need to take the third row out. That being said, it is a solid vehicle that would be great for a road trip, but the interior is very bland and utilitarian. The Suburban holds five more gallons of gas to offset the couple of miles per gallon you forfeit. Count me out on this one!

Laura: I can feel the traditional values when I sit inside this Tahoe. It does not look like a modern 2013 vehicle. However, it has many fine qualities that big, outdated vehicles possess, such as a big wide rectangle of spreading-out room in the front passenger’s seat, a simple dashboard area, and a set of wheels and tires that can handle a dirt road. In fact, a dirt road is the first place I wanted to drive it, and I was pleased with how comfortably it handled every bump. My dislikes were in the rear. I didn’t appreciate the high load-in height in back or the removable, but not stow-in-the-floor, third row of seats. I’d either buy a Chevrolet Suburban or a minivan if I wanted a vehicle this size. The Tahoe has qualities of both but achieves the perfection of neither, at least for people like me who don't tow.

Christina: I'm not a lover of big gas guzzlers, but I must say that I loved this car. Sitting up high so that I could see the road in front of me was a novelty, and the same can be said for the cooled seats (especially since I drove this during what may have been the hottest week of July). It's true that the interior isn't anything special, but it makes for a comfortable ride on long drives. I doubt that I would ever buy anything this size for myself, but if you're the type of person who needs a big vehicle to put fishing boats in the water every spring and haul them out again in the fall, this is for you.

Jean: I have never been in a Tahoe that I didn't like. Never, and I have driven many over the years. I have a one-mile unpaved driveway, and I'm forever driving the dirt roads and two-tracks on hunting and fishing expeditions. I've towed boat trailers and my old 1961 Boles Aero camper around on a Tahoe. My husband and I even towed that precious vintage aluminum egg of a camper from Michigan to North Dakota, near the border with Canada, where we bought a farm that we sold a month later. The new and improved Tahoe has cylinders that shut off to improve the V-8's fuel economy—one more reason to love it.

Who should buy a Tahoe? If you have horses, if you are an outdoors kind of person, or if you have a trailer you want to tow somewhere, this is a really rational choice that has been tried and true. Not everyone needs a Suburban. You can put all your stuff and friends in the Tahoe, and it's much more efficient and more maneuverable than the Suburban. It's the off-road minivan.

title: A Girl and Her Jeep
promoTeaserSmall: I was born a car designer's daughter, but my 2003 Jeep Liberty is perfect for my high-school life.
promoTeaser: I was born a car designer's daughter, but my 2003 Jeep Liberty is perfect for my high-school life.
metaTitle: A Girl and Her Jeep - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: A Girl and Her Jeep: A high-school student has a challenging time but still appreciates her 2003 Jeep Liberty. Read her story on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: I suppose that if you hit a mailbox and destroy your mother’s Chevrolet Equinox one month after receiving your driver’s license, you are not entitled to a luxurious first car. So, when my parents surprised me with a battered blue 2003 Jeep Liberty, I had no complaints. The rusting Jeep came complete with tattered seatbelts, coffee-stained cupholders, and the perpetual stink of cigarette smoke. She was no Ferrari, but she had a sunroof, I had a license, and we were going to taste freedom until our taste buds went numb. But first, I had to name her, and this car was a Britney if ever I saw one.

My daily seven hours of school and three hours of swim practice really limited where Brit and I traveled, and soon we almost exclusively had three destinations: home in Bloomfield Hills, Notre Dame Preparatory School in Pontiac, and the natatorium at Waterford Kettering High School. En route to these various locations, Brit developed a stalling problem. After an abrupt stop, her engine would grumble. When I tried to accelerate, she would refuse to move. My car enthusiast father (who designed the 2003 Liberty when he worked at Chrysler) assured me that it was nothing to worry about and advised me to simply put the Jeep in park, kill the engine, and then restart it. I mastered this little maneuver, and my confidence in Brit never wavered.

On Halloween 2012, I certainly wished my confidence in Brit had wavered a bit. Every Halloween, the Notre Dame Preparatory swim team dresses up together, and this past year, Team America was the theme. While the freshmen timidly applied red, white, and blue temporary tattoos to their cheeks and carefully tied ribbons in their hair, I threw caution to the wind and painted the American flag across my entire face. My blue tights, red shorts, and homemade U.S.A. T-shirt really pulled the ensemble together. Go big or go home, right?

After a long day of patriotism and attempts to stay awake during classes, I walked out of school under an angry-looking sky. The downpour soon began, and traffic quickly clogged the roads. I sat waiting at a red light on my way to practice in Waterford, and when the light changed and I pressed down on the accelerator, nothing happened. This was standard Brit behavior and did not really faze me. But when the engine refused to turn over after I performed my quick fix, I panicked and resorted to Plan B: call my dad. I made my way across the street in the pouring rain and tried to ignore the less-than-friendly hand gestures of the drivers behind me.

A police car soon arrived to find a very frazzled sixteen-year-old girl with a now-dripping American flag painted across her face, waiting in an abandoned Tubby’s parking lot. The officer was clearly having a hard time taking me seriously as I explained the situation. When he asked to speak to a parent, I handed him my iPhone, which was unfortunately covered in a yellow bunny case complete with ears and a fluffy tail. He did not succeed in stifling a laugh. My father and the officer straightened the situation out, and a tow truck came to the rescue and removed my Jeep from the congested road. My heart ached at seeing my beloved Britney on the hook.

To my delight, Britney’s only problem was her battery! After a few days in the shop, I picked her up, and the dynamic duo was reunited. She has displayed model behavior since that fateful day, and our destinations have expanded to include the Twist 'N Dip, a shacklike ice cream shop in downtown Auburn Hills where I now work. On my seventeenth birthday, Brit and I received a Life Is Good tire cover. It could not be more appropriate, because when I’m driving her, life really is good.

About Annie Boniface: I am seventeen years old and going to be a high-school senior this fall. After a year of AP Composition, I realized I really enjoyed writing and would perhaps want to pursue a career in it. When I announced my interest in journalism, my dad immediately suggested I visit Jean. (My dad, the epitome of the car guy, has a detached garage brimming with old Alfas, spends questionable amounts of time tinkering on sickly engines, and works as a designer for General Motors.) Apart from being a new fan of writing, I am on the varsity swim and tennis teams, volunteer at a hospital, and work at the Twist 'n Dip.

pageElements.text: Depending on whom you believe, electric cars might be the wave of the future. Ten years from now, we could all be driving battery-powered cars. But right now, many buyers are still nervous about making the switch to an electric vehicle. Of course, plenty of drivers are turned off by short driving ranges and long charge times. Another problem is that electric and hybrid electric vehicles often carry multi-thousand-dollar price premiums over their gasoline counterparts, which are hardly big selling points for buyers.

Faced with lackluster demand, several automakers are offering price cuts on their electric vehicles to sway buyers who might be on the fence. But how close will the discounts get you to the price of a gasoline-powered car? Here’s a rundown of manufacturers' deals on electric vehicles and how they compare with what you'd pay for their gasoline counterparts. All prices include destination.

Fiat 500e

The Fiat 500e is available to lease for three years for $199 per month after a $999 down payment. If you’re looking to buy, the 500e will set you back $32,600. Fiat offers the same lease deal for the 500 Pop, the base version. Lessees of the 500e may be on the better end of that deal, since the 500e has a standard aftermarket navigation system and automatic climate control; only the standard navigation system is available on the 500 Pop.

Ford Focus Electric

Ford is the most recent automaker to slash prices on its electric vehicle, reducing the price of the Focus Electric by $4,000 for 2014. That corresponds to a price cut of nearly ten percent. The price cut brings the base price of the car down from $39,995 to $35,995. By way of comparison, the similarly equipped Ford Focus Titanium starts at $24,910.

Honda Fit EV

Honda dropped the monthly payment on a Fit EV lease by more than $100 in June. Honda has eliminated the down payment and added a home charging station to the three-year lease deal, although lessees will have to pay for installation of the charging station. The Fit EV’s warranty will include unlimited mileage, routine maintenance, and collision coverage. The Fit Sport with navigation and the Fit EV have similar features, but the Fit Sport starts at $20,580. The quoted MSRP of a Fit EV is $36,625; with destination, the price comes to $37,415.

Nissan Leaf

The Nissan Leaf starts at $29,650 for the base model, and Nissan has a three-year lease deal with a $1,999 down payment and a $199 monthly payment. There isn’t a gasoline-powered counterpart to the Leaf, so there’s no way to say for sure how much electrification adds to the Leaf’s cost.

All of these cars qualify for a $7,500 federal tax credit and may qualify for additional state and local tax incentives, depending on where you live. In some cases these credits can take the price of a car down by as much as $10,000, which goes a long way towards closing the price gap between the gasoline and electric versions of the cars.

Even with these incentives, it’ll still be a while before you see EVs on every street corner. Honda is only planning to lease about 1,100 of its Fit EVs over a two-year period, and Ford has sold fewer than 2,000 Focus Electrics since they went on sale last year. The Nissan Leaf has made huge sales gains in the last year but still accounts for just a tiny fraction of Nissan’s car sales.
What do you think? Will price cuts make EVs an accessible technology upgrade or are they still out of reach?

pageElements.text: Choosing a color for your new car might be one of the best parts of the buying process. You’ve done all the research; decided on a powertrain, an interior color scheme, and a technology package; and now you get to decide what your vehicle is going to look like going down the road.

When my parents were shopping for my first car, I agreed to a Chevrolet HHR instead of one of the sporty death traps I really wanted on the condition it would wear Sunburst Orange Metallic paint. Chevrolet and I have both said goodbye to the HHR since then, but neither of us has lost our love of atypical paint colors.

Sonic Goes from Inferno Orange to Deep Magenta Metallic

Chevrolet has recently been using its smallest cars, the Spark and the Sonic, to showcase interesting and unusual paint colors. It’s not just for fun, either. The funky colors are a serious factor for some car shoppers. Chevrolet reports that roughly a third of Sonic buyers say color is an “extremely important” part of their buying process. The 2012 and 2013 Sonics each had a full complement of the expected paint colors, as well as an eye-catching shade dubbed Inferno Orange (right).

The Sonic is losing Inferno Orange for 2014, but fear not! General Motors is adding three new colors to the Sonic’s color palette. The first of these colors, making its appearance in August, is seen at the top of the page: Deep Magenta Metallic, a purplish hue that GM hopes will make a statement on showroom floors. That color will be only be available through October, so if you’ve always wanted a purple car, you’ll have to act quickly.

Or Maybe a Nice Dirty Blue or Dragon Green?

If magenta isn’t really your thing, November will bring Cool Blue to the Sonic’s palette. Chevrolet describes the color as “a greyish, dirty blue.” That color will be available through March 2014.

If those unique colors still aren’t tempting you, the first quarter of 2014 will bring a new permanent paint color to Sonics near you: Dragon Green. Chevrolet hasn’t relayed details about that color yet, but I’m hoping for something vibrant and metallic, like what you might see on a child’s Halloween costume. Don’t let me down, Chevy!
